PETITION.TITLE: Senate Elections: Abolition of Compulsory Preferential Voting

SPEECH.SPEAKER: WALTERS

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from 5 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That on the 10 December 1948, the General Assembly of the United Nations adopted and proclaimed the Universal Declaration of Human Rights which declares that, 'Everyone is entitled to all the rights and freedoms set forth in the Declaration. . . .' (Article 2) that 'Everyone has the right to take part in the government of his country, directly or through freely chosen representatives . . . The will of the people shall be the basis of the authority of government; this will shall be expressed in periodic and genuine elections which shall be by universal and equal suffrage and shall be held by secret vote or equivalent free voting procedures.' (Article 21 (1) and (3).)

Elections for Senators meet all requirements except one. Senators are elected periodically, by secret ballot, with universal franchise, and the quota-preferential method of proportional representation ensures that the vote values within states are equal as nearly as can be.
However the provision of the Electoral Act that compels voters to show preferences for all candidates on the ballot paper interferes with the free expression of the will of the voters, and is unjust.
Australia, as a Member State of the United Nations, is pledged to achieve observance of Human Rights and Freedoms.

We, the undersigned citizens of Australia, therefore humbly pray that the Senate will fulfil the pledge of a Member State of the United Nations and take steps to remove the compulsion from the Electoral Act in order to allow freedom of expression for everyone who has the right to vote for Senators.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Plant Breeders' Rights
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate, in Parliament assembled. We, the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth, do humbly pray that the Commonwealth Government:
1. Note that legislation establishing plant breeders' rights in other countries has had serious adverse effects, namely:

(a) Virtual monopoly control of seed production has passed into the hands of a few large international corporations seeking to profit from the exclusive rights over plant genetic materials created by such legislation.

(b) The varieties of seeds available have been restricted mainly to hybrids which will not reproduce truly and will not grow without the aid of artificial fertilisers and pesticides, thus maximising corporate profits without regard for the interests of growers and consumers.
(c) The genetic diversity of crops has been eroded, rendering them vulnerable to disease and other environmental threat.

2. Recognise that maintenance of the genetic diversity of plant varieties is crucial to the continued well-being of the Australian Nation, and take all necessary steps to preserve and promote such genetic diversity as a public recourse and to prevent exclusive control over plant genetic materials from falling into private hands.

3. Defend the vital interests of Australian farmers and gardeners, independent Australian seed companies and their employees, and consumers of Australian farm and garden produce, by rejecting any proposal to legislate for the establishment of plant breeders' rights in Australia.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for National Development and Energy. Will oil produced from Rundle and other shale oil ventures be exported? What commitments has the Government given to foreign participants in shale oil ventures regarding their rights to import Australian shale oil? In particular, what commitments has the Government given to the National corporation of Japan and the Exxon corporation?

—The clear understanding of all who participate in the production of oil, whether indigenous or synthetic crudes, is that the Australian market will be satisfied ahead of any export demands. That is understood. No commitments other than that understanding have been given to the Rundle partners. I am not aware of any commitments having been given to Japan or to Exxon, with one qualification: In a variety of discussions that have taken place between this Government and other governments regarding product sharing-that is, the product of synthetic crudes-the Government has indicated that it accepts in principle the idea of product sharing but that each case must be considered on its merits and, until the actual industry is so defined that we can know what its product will be both in quality and quantity, no decisions can be made on that matter. As to the specific details of Senator Grimes' question, it is quite clear that the Australian market has to be fulfilled ahead of any others. The Rundle partners know that.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. I refer to newspaper reports about the various councils on the aging and the claim that they will be forced to curtail some of their many services unless further funding is forthcoming. Can the Minister advise on the effectiveness of these councils? Is it a fact that their services will be restricted unless further funding is available? What consideration has the Government given to the restoration and/or improvement of Federal Government assistance?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —A number of bodies operate in the same way as the councils on the aging, namely by having a series of State organisations and a national body. There are the councils of social service, councils for rehabilitation of the disabled and so on and the councils on the aging. In each case the Commonwealth Government provides grant-in-aid funding to the national organisation and the State bodies are funded either by their constituent organisations, by State assistance or by a combination of both. In the case of the councils on the aging, until a couple of years ago the grant-in-aid was shared by the national body with the State bodies. I think it was in 1979 that the Australian Council on the Aging came into line with the other national bodies. It receives Federal funding for its own purposes and it does not pass on funds to the State councils.

ANSWER.PARA: I think that all of these bodies perform a useful service in terms of representing the interests of different welfare groups. At the Federal level they are able to bring together the views of consumers and organisations around Australia. That is, of course, of great assistance to the Government. With respect to the Australian Council on the Aging, the Government is at present engaged in a survey of the needs of the aged. I believe that from that survey will come some very useful information for the Government with respect to its policy development in this area. I think it is likely that the State councils will have to continue to rely on the support of their constituent bodies and the support of State governments, which have a similar interest to the Commonwealth Government in maintaining such representative organisations.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ANSETT AIRLINES OF AUSTRALIA: OPERATING PROFIT

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Transport to the report of Ansett Airlines of Australia which was tabled in the Senate yesterday. Can the Minister explain why, more than eight months after the period in question, the financial statement provided to the Parliament is not audited? As a chartered accountant-I know that this is not his area of ministerial expertise-can he explain the apparent conflict between the operating profit claimed before tax of $28.3m and the amount of $20.3m set aside for tax?
—You don't like Ansett.

—I will ask the same question aboutTrans-Australia Airlines tomorrow, if I am given time. Is it true that company tax is levied at the rate of 47 1/2 per cent and that with other items, notably the sale of aircraft, Ansett claims an overall profit of $14.6m? Does the amount set aside for tax indicate that the real profit before tax would be in the vicinity of $43m? If so, how does he interpret this profit figure in the light of the current debate about the level of domestic air fares?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I noted Senator Button's comments in making the point that the Ansett report is not audited. I am not clear as to whether this report has been drawn up separately from the financial statements of Ansett Transport Industries Ltd, which would have been presented to the Corporate Affairs Commission in the normal course of events. Therefore, I am unable to say specifically whether that statement has been audited. In looking at that statement yesterday, I noted that no auditor's certificate was attached to it. However, it was clear that the statement was separate from the total operations of Ansett Transport Industries and represented only the airline operations. I would imagine, therefore, that if the total company had been audited in the normal way, as required by company legislation, that statement would have been so audited. Nevertheless, I will take that point on notice and check it out for the honourable senator.

ANSWER.PARA: With regard to the figures that he mentioned, I do not have those details before me. Clearly, I do not carry them around in my mind. However, it would seem to me, again remembering some of the comments made last night in the debate on this matter, that the calculation of the profit of some $43m which Senator Button has mentioned appears to be based on very simplistic understandings of the way accountants draw up these figures. I believe that there are probably some amounts which represent actual costs, which are in fact economic costs to the airline and which are not taken into account as taxation deductions. Many expenses come into that category. One of the chief ones, of course, is provision for long service leave. Another might be the cost of depreciation on the assets which would be written off in excess of the rate allowable by the Commissioner of Taxation but which otherwise might represent a real cost to the business.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to ask a supplementary question. Is that the Minister's explanation for the figures?

—I predicated my remarks on the basis that I did not have the information immediately at my fingertips. If Senator Button requires an undertaking, I will refer the matter to the Minister and obtain a more detailed reply.

However, I will seek the information and advise him as soon as possible.

—I ask a question of the Leader of the Government in the Senate which follows the excellent question asked of him yesterday by Senator MacGibbon concerning the granting of mining rights to the Winchester South steaming coal deposit which was awarded to the consortium of British Petroleum Australia, Sir Leslie Thiess and Westfield Holdings companies. Has the Minister seen suggestions that this deal was pushed through the Queensland Cabinet by the National Party Minister for Mines, Energy and Police, Mr Gibbs, without reference to the State Treasury and, extraordinarily, without Mr Edwards, the State Treasurer, properly understanding it? Senator Lewis is trying to interject, but I point out that I am quoting the Minister. If Senator Lewis would like to keep abreast of what Mr Edwards said, I am sure he would support the thrust of my question. Will the Commonwealth Government intervene in this arrangement which surely constitutes yet another example of a large transnational company buying up Australia's mineral wealth and evidently at a much cheaper price than might reasonably have been expected? Will the Commonwealth Government now take the initiative of holding a constitutional referendum designed to give the Commonwealth adequate power over energy and resources so as to prevent States from selling Australia's natural resources to multinationals, as has been done in this case? Does the Minister have any information that the dubious circumstances in which this deal was concluded are related in any way to any substantial donation to the National Party of Queensland through the Bjelke-Petersen Foundation or by any other means?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it is fair to assume that politicians are honest unless we have evidence to the contrary, otherwise we would all be very uncomfortable here together. Therefore, I must say that if anybody has any information which suggests that there is any illegal transaction of any kind, please let me know, otherwise I suggest that inferences are disorderly in this regard. As to the Winchester coal undertaking, I have not read the Press, except cursorily. The fact of the matter is that, as Senator Chipp well knows, this is a matter which lies entirely within the State Governments' rights, and the Commonwealth has absolutely no responsibilities or rights in regard to this matter at all. Therefore, it is not within our present capacity to say what are the facts. If there is any further information that can be obtained to throw light on this subject, I will be happy to obtain it.

ANSWER.PARA: Clearly, the Commonwealth cannot intervene. As to whether there is merit in the Commonwealth's seeking a referendum to amend the Constitution in order to assume such powers, that would be a policy matter. I will refer the matter to the Prime Minister and look at it myself to see whether that should be so. The presumption within a federation ought to be that any sovereign government has both the capacity and the integrity to carry out its duties. One must assume, lacking other evidence, that not only has the Queensland Government the sovereign right to do this but also it has done so capably. Any suggestion of a decision made by a government being related to a donation to a political party, while not strictly offensive under the Standing Orders, implies that politicians are dishonest.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a reflection on the Chair. Don't you know that?

—No, it is not. I pointed out that the statement was not strictly in breach of Standing Orders. I take the view that in the absence of any information to the contrary, politicians are honest. I will treat all my colleagues on both sides of the chamber accordingly.

There were discussions with Commonwealth and State fishing authorities and commercial fishing interests but to date no firm proposals have flowed from those discussions.

I will make inquiries of the Regional Director of the Department of Social Security on the matter raised by the honourable senator and find out if it is true that some aspects of the operation are to be closed, what use is being made of it and whether, in fact, it should be closed, if that is the proposal. QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN BROADCASTING COMMISSION: SECOND COUNTRY RADIO NETWORK

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Communications. Are there any plans for the broadcast of the second network of the Australian Broadcasting Commission to be extended in Queensland, specifically into the Townsville region? If so, when will this be done and if not, why not?

—I am advised that, as yet, no decisions have been made concerning the establishment of a second country radio network in Queensland or in any other State. That is the answer to 'if not, why not?' The Australian Broadcasting Commission has stated that the establishment of a second country radio network throughout Australia is its next priority, and a plan is under consideration by the national broadcasting station planning committee. However, no proposals have been submitted yet to the Government. A second country network is part of a 10-year plan currently being prepared by the national broadcasting station planning committee. The honourable senator will no doubt be pleased to learn that planning is under way for the installation of an ABC FM transmitter to serve Townsville. That is a slightly different matter but still worth knowing. That transmitter will extend to Townsville the ABC FM program originating in Adelaide. On present planning it is expected that the transmitter will commence operation in November 1981.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer, concerns transfer pricing. How many times in the last financial year did the Commissioner of Taxation find it necessary to invoke section 136 of the Income Tax Assessment Act? Further, on how many occasions was he successful in raising revenue through the concept of notional pricing to overcome the situation whereby some transnational companies sell their products out of Australia at cost to avoid the full impact of Australian income tax?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I am advised that formal determinations in accordance with section 136 of the Income Tax Assessment Act and/or the relevant provisions of the various double tax agreements were made on nine occasions during the year ended 30 June 1980. —I direct a question to the Minister for Social Security. Does it currently take about six months to obtain a decision on an application for an invalid pension lodged in Queensland? If so, why is there such an unacceptable delay? What steps are being taken to rectify the situation?

—Coincidentally, I have just been reading a letter from a member of the Queensland Parliament making a similar allegation. I was somewhat surprised to get it. There have been some delay areas, particularly with respect to appeals, that I have been concerned about and trying to rectify, but I would have to say that this is news to me. I will inquire into the matter. The complaint I have received is that there is a limited number of medical practitioners available to undertake the necessary examination of applicants. I will examine that in conjunction with the Department of Health, which has the responsibility, of course, for that aspect of the work, to see whether there are delays and, if there are, what can be done to remove them.

—My question is directed to the Minister for National Development and Energy. What is the typical cost in fuel economy of the use of a car air conditioning set? Is the fitting of such sets increasing rapidly in this country, at considerable cost to our fuel conservation policy? Is the main cause of this situation overseas design rules which force modern cars into being glass boxes on wheels-almost perfect green houses; good for growing flowers but bad for people-and quite unsuitable for our summer climate, althought they may be suitable for the cooler climates of Europe, Japan and North America? Will the Minister consult his colleagues about encouraging at least one of our manufacturers to design and produce cars which would be more suitable for our climate and which would not require air conditioning? Might we not even be able to export some of these cars to tropical countries for which the current North American, Japanese and European designed cars are as unsuitable as they are for us and which also have the need to conserve fuel?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The estimates of the additional fuel consumption caused by the use of air conditioners in cars vary considerably, depending on the size of the vehicle, the speed in traffic or on the open road and the weather conditions. Some estimates put the additional use as high as 15 per cent whilst other tests have shown that cars with air conditioners used at cruising speed on the open road do not incur a fuel penalty compared with similar cars driven without air conditioners but with the windows open. Honourable senators will know that with the windows open there is an aerodynamic drag on cars which increases the amount of fuel consumed. The National Energy Advisory Committee, in its report, quoted an average penalty for air conditioners in the order of 5 per cent. So it is somewhere between 5 per cent and 15 per cent.

ANSWER.PARA: The fact is that apparently there is no Australian design rule which specifies the area of glass which can be incorporated into motor cars. Glass areas are incorporated to achieve design objectives regarding safety, field of vision, et cetera. Nevertheless, the honourable senator has raised an important question as to whether the design of the cars produced in Australia is suitable for the kind of climate in Australia or whether cars are designed for winter conditions elsewhere, and to that extent I will have this matter examined. I will ask my colleague in another place, Sir Phillip Lynch, to look at it. Of course, a major factor in the success of the export of cars to tropical areas would be their price. The question of whether a car uniquely designed for such climates could compete with existing designs is no doubt a matter for commercial judgment. What is needed, of course, to get the price of cars down is long production runs, as the honourable senator would know. Nevertheless, I think he has raised a very interesting point. Perhaps in the design of the world car we are getting a world climate car and that is not suitable to Australia. I will have the matter looked at and see whether anything can be done about it.

Will the Minister advise us who is talking to whom and what the involvement of the Federal Government is in this matter? Will he also advise what responsibility the Federal Government sees for the Western Mining Corporation and the company responsible for the disposal of the waste with regard to transportation, security costs and storage costs? Has a date been set by the Singapore Government for a decision to be made by the Australian Government about the disposal of the waste?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The facts are as I stated them recently. Inadvertently included in some scrap metal which was derived from Western Mining Corporation Ltd and which was exported by Simsmetal Pty Ltd to Singapore to a smelter, a measuring gauge which contained some radioactive material was included. Upon it being known by the health authorities in Western Australia that the gauge was missing, the Singapore health authorities were notified and the material secured. Discussions have been held to see whether the material could be disposed of safely in Singapore. Discussions have been held between the Federal Government and the Singapore Government. My understanding is that, recently, discussions have been held between the Commonwealth Government and the State Government and the industry concerned to ensure, at the request of the Singapore Government, that the material is returned to Australia, properly handled and properly secured for the future.

ANSWER.PARA: It is, of course, a responsibility of the Commonwealth Government to ensure that the movement to and from Australia of such materials shall be safely handled and offer no health risk in any way. It is the primary responsibility of the State Government concerned to ensure the security of the material in Western Australia. I am advised that it is a relatively easy matter to ensure the enduring total security of the material in Western Australia without threat to any human beings at all. That advice has been given presumably to the Government as well as to the industry concerned. I am not aware of a date being fixed in this matter but I do stress to Senator Coleman what I said recently. In industry and in medicine there is a very considerable traffic and movement of these radioactive materials and, therefore, an experience and ability to handle their disposal. There ought not be any real difficulties in ensuring that the material is properly disposed of. I believe that above the ground it will produce no radioactive effects at all on the environment and no harm to people. In relation to a date being fixed, if a date has been determined I will find out and let the honourable senator know.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, concerns increasing Australian overseas aid. Will the Government, in the current preparation of the Budget, substantially increase the level of overseas aid to programs of need in developing countries so that the level of Australian aid returns to the high-watermark of 0.6 per cent of gross national product reached a few years ago? Further, during the life of this Parliament will the Government increase the level of Australian aid to 0.7 per cent of gross national product which is the goal determined by a United Nations decision which had Australia's support? Moreover, I submit that such levels of aid would give direct expression to the policies set out by the Prime Minister last month in Adelaide in his speech about liberalism and the Third World?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — It is known that the Government has a considerable overseas aid program. It is a program that has had the priority of government in the Budgets which have been cast in past years. As to the forthcoming Budget, I am not in any position to speculate as to what the Government may be able to do or may wish to do with regard to this item of expenditure. I stress again that we have always freely accepted responsibilities with regard to aid for developing countries and those in emergency circumstances. In the course of the preparation of this Budget, those matters will again be before us. I have noted the statements made by the honourable senator with regard to percentages of aid that may be the objectives of many countries and I will draw those percentages to the attention of my colleague, the Minister for Foreign Affairs.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Melzer Sen J.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Yesterday, in reply to a question, the Minister for Finance indicated that the Government was deeply concerned at the growth of the 'black economy'. I take it that the Government is aware of an article appearing in the Australian of 17 February written by Mr Peter Clyne, which begins:

QUESTION.PARA: It should be stated at the outset that I am a professional tax dodger, not a tax reformer.

I teach my clients how to pay no taxes, or how to be their own tax assessor and pay whatever they wish. The morality or otherwise of their decision to pay less, or nothing at all, is none of my business.

Is the Government going to take action against such blatant advocacy of tax avoidance? Does it intend making tax avoidance an offence? Will it take action to prevent people such as Peter Clyne making a business of tax avoidance when no tax is paid on large incomes and when wage earners have no option but to have their tax taken from their wages before they receive them, thus being forced to carry the bulk of the burden of running the country?

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that one of the perennial occupations of the Australian Taxation Office is to pursue Mr Clyne. I am not aware of the success or failure of that endeavour. Mr Clyne, ever since his student days, has been renowned for his amoral pronouncements on attitudes to life. I can say only that he is not unknown to the Taxation Office. I gather that by now some kind of love-hate relationship has developed between them. I think Mr Clyne deliberately portrays himself as a studied eccentric in order to attract publicity. I suggest that we need not--
—He is costing us a lot of money.

—This Government has been pursuing Mr Clyne. It would have been a good idea if other governments beforehand had had the same enthusiasm for the pursuit of tax avoiders. It is a sad fact that at both ends of the personal income tax scale there is a significant amount of tax evasion, both by those people who receive high incomes and by those people who receive cash payments. The Government has been seeking earnestly to introduce laws to ensure that these people pay tax. If anyone has any useful suggestions they will be very welcome. We will continue that pursuit.

—Is the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs aware of any difficulties being experienced by some Aboriginal pastoral interests in the Northern Territory in obtaining funding from the Aboriginal Development Commission to carry out stock control programs in order to meet the 1984 deadline for tuberculosis and brucellosis control in Australia? Is the Minister aware of any reports that ADC has not yet been given access to funds for allocation to Aboriginal pastoral properties to improve fencing and yards, et cetera? Will the Minister advise whether this is, in fact, correct? If it is correct, will the Government look into the matter with a view to ensuring that stock control programs are not jeopardised through lack of funds?

—I am advised by the Aboriginal Development Commission that it is not aware that any Aboriginal communities are experiencing difficulties in obtaining funds from the Commission for the tuberculosis and brucellosis control campaigns. The Commission did receive funds in its enterprise grant program for this financial year to assist pastoral properties to meet their targets for the tuberculosis and brucellosis control programs. This would include funding for fencing and yards, et cetera. Those funds have been released as they have been programmed, provided the organisations have met the ADC grant funding requirements. No further funding is available from the ADC for this financial year, but applications will be received for subsequent financial years dependent upon the level of funding made available to the Commission. I make the point that it is not entirely the responsibility of the ADC to provide the funds for this purpose and that Aboriginal communities which operate pastoral leases have other sources of income, including income from sales of cattle. We have no evidence to suggest that Aboriginals operating pastoral leases will not be able to meet their obligations under the tuberculosis and brucellosis control campaign.

—I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Transport: Has the Sydney Sun newspaper today reported that Ansett Airlines of Australia, through its joint chief executive, Rupert Murdoch, last year urged the Federal Government to sell Trans-Australia Airlines? Does the report say that Mr Murdoch also urged the Government to introduce automatic fare rises for both domestic airlines, a proposal which would have the effect of keeping up Ansett's profits? Were these and other proposals canvassed in a letter written by Mr Hunt after a discussion with Mr Murdoch? Will the Minister arrange for the tabling of all correspondence between the Minister for Transport and Mr Murdoch to allay suspicions of special favours being done for Ansett Airlines?

—I have no information at all on the question which Senator Walsh asks, nor have I seen the article in the Sydney Sun this afternoon. I have not seen the paper at all. However, I will refer the matter to my colleague and ask for an early reply.

—Is the Minister for Trade aware that the present South Australian Government is continuing from the previous Dunstan Labor Government with regard to high level research, including that with a leading overseas group, for the establishment of a uranium enrichment plant in South Australia? As South Australia has potentially the largest copper, gold and uranium mine in the world at Olympic Dam, more commonly known as Roxby Downs, and is ideally situated to receive and process uranium from the Northern Territory, will the Federal Government give assistance to the South Australian Government for the establishment of a uranium enrichment plant in that State, which is far more advanced in research and negotiations and better situated than any other State for the enrichment of uranium process?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware that the South Australian Government has, for some time, been studying the possibility of establishing a uranium enrichment industry in South Australia. The Commonwealth has facilitated its studies by making possible the supply of unclassified, commercial information from a number of foreign enrichment technology holders. It has also done this for other interested States and the Northern Territory.

ANSWER.PARA: My understanding is that the South Australian Uranium Enrichment Committee is in dialogue with what is called the Uranium Enrichment Group of Australia. Senator Young will recall that UEGA is a private enterprise joint venture made up of four major Australian companies. The joint venture is undertaking, at its own cost, a study of the technical and economic viability of establishing a uranium enrichment industry in Australia, and we have a particular interest in the long term development of Roxby Downs. As to the South Australian Government's interest in these matters, it is in close and continuing consultation with both the Commonwealth and UEGA and we are aware of its views. The Commonwealth considers that any future Australian uranium enrichment industry would need to be commercially viable in its own right. To this end, we are facilitating UEGA's work, and we believe that any decisions on proceeding, siting, or other matters must be based on commercial factors. The study is well advanced.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations and refer to the creation of a government company to operate the Christmas Island phosphate deposits. I ask: In view of the lack of any reasonable industrial relations in the past, does the Minister contemplate bringing the Christmas Island work force within the ambit of the Australian arbitration apparatus?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable senator's question touches on an area in which there have been difficulties, that is, in industrial relations on Christmas Island. He will be aware, as will many other honourable senators, that in late 1979 the Government appointed Mr Sweetland, a former senior executive of the Broken Hill Pty. Co. Ltd, to examine that and other matters which were of concern on the island. The report which Mr Sweetland prepared was in fact tabled in Parliament early last year, and no doubt the honourable senator has seen it. The report has now been carefully considered by the Government and, following that consideration, the Government proposes to take certain action which touches on the areas of concern to Senator Mulvihill.

ANSWER.PARA: One of the most important initiatives is that the Government is to provide for a review of the Christmas Island Arbitrator's decisions by an appeal bench of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. I think this will bring the Christmas Island workers within the Commonwealth arbitration system in the way that the honourable senator was suggesting. The Government intends to introduce legislation in this session of Parliament to give effect to this decision, which was taken by the Government only after the closest consultation with all interested parties, including the Australian Council of Trade Unions and the principal unions representing the Christmas Island work force. The new arrangements will mean that the industrial practices and procedures applying on the island will more closely approximate those applying in the various mainland industrial jurisdictions.

The honourable senator also referred to the formation of a Commonwealth-owned organisation. As from 30 June 1981, the British Phosphate Commissioners will cease operations on the island and a new organisation, owned and controlled by the Commonwealth, will be responsible for the island's mining operations. The Government has decided to appoint a trade union representative to the board of the new company and proposes to discuss this appointment shortly with the ACTU. In order to ensure an harmonious transitional period, the Government has also agreed that former employees of the British Phosphate Commissionersshall have continued employment with the new organisation, with no loss of the service entitlements which may have accrued from their previous employment with the Phosphate Commissioners.

TALK.START.PARA: —That will be worker participation.

—That will be worker continuation, but there will be union participation at the board level. I think that in a series of ways the Government has moved to meet the problems raised by the honourable senator in his question. I am sure that he will join with the Government in hoping that this will lead to stable and harmonious industrial relations on the island.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer and relates to section 36AAA of the Income Tax Assessment Act. Footrot is a serious stock disease and is increasing in some States of Australia. Traditional control methods are expensive, painful to the stock, very time consuming, and not always successful. The costs are deductible in the financial year of expenditure. A more satisfactory solution is to sell all susceptible stock on the farm and replace them after a few weeks, by which time the footrot virus will already have died on the farm. The profit made from the sale of those stock is subject to taxation, which in some cases can be about equal to the value of the stock sold. Will the Minister suggest to the Treasurer that he consider amending section 36AAA with a view to stopping the discouragement of farmers from adopting better farming practices.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I have noted Senator Thomas's suggestion. I will refer it to the Treasurer and seek a response from him.

—My question is directed to Senator Peter Baume in his capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Health and Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to the article headed 'Scandal Over Police Seizure of Doctors' Files' in the current issue of the Bulletin? Does the Government approve of the seizure of files dealing with confidential medical information and comments on patients attending a private psychiatrist? Does not this invasion of the privacy of a doctor-patient relationship place in jeopardy the treatment and rehabilitation of patients suffering from mental disturbance? Does the Minister acknowledge the natural and extreme sensitivity of such patients and their medical practitioners? Is the Government satisfied that the Australian Federal Police are justified in breaking into doctors' surgeries and seizing confidential files, interviewing disturbed patients and generally hassling the psychiatric profession? Is that in the best interests of the community and the health of patients? Finally, in view of the seriousness of the allegations made in the article, will the Minister, as a matter of extreme urgency, have the present practice of the issuing to the police of warrants authorising such intrusions stopped and have a more humane process established after consultation with the Private Psychiatrists Association and the Australian Medical Association?

—There are a large number of parts to the honourable senator's question. I have not seen the article in the Bulletin and do not know the particular circumstances to which he referred. I think those matters should be referred to my colleague for a specific answer. I am aware that the Australian Federal Police are able to seize records where they have reason to suspect that certain Commonwealth laws have been broken. There has been some conflict because, as the honourable senator pointed out, sensitivities are involved in the seizure of medical records. I do not believe that the activities of themselves place in jeopardy the rights of patients, as he suggests might be the case. The honourable senator asked whether action should be taken to stop the practice of issuing warrants and to replace it with some other appropriate mechanism. I believe that the medical profession, through various representative bodies, has already made contact with the Government in a number of ways to raise this point. I think it best that I refer this matter to my colleague for more detailed consideration.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport. Since the Minister's attention was drawn last night to the financial statements and annual report of Trans-Australia Airlines, will he ask the Minister for Transport whether he is concerned at the apparent reduction in the airline's profit and the reasons given in the statement of the Chairman of TAA for the huge fall in that profit? Is the Minister satisfied that the Trans-Australia Airlines accounts are accurate in disclosing, upon a basis which is comparable with the business sector of the Australian economy, the financial position and affairs of Trans-Australia Airlines? Are the Government and the Minister concerned about the $140m which is stated in the annual report as the superannuation liability that the airline would have faced at the year ended 30 June 1980-nearly a year ago-and which presumably has increased somewhat since then? Do the annual report and the Chairman's statement totally confirm the statements made by me last year that the liabilities of Trans-Australia Airlines exceeded its total assets by a very substantial margin? To overcome many of the problems being experienced by TAA, will the Minister consider restructuring TAA as a wholly or substantially government owned public company rather than a statutory authority?

—Senator Rae is seeking details on a number of matters. I do not have information at my fingertips to enable me to confirm or deny any of those matters. He raised several matters which are of genuine concern to him and which I know he has referred to on earlier occasions. In fact, he referred to them in a speech in the Senate last night. I undertake to refer his remarks to my colleague and to obtain an early reply for him.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport. Over the last week have there been attacks by Ministers on the veracity, integrity and competence of the three members of the Holcroft Independent Public Inquiry into Domestic Air Fares? Has Mr Warwick Holcroft, Chairman of the inquiry, said that he has now had his full share of public inquiries? Has another member of the inquiry, Professor Hogan, when asked whether he would serve on another public inquiry initiated by this Government, said that his feelings were best expressed by Eliza Doolittle in My Fair Lady when she said: 'Not bloody likely'? Given this reaction by these gentlemen and the behaviour of the Ministers, does the Minister expect the Government to have difficulty in future in getting suitable people to serve on government committees of inquiry?

—It will probably come as a surprise to the honourable senator that I do not have that information at my fingertips. However, confirmation is required of the many facts that the honourable senator has asserted, none of which sound reasonable. Nevertheless they deserve investigation. I will refer the matter to the Minister for Transport and obtain a reply.

—My question is directed to the Minister for National Development and Energy. Have any special or extra funds been applied to wind power research from the National Energy Research, Development and Demonstration Council over the past two years? Is there any problem in developing operational commercial trials in areas known to be appropriate, and is there any program to establish locational suitability for future work in wind power?

—Throughout the world there is a great deal of interest in energy from renewable resources, as distinct from the expendable and non-renewable hydrocarbons, and wind power along with solar power and biomass which constitute matters for close investigation. Wind power research has been continually supported at a modest level under the NERDDC program. In 1978, for example, about $250,000 was committed. Over the last two years a modest sum has been committed to three projects. In South Australia a firm called Dunlite has developed a hybrid energy system suitable for isolated homestead power supply which is based on a new five kilowatt wind generator. Indeed, I opened such a demonstration home. In Western Australia, in conjunction with the State Energy Commission of Western Australia, two medium scale commercial wind machines are being installed on Rottnest Island for operational trials.
—The Minister for wind power.

—No one would need to have a more expert knowledge of wind power to understand the honourable senator who interjects. One needs an expert technical knowledge and I acknowledge that further research into the Labor Party will be conducted under NERDDC. The Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation has undertaken theoretical studies into the possible integration of wind power into State electricity grids. In conjunction with the Hydro-Electric Commission in Tasmania, wind measurements have been recorded at various sites on King Island to determine the possible locational suitability for installing a medium scale wind generator to substitute for the current diesel generated electricity supply.

—Has the Attorney-General seen news reports today about comments by Mr Justice Davies of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal to the effect that the News corporation may be in daily breach of the provisions of the Broadcasting and Television Act? Is the Minister, as the responsible officer-I refer to questions asked and answered last year-continuing to keep an alert eye on this matter? Does he agree with the conclusion of His Honour that it would be desirable if this matter were brought on as quickly as possible in order that the issues for determination may be concluded?

—I noted the news reports to which Senator Button referred. I have, of course, a continuing and important interest in the question which is discussed here from time to time. I do not propose to make any comment on the decisions or the observations of His Honour on this matter as, indeed, I do not on any other court proceedings.

—I direct a question to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and it is supplementary to the question asked earlier by Senator Rae which directed the Minister's attention to the figure in the Trans-Australia Airlines annual report attributed to the superannuation aspect. As the attention of the Government was earlier drawn to this matter by Senator Rae and as the figure involved is approaching $140m as at 30 June last year, is the Government concerned about it? What action does the Government propose to take?
—The action which I outlined to Senator Rae in reply to his question was that I would refer the matter to Mr Hunt, the Minister for Transport. I propose to do the same with Senator Jessop's question.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Mr President, I wish to make a personal explanation. I claim to have been misrepresented. Yesterday after Question Time in the House of Representatives, Mr Burr, the member for Wilmot, claimed that I had quoted out of context a speech that he made in the House of Representatives on 25 February and that I had mis- represented him. I claim that the honourable member has severely misrepresented me because, in fact, in a speech which I made in the Senate last Thursday night, I quoted directly from the Hansard. I wish to read from the report again in order to put the record straight. Mr Burr's speech is reported on page 158 of the House of Representatives Hansard of 25 February. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Liberal Party of Australia maintains that elected members are free to make their own judgment. However, the reality is vastly different. If a member steps out of line or rocks the boat in any way, he can be subjected to the most intense pressure, from both the parliamentary executive and the party organisation. On the other hand, members who passively toe the line often are rewarded with overseas trips or junior portfolios.

Rank and file members of the Liberal Party complain that the Public Service has too much power and influence, yet the discipline that they, through their organisation, exert entrenches the Public Service power. If a member suggests that a department is inefficient or that a matter of government operation should be scrutinised, he is accused of disloyalty to the Minister, to the government and to his party, with a covert threat to withdraw endorsement.

Mr President, it appears that the very thing about which Mr Burr is complaining has happened to him because he felt the heavy hand of the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) on the back of his neck and as a result of his remarks on--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator, you are making a personal explanation, are you?
—Yes, it is.
—And it concerns you?

—Yes, I have quoted the words used by Mr Burr. He has claimed in the other House that I took his speech out of context. I have quoted again the exact words which Mr Burr used. I cannot do any better than to quote from Hansard. I was saying that what Mr Burr was complaining about has now fallen upon himself. He is now trying to rehabilitate himself in the eyes of the Prime Minister by claiming, after Question Time yesterday, that I quoted his remarks out of context and misrepresented him. I did no such thing.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator CARRICK

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday, Senator O'Byrne asked me a question about an accident involving a semi-trailer loaded with radioactive materials. I regret that I could not give him the information at the time. In fact, it appears that the incident occurred on the day I left Australia to go abroad to the International Energy Agency meeting and I had not registered the fact that the incident had occurred. I now point out that on 4 December 1980 a semi-trailer overturned on the Pacific Highway near Port Macquarie-regrettably killing the driver-and blocking the highway with cargo, including DDT, foodstuffs and packages containing radioactive material. The highway was cleared by emergency services. The radioactive substances involved in the accident were part of a density measuring device for geophysical logging of bore holes. These two substances had half lives of 30 years and 458 years respectively and are moderately to highly toxic.

INTERJECT.PARA: The Australian Atomic Energy Commission officer who inspected the accident site, shortly after the accident, on behalf of the State Health Commission-I interpolate that happily he was on holiday at the time and therefore on the spot-reported that, although the outer packaging had been broken, the radio-isotope container showed no sign of damage and no radioactive material escaped. The sources were being transported, in accordance with international and State regulations, in containers designed to withstand such accidents. The radiation levels on the surface of the containers would have been such that they could have been handled safely without special protection. Normal procedures, in the case of such accidents, are for the police to contact the State Health Commission which has legislative responsibility for matters relating to radioactive materials. If necessary, the Health Commission contacts the Atomic Energy Commission for assistance. Both the Atomic Energy Commission and the Health Commission operate 24-hour emergency services and a safety officer is on duty at Lucas Heights at all times.

Senator O'Byrne referred to an incident between the State police and the police at Lucas Heights. I am advised that the State police contacted the Australian Federal Police security officer at the Commission who, in fact, was briefed on the procedures to be adopted. The reason why that policeman apparently did not follow the procedures is the subject of investigation. Nevertheless, I indicate that it so happened that there was an officer of the Atomic Energy Commission at Port Macquaries at the time of the accident and that he was at the scene shortly afterwards. At the request of the police medical officer, medical tests have been carried out on the policemen concerned but it would seem unlikely that any ill effects would have resulted from handling the containers. It is noted that the truck was reported as containing a large quantity of DDT and a fungicide called sodium propanate. As I have said, the incident coincided with the day I left for abroad. I apologise that I did not have the details of the accident because, of course, I was not here when it happened.
Senator O'Byrne-Have you advice as to what happened to the food on the truck?

TALK.START.PARA: —As far as I know there was no contamination. I will follow that question up too because any of these questions are worth chasing in the most minute detail.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Dame MARGARET GUILFOYLE

TALK.START.PARA: — Last Thursday, Senator Tate asked a question in regard to El Salvador. I have consulted with the Minister for Foreign Affairs and I am advised that the Australian Government has made its own assessment of the situation in El Salvador. As to the causes of the present conflict, El Salvador's political instability has arisen from a prolonged period of acute inequality of income and wealth and repressive governments in a densely populated country. Following a coup in 1979 a series of governments have attempted a number of major reforms including, crucially, land reform. Caught between right wing and left wing extremists the present Government has found it increasingly difficult to pursue its efforts at reform. Violence and terrorism have accelerated and human rights have been violated.

INTERJECT.PARA: Based on the Government's own assessment of the present situation and the Minister's conversation in Washington last Friday with Vice President Bush, it is clear that a two-pronged approach is necessary in El Salvador. While strong words and actions are justified to cut off external arms supplies for left wing guerrilla movements, support for economic reform and for social reform is also necessary to remove the historical causes of political instability and this is recognised by the United States Government. While the Minister is not able to release the details on which the Government's assessment is based, he can say that on the basis of its own assessments, the Government accepts evidence provided by the United States of external support for left wing guerrillas in El Salvador. As the Prime Minister said last Thursday, we consider that the United States is entirely right in seeking to cut off that source of disturbance, that source of revolution, in Latin America. The Prime Minister's statement was welcomed warmly by the United States Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Georges Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the answer.
I seek leave to continue my remarks.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday Senator Ryan asked me a question concerning alcohol rehabilitation services in Alice Springs and Darwin. She asked me whether I was aware that no detoxification centre and no psychiatric services for Aboriginal people were available in Alice Springs or in Darwin. Later she asked me a similar question. I said that I would come back to the honourable senator when I had more information. I have a little information relating to alcohol rehabilitation services which are funded through my Department in Alice Springs and Darwin. The Department has been funding Aboriginal alcohol rehabilitation centres in Katherine and Alice Springs since 1976-77 and in Darwin since 1977-78. I note, for example, that this financial year in Darwin the Department is providing $55,000 for capital costs and $98,000 for recurrent costs. In Alice Springs this year for an alcohol rehabilitation centre we are providing $39,000 in capital costs and almost $100,000 in recurrent costs. In addition to the direct alcohol rehabilitation funding carried out under the grants-in-aid program, my Department has provided further funding under programs which are carried out by the Northern Territory Government-the grants-in-aid social support program. The following funding has been provided to the Northern Territory under this program in the last three years: 1978-79, $426,000; 1979-80, $559,000; 1980-81, $581,000. I am not suggesting that the matters raised by the honourable senator were not important or relevant. I just thought this information would round out what was available yesterday.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —At Question Time on 26 February 1981, Senator Martin asked me a number of questions regarding the admission of visitors to Parliament House. I have had this matter investigated and advise that, in regard to the specific questions raised, the people who have a right to bring visitors into the non-public areas of Parliament House are senators and members and all holders of Parliament House photographic passes, including journalists accredited to the Press galleries. Similar requests are made to others as are made to the senators and members to escort their visitors when in Parliament House. Escorted passes are issued to visitors who, with the approval of the senator, member or passholder, visit such persons. When escorted passes are issued, the senator, member or passholder sponsoring the visitor is requested to escort his visitor.

INTERJECT.PARA: In relation to Senator Martin's question, this practice includes requesting journalists who are passholders to escort their visitors. Unescorted passes are issued to identified visitors, selected staff required to attend urgently for emergency breakdowns et cetera, and tradesmen whose duties or visits preclude the feasibility or the necessity for an escort. In cases where unescorted passes are issued, the visitor is issued with an information slip which reads:

Bearers of unescorted passes are granted the privilege of being able to move through the lobbies and corridors of Parliament House without the need to be escorted. Holders of these passes are not entitled to call on Senators and Members in their rooms without prior appointment. Appointments may be arranged by telephone from the Senate or House of Representatives inquiry counters in Kings Hall.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator Ryan proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The failure of the Federal Government to develop employment opportunities for Aborigines.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by sessional order having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have submitted this matter for discussion today because it is a matter of public importance, I believe, to this Senate, to this Parliament and indeed to all Australia. I have done so in the hope that the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Peter Baume), on behalf of the Government, will respond positively and not attempt to defend the indefensible. I hope that the Minister will not spend a lot of time telling us what has been done but will direct his attention to what is not being done and give some positive undertakings on behalf of the Government. As everyone in this Senate will know, the disadvantages suffered by Aboriginal Australians are numerous and cover all areas of public policy and the law. Wherever one looks-housing, employment, education, health, transport, access to communication facilities-one finds serious, gross disadvantage for the Aboriginal people. However, I suggest to honourable senators that the underlying problem of Aboriginal disadvantage, as with all areas of disadvantage in our sort of society, is economic. Simply put, Aborigines are the poorest people in Australia. They fall into this category because the majority of them are without income other than inadequate and often erratically provided social security benefits. Aborigines by and large are unable to compete on the job market because they have no skills. This is the matter I wish to draw to the attention of the Senate today.

SPEECH.PARA: There are a number of matters to which I expect and hope that the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs will respond. First of all, if we look at the situation concerning education for Aboriginal people and in particular vocationally oriented education we find a picture which goes quite a long way in explaining why Aboriginals are so unable to compete on the job market. I quote from the report of the Committee of Inquiry into Education and Training, the Williams report of February 1979. It states:
The Census returns--
That is, for 1971-

indicated that 25 per cent of the Aboriginal population had never attended school, that 43 per cent had not proceeded beyond primary education (and only one-third of them had completed primary education) and that only 2 per cent had proceeded as far as Year 10 of secondary school or higher.

The Williams report also cited figures for Aboriginal enrolments in Technical and Further Education institutions in 1975. Only eight Aboriginals enrolled in diploma courses; only 63 enrolled in certificate courses; 88 enrolled in apprenticeship courses; and 428 enrolled in pre-employment courses. The report states that 3,310 Aborigines enrolled in what was described as other courses. The bulk of these enrolments would have been in adult education courses, not apprenticeship or certificate courses which could be expected to lead to employment.

Aboriginal people suffer a serious lack of employable qualifications compared with the white population. The data from the Department of Aboriginal Affairs concerning the qualifications of Aboriginal people as at the June 1976 census reveal that the number of Aboriginal people with diplomas or degrees was only 252 men and 231 women. There were 2,958 men and 1,069 women with technician or trade qualifications and another 393 persons with some form of vocational training. But of course the vast majority-over 83 per cent of Aboriginal people-have no qualifications at all. Education statistics to which it is very hard to get access-I will have something to say about the statistical problem later in my remarks-show an equally disadvantaged picture. Of those Aboriginal people for whom education statistics do exist, 9 per cent of the present school age population do not attend school; 13 per cent of the Aboriginal people over the age of 15 years have never attended school and overall Aboriginal children leave school earlier than their non-Aboriginal counterparts-75 per cent leave at or before the age of 15 years compared with 63 per cent of the total population, and only 2.5 per cent stay on to the age of 18 years compared with 6.3 per cent of the total population.

I present these statistics to the Senate this afternoon because I believe they are not commonly or widely recognised and their significance is not widely recognised. While we have this sort of gross disadvantage in respect of the access of Aboriginal children and adults to education and vocational education courses we will continue to have the very high rates of Aboriginal unemployment from which the Aboriginal community currently suffers.

There is a serious lack of trained personnel in the Aboriginal community. That lack exists particularly in the areas of greatest need. For example, I was very concerned to discover from an answer to a question I asked recently of the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, that of the 340 Aboriginals employed in Commonwealth funded Aboriginal health programs in the latest year for which figures were available, none were doctors, only 12 were nurses and 328 were employed in support roles mainly as Aboriginal health workers, aides or assistants. I would be very interested to hear the views of the Minister, himself a trained doctor, on the total absence of any Aboriginal doctors in Australia at a time when more and more information about the appalling health problems in Aboriginal communities is being brought to the fore.

In Alice Springs, the figure for registered Aboriginal unemployment as at July of last year was 1,199 or over 7 per cent of the total number of Aboriginals registered as unemployed throughout Australia. On a recent visit to Alice Springs, I was told that the number of vacancies registered with the Commonwealth Employment Service was not far behind the number of registered unemployed. That picture, of course, could be interpreted by some unsympathetic people to mean that Aboriginals were not genuinely seeking employment. However, that is not the explanation. The explanation is that Aboriginal unemployed do not have the skills for the jobs that are available; so the vacancies cannot be filled from this vast number of Aboriginal people. The Government will, no doubt wish to point out that the advertising campaign conducted by NAEDC, the National Aboriginal Employment Development Committee, which was designed to create some sympathy for Aboriginal employment in the private sector, is soon to come to Alice Springs. Of course, I welcome that intention. However, if Aboriginal skills are as badly mismatched with job vacancies in Alice Springs as I am informed, surely such a campaign will have only limited success and the real solution will be the training of Aboriginal people to do the jobs. There are a number of Aboriginal people in training at the moment. Currently the figures show that 2,391 Aboriginal people are in full time training. However, I suggest that this is not an adequate number to meet the needs of either the Aboriginal community or the available job vacancies.

When we look at the consequence, nationally, of these inadequate education and training schemes we find a picture of considerable disadvantage. Currently, over 17,000 Aboriginal people are registered as unemployed. The Department of Employment and Youth Affairs estimated that this represented an unemployment rate of 37 per cent of the estimated Aboriginal work force. This is an unemployment rate six times that in the general work force. In our society and in our sort of economy, we find it intolerable that we have unemployment in the general work force approximating 7 per cent from time to time. That is a national scandal and a national disgrace and it is acknowledged, I think, by all political parties to be the case. But when we look at Aboriginal unemployment, we find a rate six times that in the general work force. Yet we hear very little from the Government about this problem.

It must also be pointed out that these figures represent only those Aboriginals registered with the CES as unemployed and therefore underestimate the real level of Aboriginal people unemployed. They do not include, for example, those who do not have access to the CES. That would include many Aboriginals living in remote areas or Aboriginals who are not contacted by vocational officers of the CES. They do not include over 1,200 Aboriginal people who are paid at the level of unemployment benefit for working on community development programs under the Community Development Employment Project. The figures do not include Aboriginal people seeking part time work. Therefore, the CES figures reflect a minimum level of Aboriginal unemployment. When we look at Aboriginal youth unemployment we find, as with youth unemployment in the general community, a picture of considerable disadvantage. The most recent figures for Aboriginal unemployment in the 15 to 25 year age group show that 3,670 Aboriginals aged between 15 years and 19 years and 3,969 Aboriginals aged between 20 years and 25 years were unemployed. Forty-seven per cent of Aboriginals unemployed at that time were under 25 years of age.

In presenting these statistics to the Senate, I am aware that I am presenting a very fragmented and incomplete picture. I wish to make some comment on that. One of the main difficulties in assessing the real problems of Aboriginal employment is the lack of systematic statistics on the subject. The most significant inadequacy concerns the Department of Social Security. The Department of Social Security does not maintain regular statistics on the number of Aboriginals in receipt of unemployment benefit. Statistics are not kept on the number of Aboriginals employed under the Commonwealth Rebate for Apprentice Full-time Training Scheme. The Public Service Board does publish a statistical bulletin called 'The Employment of Aboriginals in the Australian Public Service' which is useful. However, statutory authorities are excluded from this bulletin and so the access of Aboriginals to employment in statutory authorities is very hard to establish. Similarly, in the area of education I am informed by the Minister in answer to questions on notice about Aboriginals in education that official statistics are not available since some education authorities do not maintain records based on race. It may have been regarded at some time in the past as racist to keep separate statistics on separate races or persons of separate ethnic origins. However, I reject that view very strongly. The usefulness of such statistics concerning education and employment of people according to race, if collected properly and regularly, must be apparent to all honourable senators. I urge the Minister to take steps to ensure the proper measurement of Aboriginal employment throughout the entire public sector.

Another difficulty relating to Aboriginals getting access to training and subsequently to employment is presented by the inadequate training allowances. Because of the disadvantaged situation concerning education and training, many Aboriginal people currently wishing to undertake work force training are mature age people. They are in the 20 to 30 age group and have families to support. Yet the highest amount a trainee student with a dependent spouse and two children could receive under current training schemes is $125 a week. This amount, of course, is totally inadequate, in many parts of Australia to maintain a reasonable standard of living. I ask the Minister to turn his attention to the need for positive discrimination or particularly helpful training allowances for Aboriginals with dependent families who need and wish to undertake training. While ever training opportunities are beyond the financial reach of the Aboriginal people, the employment situation will not improve.

The crux of my argument today is that the Government, as the largest employer in the country, ought to be providing more employment opportunities for Aboriginal people. If the Government were serious about Aboriginal unemployment, it could ensure that all of its departments and all statutory bodies initiated affirmative action for Aboriginal employment. The level of Aboriginal employment within the public sector has been declining. I could cite statistics to indicate that but I see that my time is running out. I also have available-I am sure the Minister also has this available to him-the number of Aboriginals who are currently employed in the public sector. The numbers are too low. As I said before, I hope the Minister will not defend the current situation.

If we pass on to statutory authorities which seem to me to present an ideal opportunity for affirmative action with regard to Aboriginal people, we find a very unbalanced picture. As I said, regular statistics are not available concerning the employment of Aboriginal people in statutory authorities. However, I inquired what the situation was from a number of our larger statutory authorities. Qantas Airways Ltd, with an approximate staff of 13,000 people, employed probably two Aboriginal flight stewards. There may be a couple of other people employed amongst the general staff. But there are two Aboriginal people employed by that huge statutory authority. Surely that is not a situation that the Minister will defend. Trans-Australia Airlines employs nine Aboriginal people; that is, 0.1 per cent of its work force. I inquired of Joint House Department about the number of Aboriginal people employed here in Parliament House where we again have a large and very visible public area of employment. It is, I suggest, a most appropriate area of employment for Aboriginal people in terms of positive discrimination and for presenting positive role models. No Aboriginal people are employed in Parliament House. So it goes on. I was unable to get statistics from the Australian Broadcasting Commission. The Australia Council employs one Aboriginal person. The Australian Postal Commission employs 0.2 per cent Aboriginal persons, and so it goes on.

I say to the Minister that the Government must adopt two main strategies if the economic disadvantage of Aboriginals is to be overcome by the creation of employment. The first strategy concerns the Government's role as trainer and provider of subsidies to the private sector to encourage it to adopt a training role. As I have pointed out, current training schemes are inadequate. What is needed is a nationally co-ordinated Aboriginal training program which will work within the public and private sectors and which will provide Aboriginal trainees with financial support at a realistic level.

The second strategy concerns the Government as employer. I put it to the Minister that the Government should require each Federal department and every statutory authority to set Aboriginal employment goals over a set timetable, and not a very long one-perhaps five years. The effect of putting a significant number of Aboriginal people into very visible employment areas, such as our national and international airlines, on ABC television and in Parliament House, would be significant.

In conclusion, I say that the Minister can make no plausible case that all is well with regard to Aboriginal training and employment. I hope he will not attempt to do so. In the spirit of constructive bipartisanship, which the Minister has invited me to take up, I ask these specific questions and hope that in the course of the Minister's response I shall receive some specific answers. Is he prepared to support the introduction into the Department of Social Security of a method of identifying Aboriginal recipients of pensions and benefits so that the true effect of social security programs on the unemployed Aboriginal persons can be known and assessed? Is he prepared to initiate a national Aboriginal employment and training council to co-ordinate and develop training and employment for Aboriginals throughout Australia? Is he prepared to support training allowances at a reasonable level for Aboriginal trainees with dependent families? Is he prepared to pursue with the Government the adoption of a clear, affirmative, action policy which will ensure the employment of a greatly increased number of Aboriginal people in all Commonwealth departments and all Commonwealth statutory authorities?

As I said at the outset, I recognise that the problems facing Aboriginal people in our society are manifold. I do not pretend that I have addressed all of them today. I have addressed only one problem-that of Aboriginal employment. But I would say that whereas a lot of the problems that Aboriginal people are facing-because they are of such long standing, because they involve such complex legal issues and because they involve such an accumulation of neglect and disadvantage-are very difficult to deal with, I have never said that the solutions were easy. But in the area of employment I think we have an area in which a Federal government of good will can act directly and effectively. As I have said, the Federal Government is the largest employer in this country. If it wishes to be an equal opportunity employer and an employer with affirmative action programs to bring Aboriginal people into the mainstream of economic life in this country, it can do so. I urge the Minister to treat this matter in the spirit of good faith in which I have raised it in the Senate and to tell the Senate what steps the Government, as an employer, is prepared to take with regard to Aboriginal employment in this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the debate which has been brought on by the Opposition. I welcome the suggestion by the Opposition spokesman that we should take a bipartisan approach. I too want to see the benefits of this debate and of the policies towards Aboriginal people flow to the Aboriginal people. I want to see outcomes in terms of employment and I am not seeking a moment's political advantage in approaching this debate now. Nevertheless I draw to the Senate's attention the fact that the subject we are discussing, which was put forward by Senator Ryan, is:

SPEECH.PARA: The failure of the Federal Government to develop employment opportunities for Aborigines.

With respect, that has not really been discussed at any length in the case that has been put to us. I would agree with many of the points raised. Aboriginal disadvantage is undoubted. The handicap under which Aboriginals labour is not questioned. But more is required than for the honourable senator or her colleagues to want to suggest that there has been a failure of the Federal Government to develop employment opportunities. They are her words-'the failure to develop employment opportunities'.

There is a story to tell and I would like to spend my time putting a balance to the view which the honourable senator has put. She has made a number of statements which are quite correct. It is undoubted that a large number of our corporations, our institutions and our own Parliament do not have a record of offering employment to Aboriginal Australians. I remind the Senate of the observation made by Professor Bernard Smith when delivering the Australian Broadcasting Commission Boyer lectures in 1980. He said:
Australia has an opportunity to develop a convergent culture with its sources in European traditions and the ancient land culture of the aboriginals.

That is a very good, desirable, goal statement by Professor Smith. But the development of that culture has not been, will not be and cannot be easy. Undoubtedly there will be areas of difficulty, areas of friction and areas of turbulence; and employment is one area. Employment-as we use the term in the non-Aboriginal sense-is an activity to provide cash resources. It is something which is quite new to many traditional Aboriginal people and Aboriginal communities. The Commonwealth Government has not failed to develop employment opportunities for Aboriginal people. Senator Ryan may argue that it has not developed these opportunities enough, not quickly enough, or at an appropriate level. But to say that these opportunities have not been developed is simply to ignore the facts as they exist.

The Government is only too well aware that levels of Aboriginal unemployment are six times those of the non-Aboriginal community. We are aware of that. We acknowledge the handicap. We understand the problems such as the historical and continuing lack of access to education and skills training which Senator Ryan has already mentioned.
