We understand and recognise the lack of economic development in areas of high Aboriginal unemployment. It is not easy to find jobs in a depressed country town which has no employment for anyone. I think of some towns in my own State. It is very difficult when there is no work in such places. We understand the problems of lack of motivation. We understand the sometimes adverse community attitudes and-not to put it too bluntly-the racist attitudes, all of which require action and will require long term solutions.

But, in tackling the Aboriginal unemployment problem, the Commonwealth Government has developed programs which have been aimed at the Aboriginal population which seeks access to normal labour markets, particularly the urban Aboriginals; also it has sought to address itself to those Aboriginals who choose to live in remote Aboriginal communities with no economic base to generate employment. Our programs have also sought to address themselves to non-Aboriginal Australians because the attitudes of non-Aboriginals will be critical in some areas in making the jobs available and making people appropriately willing to cope with their new employees.

There is a paradox. If we want to, we can concentrate on the efforts at job creation, on the number of people who have been placed, or we can concentrate on the unemployment registrations. I suggest that we should be looking at both sets of figures and not just at one set of figures. We cannot look at the job creation or job placement figures and ignore the unemployment figures. I will not try to. On the other hand, we cannot concentrate on the unemployment figures without recognising what has been done over the last few years.

If one is looking at the figures showing unemployment among Aboriginal Australians, it is worth while remembering that, of the 16,000 registered unemployed Aboriginals, 81 per cent of them are country registrations. Most of the time it is a problem of non-metropolitan unemployment. They are particular problems which are applicable, in some part, to non-Aboriginals as well. This is a particular problem of non-Aboriginal Australians. What is interesting and what is important is that the rate of rise of Aboriginal unemployment has been dropping steadily. In other words, the rate went up very rapidly between 1977 and 1978, and less rapidly the following year. The rise in Aboriginal unemployment between 1979 and 1980 was under 2 per cent. Although the unemployment is unacceptably high, it is beginning to drop.

TALK.START.PARA: —Recorded unemployment.

—I recognise the honourable senator's interjection and I acknowledge the point. We are talking about people who are registered for employment. I recognise that that may not completely identify Aboriginal unemployment. I put it to the honourable senator that, as we extend our capacity to move into communities and as we extend our capacity to bring social security benefits to those who are entitled to them, there may be an apparent rise in the number of unemployed. It may in fact represent the discovery of some hidden unemployed among the Aboriginal people. We have to be careful in interpreting that as a worsening of the situation. It may be in fact the first step in improving what is a bad situation.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to concentrate for a while on what Aboriginals have available to them, but before I do that I want to indicate that, State by State, Aboriginal unemployment-in doing this I am coming back to Senator Robertson's point-is highest in New South Wales, followed by Queensland and then Western Australia, with the number of registered unemployed in the Northern Territory being considerably less. The Aboriginal population is less in the Northern Territory, but the number of registrations suggest that possibly there are more Aboriginals in the Northern Territory who have not been discovered. I put it to honourable senators that we have to be careful about their discovery. That does not mean an increase in the number of unemployed. We have to look as well at the balance of what is being done to provide resources, facilities and opportunities.

At the moment, Aboriginals may avail themselves of the full range of services of the Commonwealth Employment Service, particularly in the more populated areas. Where particular employment assistance is sought, specialist employment officers-they are vocational officers-are available to counsel and support the Aboriginals seeking employment. We have to acknowledge that these vocational officers are useful and helpful. They are located in areas of significant Aboriginal population and they supplement services provided by the general Commonwealth Employment Service staff. That is the first thing the Commonwealth Government is doing.

The Commonwealth Employment Service is placing Aboriginals in jobs. This is part of the balancing of the grim picture painted by Senator Ryan. In the financial year 1978-79 almost 6,500 Aboriginals were placed in employment throughout Australia by the Commonwealth Employment Service. In the following year 7,472 Aboriginals were placed in employment. That is an increase of 16 per cent. Let us look at the present financial year. We can say that in the first six months of it almost 4,500 Aboriginals have been recorded as having been placed. Those figures are up considerably on those for the previous year. What we can see in this situation is that, through our normal services, we are able to place more and more Aboriginals in employment with each year that passes.

In 1978-79 over 12,500 Aboriginals were referred by the Commonwealth Employment Service to prospective employers. In the following year almost 14,000 Aboriginals were referred. I must say that the figure is probably higher than that because in two of the areas operated by the Commonwealth Employment Service no returns were available owing to industrial action. We know that at least 14,000 Aboriginals were referred by the CES.

There are a large number of government programs that are designed to alleviate unemployment among Aboriginals. There are training programs that are designed to try to help them to overcome some of the disabilities to which Senator Ryan has already referred. These are some of the affirmative policies which are being put into place. We have no difficulty in Senator Ryan's call for affirmative policies. We accept that proposition. The National Employment and Training system already provides training to enhance the long term employment prospects of individuals by giving them extra skills which will be helpful to them in the open labour market. In this financial year approximately 4,500 Aboriginals will receive training through the NEAT system.

Let us look at the national employment strategy for Aboriginals in the Australian Public Service. Over 650 positions in Commonwealth Government departments and authorities have been identified as requiring the ability to communicate with Aboriginals or some knowledge of Aboriginal culture. So far this amounts to 650 positions. We are looking to increase that number of positions. A pilot-scheme-the Clerk (Aboriginal Services) Scheme-has been commenced to promote the recruitment of Aboriginals into the Australian Public Service. Although there have been only a few recruitments to date, that program is already under way, working and in place.

The projects funded under the Community Development Employment Project scheme, which has been introduced in remote areas of Australia, employ some 1,300 Aboriginals in 18 remote communities. From some areas-notably the Torres Strait area-there is a call for those schemes to continue. The Torres Strait area actually wants them extended. The special works project scheme, which is funded through my Department, provides employment for Aboriginals in local government areas. Aboriginal organisations and some private employers can also take part in the scheme. Priority is given to employing Aboriginals who are ineligible for assistance under other employment or training programs. In this financial year the Government will be able to provide 415 man years of employment under this program alone.

The Department of Aboriginal Affairs' training programs are being extensively funded this year. About $5.5m has been set aside. Approximately 3,900 Aboriginals will receive some form of training through these grants. This training will include training in vocational skills, community management and welfare assistance. The National Aboriginal Employment Development Committee is at work and approximately 1,600 Aboriginals have been placed in employment in the areas covered by its promotion programs. It has been estimated that over 1,000 of these positions are extra positions which would not have been filled without the promotion programs that are run through this Committee. I am an employer of Aboriginals. I commend Senator Bonner, Senator Robertson and Senator Melzer, who will be speaking in this debate, for employing Aboriginals. I even commend employing Aboriginals to Senator Ryan.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do.

—That is excellent. I did not say that the honourable senator did not employ Aboriginals. My first trainee left about one month ago to take up a permanent position. A second trainee has now started work in the electorate office. I have an Aboriginal clerk working in my office and one of the Aboriginal assistant research officers who was with me several months ago has now been promoted to a class 5 position in the Third Division of the Public Service. I hope that he is just one of very many who will be following that course. A large number of people do not just talk about employing Aboriginals but are involved in doing what they can. In my own Department 322 positions at various levels have been identified as being positions which could be filled by aboriginals. This figure is about 32 per cent of the Department's establishment. This is the largest number of identified positions of any department within the Australian Public Service. We make sure that the job vacancies for these positions are advertised in the Press through a weekly circular to all Aboriginal organisations to make sure that they know the jobs are there. We have a list of interested persons among all Aboriginal tertiary students. We modify our selection procedures to include a recognition of special Aboriginal abilities as a significant selection criterion, to try to make it easier for Aboriginal applicants, and more likely that they will be successful in applying for these kinds of positions.

SPEECH.PARA: As at 1 October 1978 about 1,180 Aboriginals were employed in the Commonwealth Public Service. A year later there were 566 but what had happened in the meantime was that a number of Aboriginals who had appeared to be employed in the Public Service were still employed, but the authorities under which they were funded had moved out. Senator Bonner will take up this matter later. He will talk about the Aboriginal Development Commission and about the grants-in-aid programs. He will also talk about some of the other bodies with which Aboriginal employment can be seen. The figures I gave to honourable senators actually represented a slight increase of some 13 people for the period after allowances had been made for transfers. During the period 1976-80 while the non-Aboriginal numbers had decreased from 820 to 550, the number of Aboriginals employed had almost doubled, from 109 to almost 180. The number of Aboriginal people employed in the Department of Aboriginal Affairs is now about 132. This figure covers people at all levels of the Service from Special Adviser, Level 4 in the Second Division, down to clerical assistants and steno-secretaries.

I have not gone through some of the other programs at any length. I have not talked at any length about the National Employment Strategy for Aboriginals scheme, nor have I spoken at any length really about the CDEPs or some of the other training schemes. My Department has allocated this year some $3.5m for specific training programs. We have allocated $234,000 to develop new steps in training with emphasis on self-management. We have provided support to Darwin and Alice Springs community colleges to establish courses to provide Aboriginals with skills necessary for community management and self-sufficiency. The Aboriginal resident community worker training program is also under way. Approximately 9,000 Aboriginals are expected to be assisted in some fashion by government employment and training programs this financial year.

Mr Charles Perkins was the first Aboriginal university graduate. He finished his university training only in the mid-1960s. He is now at a very senior level of public administration in this country. He is the first of a stream of Aboriginal university graduates. He is the first of a stream of graduates who are coming out of the colleges of advanced education. If honourable senators look at the undergraduate schools they will see that Aboriginals are there, not in the numbers that I or Senator Ryan or any other participant in this debate would want, but they are there. Aboriginals are now taking part in technical training. There are now thousands more high school graduates than there have been in the past. There are many more job holders. We are getting somewhere, we are making progress. There are programs in place and the fact that there is a lot more to be done is simply a reason for us to try harder. There is no way that the Opposition can assert, as it would seek to do in raising this matter of public importance, that there has been a failure on the part of the Federal Government to develop employment opportunities for Aboriginals.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Robertson Sen E.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the matter of public importance so capably raised by my colleague Senator Ryan. Before I enter into my prepared material, I must make a couple of comments on what was said by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Sentor Peter Baume). The Minister claimed that Senator Ryan had not addressed herself to the topic. The topic, as I understand it, is:

SPEECH.PARA: The failure of the Federal Government to develop employment opportunities for Aborigines.

I am a simple soul. I would have thought that that meant basically the failure to get Aboriginals into employment. I think the man in the street would accept that sort of proposition. If the Minister has developed programs, if the Government has done these things, then the man in the street is quite entitled to ask: How effective are they? Of course the percentage of Aborigines employed would have to be the criterion and the percentage unemployed would have to be a factor. The Minister also said that he recognised the problem, and I do not doubt that at all. He is a very astute person. He has taken a keen interest in the Aboriginal situation over the years. I am encouraged by this because a philosopher tells us that if we recognise the problem we are half way towards a solution. All we want to see now from the Minister is the solution. The Minister mentioned training. I have some comments to make on this aspect, but first let me repeat what I have so often said in this place, that training is not the key, that the creation of job or employment opportunities is the key.

I will direct my attention to the situation in the Northern Territory, though I think the comments I will make will apply fairly generally. The Minister has indicated that unemployment in Aboriginal communities in the Northern Territory is high. The recorded figure is high and the unrecorded figure is even higher. It is high also in the urban areas of the Northern Territory. Both of these situations are to be deplored because something can be done about both and unemployment need not be so high. I will spend just a couple of minutes speaking very briefly on the effects of unemployment on the individual and on the community, but in particular on the youth because that is where the problem is the greatest.

Studies have been carried out by the Young Men's Christian Association and others of non-Aboriginal people in urban areas, but similar studies have not been done for Aboriginal people, although social workers, teachers, Aboriginal elders and others have all commented on the problem. The effect of unemployment and virtually no prospect of employment is a debilitating and damaging one on the young people of the Northern Territory. We see at an early age-at the age of 12 or 13-the young boy or girl, and particularly the boy, losing interest in school. The boy feels that the teachers have let him down because they have said to him: 'If you work hard, if you do well at school, you will get a good job when you leave'. Of course there are no jobs, so he becomes disillusioned with teachers. He becomes disillusioned with whites because most of the teachers are white. He becomes disillusioned with authority and he becomes anti-social. At a later age the same sort of anti-social behaviour comes forward as anti-authority. The sad thing, of course, is that it is not only anti-authority towards white people; it is also anti-authority towards his own Aboriginal people.

There is an old adage that the devil finds work for idle hands. Unfortunately, this is the situation that we see in communities in the Northern Territory. There is juvenile delinquency out of sheer boredom. There is juvenile drinking and petrol sniffing out of sheer boredom. There are crimes of break and enter to get grog because they do not have any money to buy grog. The situation for the older people is almost as bad. There is an abdication of responsibility for their families. The man with a wife and several children will say: 'I have no money. It is your fault I have no money. You look after my wife and kids'. He then goes on the grog. The breakdown of the old men's authority leads to a disintegration of the community. There is no doubt that the extension of the outstation movement has many causes. Some of these are: The need to get away from the grog, that is, where the central community is not dry; the need to keep the group or the clan integrated on traditional authority; the need to find meaningful employment for all the young people; and, of course, the desire to occupy traditional homeland centres. There are many other causes but the two key ones are related to the topic we are discussing at present-the need to find meaningful employment for young people to keep them out of trouble and the need to keep them away from this rejection of any sort of authority, particularly the authority of the old men.

Why is Aboriginal unemployment in the communities of the Northern Territory so high? I suggest that there are three basic reasons and I will deal with them. First, there are the limited employment opportunities; second, there is the fact of people being not trained to fill the vacancies; and third, there is the fact that finance is not available to employ those who want to work. We have always heard the cry in this area of limited employment opportunities that the location of the Aboriginal communities does not lend itself to industry. This is the usual answer. We talk about inhospitable country and the fact that there are no resources there and no opportunities to develop anything. But studies that have been carried out have shown quite clearly that almost all adults-by adults I mean those 16 years and older-could be employed in the communities with the right sort of organisation. Let us just take one simple case of all those services that are required by the community. There is the need for shop attendants, mechanics, projectionists, teachers, drivers and gardeners. All these avenues really have not been explored. The studies are available.

I commend, as the Minister has done-I give him and his predecessors full credit for this-the introduction of the Community Development Employment Project. It was a proposition I spoke about when I first became a senator and it is one which I have always supported. Of course, we must see an extension of this proposition. We cannot hold up one or two communities or a small percentage and say: 'This is the answer'. If it is the answer, let us use it everywhere else. There is little real evidence of attempts to create employment opportunities. As I indicated in my introductory remarks, I see the creation of employment opportunities as the key. We need to study the area to find out what can be done, then create opportunities for employment and train the people to do the jobs that have been created. I will come back to that matter in a moment when I talk about training.

The third matter that I want to mention is that there has been little attempt to provide guidance and assistance for individual projects. I refer to the CDEP as well as many other individual and group projects. People have not been trained to fill the vacancies when they occur. So when we need to have houses built on settlements, to use the old phrase, the carpenter, the bricklayer and the plumber are not available. When we want to put sewerage in some of the areas the only jobs that we can offer the people are the ditch digging jobs. We do not have the plumbers there to do the job.

I must say that the two areas where training has been better than in others are nursing and teaching. In nursing, unfortunately, training is taken only up to the aide level but teachers are trained up to the full level because of the work of my senior colleague, Senator Cavanagh, and many others from 1972 to 1975 when we had that wonderful concept of Aboriginality as a qualification and a desire to see Aboriginal people moving into all the jobs. I remember quite clearly the times that I have spent in the Territory trying to make the point that every job in the Education Department, which was my area, would eventually be filled by Aboriginal people. We want to see that happening but despite the comments that have been made by Senator Baume, we do not see it happening and we do not see any great indication that it will happen in the near future, but rather in the quite distant future. Aboriginal people have become full members of the Commonwealth Teaching Service. There are problems, of course, as I raised with the Minister last week. Again, because of lack of finance from the Government, we are not able to seek replacements, so the training is not going ahead as fast as it should.

In the main, little training has been done, but not because it has not been attempted. There is no doubt that the Ministers' advisers could tell them of 20 years or more of real attempts at training, but the training has not been appropriate and it has not been effective. It has not been appropriate because it has not been related. The Government cannot say that over the years it has not been told what ought to be done. Many people have told it that the Aboriginal people who are brought to Darwin to do bricklaying do not relate this to bricklaying at Hooker Creek. If they do plumbing at Alice Springs, in some strange way it is not the same as doing plumbing at Areyonga. This has been said many times.

I refer to the report of the Stephen committee. It set very clear guidelines on what ought to be done. I will sum up very quickly the recommendations it put forward. Firstly, it said that any training undertaken should be on-site training and that any essential training should be done by visiting trainers, supported by the local tradesmen and the local school teachers. It recommended that all work should be designed on modular programming so that it could be done a bit at a time, and that the certification should be cumulative so that as each module was completed an indication could be registered on the certificate that that module had been completed. Each module would be capable of being sold in the market-place, that being either the town situation or the rural situation. Numerous interdepartmental committees have talked about this for years. I talked to my old colleague Martin Ford, who has been commissioned to do a study yet again. He has just completed that study. I do not know what will happen to it. He does not know either. I wonder whether that study will give us any more information on what ought to happen.

Again I make the point strongly that training-just training-is still not appropriate. We need to have job creation first and then appropriate training. As Senator Baume has said, we do have Mr Perkins in the Department of Aboriginal Affairs, and other Aboriginals are filling positions throughout the Public Service and in the Northern Territory. I do not deny that in other areas also-such as mechanics, nursing, teaching and others-we have had some outstanding successes but there is no doubt that the vast bulk of the people are missing out on getting a job in their community or in the town because they are not qualified.

The fourth area of government inactivity at which I wish to look is the lack of available finance. Last week I asked the Minister: Why do we have inadequate municipal services? Quite obviously the answer is that there is not any money to pay for them. The answer that came from the Minister was: The Northern Territory Government has not made the finance available. I am afraid, with due respect, that we cannot pass the buck that easily. The Minister has the responsibility to see that money is provided-he was given that responsibility in 1967-and then, having seen that it is provided, to see that it is properly spent. What is the situation of the Aboriginal people in urban areas? Aboriginal people are not qualified to fill the jobs that are available. In many cases they are not prepared for living in urban areas. As the Minister stated, the attitude of employers in some cases is racist in the extreme. Others are not prepared to make the sorts of special allowances that are necessary to cope with the working habits of the Aboriginal people.

What has the Government done? Firstly, it claims that it has set up an example in employing apprentices and others. I accept that. All I ask the Minister to do is to give the Senate some indication of the number of people in apprenticeships and the number of people in employment at present. He has given us some of those figures. I would like to relate those to the number who are unemployed. I suggest strongly that the Government has not provided appropriate training along the lines that the Stephen committee and other committees have recommended. It has not prepared employers sufficiently to take Aboriginal people into their employment. Let me say that some individual Commonwealth Employment Service officers have done outstanding work. I commend them for it, but sufficient work has not been done. Again I ask the Minister to give us the figures for unemployment among Aboriginal people and non-Aboriginal people and let us see who is disadvantaged.

What is the solution? Quite clearly, the solution is firstly to create employment opportunities, preferably by Aboriginal-run enterprises-with assistance, of course, rather than the dumping of money onto people and telling them to do the job. Many industries are favoured by the Aboriginal people. I refer to the pastoral project at Willowra and many others. The Minister knows of these. We should provide appropriate training for Aboriginal people along the lines that I have suggested. It should be done at the Aboriginal community by visiting trainers, supported by the local tradesmen, the local school teachers and then, through modular programs, cumulative certificates should be given. We should make sure, of course, that this work is tied in with schooling. I use the word schooling rather than education because it is broader. Training of any sort, to be effective, must be tied in with what goes on in a school. I would suggest that education is attitude development. We need to do a lot of that. Children will not work at school if there is no job for them when they finish. They have been fooled too often. I cannot make the point too often that job creation is the vital aspect.

In conclusion, let me simply say that I believe the Opposition has shown that Aboriginal people are disadvantaged. We have shown the solution is quite clearly in the hands of the Federal Government and the State or Territory governments. We have demonstrated that the Federal Minister has responsibility and we can claim that the present Minister and his predecessors have let the Aboriginal people down. The way is open to correct this situation. I suggest that in what we have said today the Minister and his advisers have been given some additional thoughts on how this might be done.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collard Sen S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As has been indicated we are discussing a matter of public importance, namely: 'The failure of the Federal Government to develop employment opportunities for Aborigines'. I say at the outset that I wish the situation were so simple that it could just be defined as: 'The failure of the Federal Government to develop employment opportunities . . .' That there is a problem is not denied. It is accepted by both sides of this chamber and I think by every serious thinking person within the community. I think the situation has resulted from more than just a lack of employment opportunities.

SPEECH.PARA: We are dealing with a people who for about 200 years have been seeking to make their way in a society that has been 2,000 years or more in the making. I guess that they are suffering from culture shock, future shock or whatever we might like to call it. They are a people who have lived and survived in probably one of the harshest environments on earth. Their living and surviving have not despoiled or fouled the environment. They have lived in and, I suppose I might say harvested, or at least found a way to come to grips with, the environment without harming it. They have not had the benefit of the technology that we have. Of course, we must recognise that we could not survive in this country as they have for 2,000 years. During that time they have developed traditions and a culture. We are still doing that in our new land.

As I said at the beginning of my remarks, for Aborigines to make their way in our society we must provide them with more than employment opportunities. We must look at their difficulties with sympathy and compassion, while at the same time trying to provide employment for them. In the last few years many people, unfortunately with more zeal and sympathy than knowledge and common sense, have advocated advancements that have not had the desired effect. I will give two examples: Firstly there was the court decision that required Aboriginal stockmen on station properties to be paid full award wages. It was an unfortunate decision at that time, although one must agree that it was inevitable; it had to happen. At that time an arrangement existed on the station properties which may be called paternalism, but it worked. The stockmen were employed on properties and they were kept by the property owners. They worked and had pride in their jobs. Those who were good at their jobs were automatically promoted. They might have run mustering camps on their own-without the station foreman.

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't you believe in award wages for Aboriginal workers?
—If the honourable senator was listening, she would have heard me say that the change was inevitable; it had to happen. I am just talking about--
—You sounded as though you regretted it.

—I regret the results. I regret what has happened. I lived through it. I was not in this area; I was in the north-west of Queensland when the changes occurred and saw what happened when station property owners could no longer afford to pay the full award wage to large numbers of Aboriginals. I saw them become fringe dwellers on the outskirts of country towns without the pride that they had when they had good employment. People who sought to do good for the Aboriginals have not yet come to grips with the tremendous problems created and which still remain. As I said, it was inevitable but I think the change could have been handled better and brought in a lot more smoothly so that we would not have seen the degradation of these fine people.

SPEECH.PARA: In one fell swoop we decided to give Aboriginals equality. They had the right to consume alcohol. On the face of it, who can argue with that, if we see it as one of the attributes of a white society. Of course, alcohol has had a tremendous and far-reaching effect on Aboriginals. We have almost literally written off a generation of Aboriginals because of alcohol. It has been very damaging to these people. It is quite interesting to note-Senator Robertson with his knowledge of the Northern Territory touched on the matter-that where the clan structure is still intact and where there is clan discipline, the elders are doing their best to steer the young people away from all the problems that the consumption of alcohol involves. Some Aboriginal communities are dry. In some areas when the canteen is open, Aboriginals are allowed to buy alcohol-that is, mainly beer and no spirits-only in a jug. In other words, they have to drink it there. They cannot take cans or stubbies away with them. It is quite ironic that the elders are trying to come to grips with a situation that we in our paternalism thought would provide them with equality.

However, the story is not all bad. There are many Aboriginals in all types of employment. They are holding down good and permanent jobs. Indeed, two bright parts of my life this year have involved Aboriginal families who have been very close to my family. In one instance, the father phoned me and asked me whether I would like to go to the Edinburgh Air Force Base because his son was taking part in a passing out parade. When I arrived, I found that not only had he completed his basic training but also he had come first in his course. I thought that was tremendous. Also, on Monday of this week an official in the Queensland railways phoned me. We were both engine drivers and spent many hours together in the railways. He thought I would like to know that my friend had just passed his locomotive inspectors examination. That is no mean achievement and I thought it was marvellous. I rang him and he was rightfully proud because he had done so well. I give just two examples that have happened this year and which prove that the Aboriginal story is not all bad, that they can hold good and permanent jobs and take their rightful place in society.

Nonetheless, as this matter of public importance indicates, there is a problem and it is recognised by all honourable senators. Of course, the Federal Government is aware of it and has developed programs aimed at both the Aboriginal population, which is seeking access to the normal labour market-normal employment-and also at that other section, the Aboriginals who choose to live in remote Aboriginal communities with no economic base to generate their support. Investigations by the National Aboriginal Employment Development Committee in 1978 found the following causal factors: Absence of economic development in areas of high Aboriginal population, lack of education and skills and depressed rural industries. The latter finding was one of the contributing factors involved at the time of the granting of award wages to Aboriginals. The wool industry was on the decline and since then we have seen the massive problems in the beef industry, the lack of motivation and the resultant adverse community attitude.

I suppose one of the first aspects that we have to look at is education. We realise that massive problems exist there. The Government has put money into education. I think in 1980-81 $13.2m was directed towards Aboriginal education. There are 68 direct grant projects for 3,000 students, plus employment for 480 Aboriginals working as literary officers, teacher aids and traditional teaching and liaison officers. It is expected that about 2,800 Aboriginals will receive direct training under grants for training and that 4,500 will be trained under programs supported by grants to the States. It is interesting to look at the increase in the numbers of Aboriginals involved in basic education. In 1979 there were 499 participants in receipt of Aboriginal study grants, and in 1980 there were 7,202. In 1971, 4,025 Aboriginals received secondary grants. In 1979, 16,189 Aboriginals received such grants. Quite often, more of these grants are available to Aboriginal children than to white children who are in similar conditions, particularly in the rurally depressed areas surrounding some of our country towns.

In tackling the Aboriginal unemployment problem, the Commonwealth Government has developed programs aimed at both the Aboriginal population which seeks access to the normal market and those who live in Aboriginal communities. We can only spend money wisely; we cannot throw money away as though it will solve all of our problems. We must have the adequate resources and people who can work in these communities. I suppose that we would like to spend more money in this area but we would also like to spend more money on lots of other things. I think what is more important is that the money that has been allocated is well spent. I will go through some of the schemes that were outlined by the Minister.

The National Employment Strategy for Aboriginals is one scheme which is known pretty well to many of our members. As has been indicated, members are employing Aboriginals under that scheme. In my own town of Rockhampton, the Australian Broadcasting Commission employs two young ladies under that scheme. One is doing general announcing duties both on television and on radio and has progressed to interviews as well. She is doing a very good job. The ABC is quite proud of these young ladies. NESA, as it is called, is an intensive effort to create training and employment opportunities for Aboriginals in the public sector. Of course, this scheme has been complemented by a concentrated and a geographically spread campaign to create employment opportunities for Aboriginals in the private sector as well. Together with that there is the National Employment and Training system. Many people are trained under this system. I believe that, in December 1980, 986 Aboriginals were receiving training under the NEAT system in Commonwealth, State or the Northern Territory Public Service departments or agencies. In the Commonwealth Public Service alone, between August 1978 and August 1980, 563 NEAT trainees had completed their training and 302 had gained employment.

As I mentioned, the National Aboriginal Employment Development Committee is seeking to stimulate employment amongst private industry. I believe it has done so with some success. Its operations extend to many areas, including north Queensland, Dubbo and Spencer's Gulf, to name a few. Its activities begin with media campaigns which help to stimulate community awareness of the employment problems facing Aboriginals and then there is direct contact between employers and the Department of Employment and Youth Affairs officers. As has been mentioned, the Department does a tremendous job. Its officers are people with great capacity, compassion and sympathy, and they go and talk to these people. Of course, there are discussions on employment issues with the local Aboriginal organisations and their communities. Through this program, approximately 1,600 Aboriginals have been placed in employment in these areas.

The Special Work Projects provide subsidies to local governments, to Aboriginal organisations and to private employers so that they also can employ Aboriginals. The Community Development Employment Projects are aimed at community projects which do not have a viable base on which to operate. The grants are basically similar to the unemployment benefit. A further subsidy is provided to meet overhead costs. The Aboriginals then are employed on a part-time basis. In 1980-81, 18 communities operated under the CDEP scheme, which employs approximately 1,300 Aboriginals.

In my own State, the Queensland Government is conscious of its responsibilities and it employs Aboriginals in all government departments. I mentioned a friend of mine who works in the railways. Indeed, I worked in the railways with many Aboriginal people who were guards, engine drivers or fettlers. Others were driving graders for local councils. They are making their way and they are employed. Our Queensland Government encourages communities to go into industries which are based on handicrafts, tourism and also primary industry. The Torres Strait community is encouraged to enter the prawning, pearling and fishing industries. As I indicated earlier, there are problems-we all recognise them. The problems will not be overcome tomorrow. It is one of those unfortunate facts of life in the situation in which we find ourselves, but I think that, while there is sympathy, compassion and a will within the community and within the Government, we can do much to alleviate these problems.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Melzer Sen J.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —I speak in this debate in order to put a point of view about the Aboriginal people in Victoria. When I saw the speakers list, I found that two of my old comrades in arms, Senator Bonner and Senator Peter Baume, also were to join in the debate. We three were part of a Senate committee which produced a long and comprehensive report about the conditions of Aboriginal people in Australia. Seeing their names, I hoped that I would be preaching to the converted; but, of course, I had to realise that my two colleagues would not be making all of the decisions in regard to Aboriginal people in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: I must say at the outset that I resent the patronising tone which is used so often in this chamber when speaking about Aboriginal people. They are not people who desperately need love, understanding and kindness: They are real people who need real jobs and the ability to lead their own lives. I am not talking about the outback Aborigine-some vague mythical figure which seems to appear in debates here so often-but about Aboriginal people who have been born and have grown up in large cities and in large country towns, about people who have proved that they do not need great paternalistic help, and about people who do not have to be called 'these people'. They are Australian adults who, given a chance, have proved that they have the ability to learn, to work, to hold jobs, to drink alcohol in moderation or not at all and to keep their families together if the community and the Government would give them half a chance to get out on their own and to get started.

There is a very high level of unemployment in the Australian community. Everybody-even the Government-admits that we have an extraordinary high level of unemployment for a country with such a wealth of resources. We have a country at this time in which a university degree, six years of high school, years of experience in the work force, proven managerial ability or first class tradesmanship will not necessarily get a person a job. So, what hope have we for people who have never had a job, apart from a month or two of fruit picking, who have left school at the age of 13 years, who have no training and who have never had an income that really copes with the expenses of a family, who have lived in second rate accommodation in crowded conditions, who have been expected not to use their initiative but to do as officialdom tells them.

Many Aboriginal people in Australia today and many of the Aboriginal people in Victoria have lived in those conditions all their lives and, given some government assistance to get them out of that hole, could live as proper human beings. Many Aboriginal people in Victoria, when they found that the cities-the ordinary work places-would not provide jobs for them, tried hard to move out to the land and set up for themselves. They tried to set up fruit blocks, garages and farms in the country, but they failed not because they did not have the ability, not because they did not have the desire to succeed or the will to go on but because, in a pure commercial sense, they did not have the capital necessary to keep those sorts of enterprises going. The Government would not provide the capital necessary to get those enterprises off the ground and so many of those people sank back in despair.

If the employment scene is bad for white males and for Aboriginal males in Australia, for Aboriginal women and girls it is very much worse. Forty-three per cent of Australian women over the age of 15 years are employed, but they are in a very restricted area as far as wages are concerned. Seventeen per cent of full-time male employees earn less than $150 a week, but 38 per cent of full-time working females are in that low income bracket, and Aboriginal women are at the bottom of that pile. If it is bad for white women, it is even worse for Aboriginal women because they are regarded in the community, without a great deal of evidence, as being bad workers, alcoholics and people with no ability. They really are at the bottom of the pile. Youngsters growing up in our community today are hard hit by unemployment. The rate of unemployment amongst young girls in parts of this country, and certainly in parts of Victoria, is well over 20 per cent. Well qualified, bright youngsters may find it impossible to get jobs. If that can happen to white youngsters, how much harder is it for Aboriginal youngsters who are not regarded highly in areas where employment is available?

For young Aboriginal girls it is becoming almost impossible. They have, first of all, to overcome the prejudice in the community. They have to put up with the extraordinary level of unemployment within the community and then there are the youngsters who drifted out of school at the age of 13 years because they did not think that they had any future. The children live with despairing parents who may never have worked in their lives. They see the dole as the only income possible to them. They drift into alcoholism because there has to be something to kill the pain. Aboriginal people who have grown up in closely settled areas of Victoria-not remote areas-have worked for only two months of the year, that is, when fruit picking work is available. Aboriginal unemployment falls below about 80 per cent in some of those areas only when fruit picking work is available.

Figures given to me by the Department of Employment and Youth Affairs and by Aboriginal people in Victoria indicate that there are only 288 people in real training in that State. At present about 50 Aboriginal people are apprentices and about 200 Aboriginal people are coming out of high schools. About eight Aboriginal people are in Victorian universities and 30 of them are participating in the national Aboriginal training scheme. We have a minimum of 14 per cent unemployment amongst Aboriginals in Victoria. I use the word 'about' because nobody in Victoria is willing to give firm figures. As has been said in this debate by Senator Ryan, no statistics are kept on Aboriginal conditions in this country despite the fact that the Senate report to which I referred earlier recommended strongly in 1976 that statistics be kept so that we would have some idea of the extent of the problems existing amongst Aboriginal people. Five years later we are still using the word 'about'. We do not even now how many people in Australia claim Aboriginality.

We know that only 21 per cent of the full time workers amongst the white community in Australia have trade qualifications and that only 2 per cent of the working females have trade qualifications. I know that in Victoria at the moment there are 50 apprentices from the Aboriginal community. The figure for the Aboriginal people who will go on under those schemes to achieve some sort of standing as tradesmen-people who are really needed in their community-is very low. The employment figures for Victoria raise grave doubts because of the strong move over the last few years to push Aboriginal people out of the unemployment benefit area and into the invalid pension and special benefits area. On the surface this is not hard to do because misery, loneliness and despair have pushed many Aboriginals into alcoholism and they are easily seen as invalids. The feeling of personal unworthiness which pervades the Aboriginal community can push the Aboriginal people into a deep depression in which they can be seen as invalids, but in point of fact these people are not invalids; they are people who are looking for work. Work would cure so many of their problems. There are training programs, but the real problem lies in what happens when a training program is finished. We know that there is a problem in getting people into training programs in the first place. We know that there is a problem in finding places for them to live while they train. That is not easy in Victoria, so I daresay that in places such as the Northern Territory and Queensland it is much worse. Where do these people go when they are trained? I will quote from a letter written by Mrs Nessie Skuta, the National Aboriginal Conference member for Victoria, which deals with precisely this problem. The letter states:

When the NESA Policy was introduced it was my understanding that part of that Policy required all Government Departments to investigate and identify positions in which it would be desirable to employ Aboriginal People. I know that this Policy has been carried out in some Departments and positions have been identified. For instance I am told that some 13 counter Officer positions have been identified by the Department of Social Security in Victoria. However it appears to me that this Policy has not been followed through in the Department of Employment and Youth Affairs.

I am aware that your Department has a number of Vocational Officer and Assistant Vocational Officer positions in which Aboriginals are employed, but each of these Officers has to cover a number of CES offices. These are many CES offices, especially in the country areas, which have a significant and continuous flow of Aboriginal clients. It is my belief there should be an Aboriginal person permanently situation in Offices which have Aboriginal clients.

For the past 12 months, Miss Glenda Mongta has been employed in the Bairnsdale CES as a NES trainee. I was amazed and distressed today when Miss Mongta told me that she was not going to be employed in the CES when her training period ends in a couple of weeks time.

This is just a little evidence of what so many of us are afraid of. So many of these training programs are just camouflage schemes to get the Aboriginal people off the unemployed list and make it look as though the Government is really doing something about employment. Giving training is one thing, but if there is no job at the end of it the training is useless and the despair that follows is very heartbreaking. There are other areas at which the Government could look. Aboriginal health in Victoria is not good. With a minimum of funds, the Aboriginal health organisation in Victoria does more for the health of the Aboriginal community there than the State itself does with four times the funds. With more understanding and funding in that area, not only would Aboriginal health be better but also more Aboriginal people would be trained and earning a living. Aboriginal people say over and over that as soon as jobs are advertised for Aboriginal institutions and organisations in Victoria there is an overwhelming number of applications for these jobs because Aboriginal people love to work with Aboriginals. For once they have some dignity, they are accepted as equals and they have a job to do.

The Aboriginal legal service in Victoria provided a pattern for the Australian legal service to follow. We would love to say that such a service is no longer necessary in Victoria, but it is very necessary. The housing of Aboriginal people in Victoria is abysmal because responsibility for that has been handed over to the State housing authority. If the money for Aboriginal housing were given to the Aboriginal people there it would be found that with understanding and tolerance the overcrowding, lack of maintenance and lack of houses would be overcome by the people who understand the problem and who have the ability to look after that area. It might even be found that there are people with imagination who can use that need for housing and maintenance to train young Aboriginal people as carpenters, builders and building workers of all types. Certainly, that sort of imagination is not being used by Federal and State authorities in that area. I will close with a quote I have used every year since 1976 when the Committee brought down its report. The report states:

. . . we still must express our conviction that if we are ever able to make atonement to the remnant of this people, it will require no slight attention, and no ordinary sacrifices on our part to compensate the evil association which we have inflicted; but even hopelessness of making reparation for what is past would not in any way lessen our obligation to stop, as far as in us lies, the continuance of iniquity.

That came from a House of Commons select committee on Aborigines in 1837. It was quoted in our report in 1976; I have quoted it ever since. We have governments and people in government who insist on treating Aboriginals as idiot children, giving them no chance to control their own future, no control of funds, no chance to make their own mistakes and no chance for a future. I hope that my two colleagues who helped to write that report feel as I do: We have waited long enough and it is time for Aboriginal people to be treated as Australians.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Knowing that a matter of public importance was to be dealt with today I was struck especially by that section of the prayer which precedes our deliberations in the Senate every day and which mentions our prime responsibility as parliamentarians to advance the welfare of the people of Australia; not solely the welfare of the white people of Australia. This, of course, begs the question: Does this Government really carry out its duty towards the public welfare of black Australians? Basically, this is the issue we are discussing. I have risen to speak in this debate because the welfare of Aborigines is a basic concern of the Australian Democrats. We believe that the Australian nation, of which the Government is or ought to be the leader of opinion and action, has failed to solve the Aboriginal problem and shows very little prospect of mending its ways. There seems to be no real light at the end of the tunnel. Judging from what the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Peter Baume) said earlier, there is only a feeling of complacency, that somehow enough is being done and the problems are being engaged.

SPEECH.PARA: The subject of this matter of public importance is the need to develop employment opportunities for Aboriginals. It is possibly the most important and significant part of the overall problem because equality of opportunity in the work place tends to be the basic test of equality between communities; and that is especially the case in this country now with growing and stubborn unemployment. I commend the current television advertisements which are seeking to alleviate the problem of Aboriginal unemployment. They contain the slogan: 'The right to a job is as important as the right to live'. I have sat through various annual functions, such as National Aborigines Week, listening to some speakers defining problems and to others giving reasons for those problems not being solved. By now I am heartily sick and tired of the lack of progress we have made. I must say that the speech by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs here today struck me as very much another one of those speeches giving reasons why the real problems are not being solved. To be honest, I found his speech disappointing.

What is the nature of the unemployment problem? It is plain enough and bad enough. I do not think it has actually been stated squarely yet, but I shall do so. More than 160,000 Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders are in Australia. Of those some 37,000 are actually estimated to be in the work force. They are suffering the highest rate of unemployment of any identifiable group in the community. This has been placed by some people at 37 per cent and by some at 40 per cent. It is said to be perhaps as high as 50 per cent which is, of course, so many times higher than for the rest of the community as to be, I would have thought, a cause for alarm and not a cause for complacency in any way.

What about the future? According to a bulletin of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs issued late in 1979, based on present birth rates our Aboriginal population is likely to double over the next three decades. Then there will be about 320,000 people, many of them young people, who will face especially difficult problems of employment unless something is done in the meantime. There will be a much higher proportion of young Aboriginal people unemployed than the proportion in the total community. We have a responsibility, I suggest, to that group. Such major solutions to the problem of Aboriginal employment as we have at present seem to us to be crude palliatives. They are mostly a matter of money subsidies of one kind or another to Aborigines. Others are seen as protected patronage-certain types of jobs and training. This, I believe, in no way solves the real problems. Indeed, it creates a new and growing one of division within the society. Many Australians of non-Aboriginal origins, especially those who may be poor or disadvantaged themselves-as we all know, there are many such people-believe Aboriginal people are being given an easy option, a kind of hand-out, which places white people at a disadvantage. This is steadily creating divisiveness and resentment and can be in no way acceptable as a long-term policy. It would only lead, I suggest, to a steady growth of community backlash against Aboriginal people; and there is evidence of that already.

Our society has grave internal weaknesses over this matter of Aboriginal unemployment. Many influential people seem not to be disposed to admit that there is any kind of problem at all. Even worse is the tendency they have to strike back at those who try to identify the problem and to do something about it. I must number among those racists the truly influential areas of the Liberal Party of Western Australia. When our colleague the honourable Fred Chaney was the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs I several times had good occasion to congratulate him for the enlightened and thoughtful way in which he was trying to grapple with the overall Aboriginal problem. I recall reading, I think last year, a Press report in which Senator Chaney was reported as mildly chiding the Western Australian branch of the Liberal Party at a convention for its almost complete lack of interest in his portfolio. We all know now his reward for his comparatively mild and certainly far from extremist or revolutionary policies in that portfolio. It has earned him the name of Red Fred in his own State and among his own Liberal colleagues; that has been said to me by them personally. He has recently had his political throat savaged by the same colleagues when they engineered his defeat in the preselection for the seat of Curtin in the recent Western Australian by-election.

I raise that matter because it is relevant to this debate. It is not good enough that these reactionary and racist elements in our society should be able to do those things, get away with them and apparently wield the influence they do. Does the Government really wish to restrain them or merely use them as an excuse for its current inactivity in these areas? I plead with all honourable senators, especially Government senators, to consider the plight of the present Minister, Senator Baume, after observing in Western Australia this object lesson in practical politics. If we are to get anything effective done in this area of Aboriginal employment Senator Baume will have to be supported solidly by his own party and, of course, by others. He certainly would have the support of the Australian Democrats for any decisive moves he makes to solve these kinds of problems.

Of course, the problem of unemployment cannot be isolated as a single problem; it is not really that at all. It is a symptom rather than a basic issue. It is a symptom of other things that are wrong. What are those other things? They include bad health conditions, especially child health; bad housing; and dismal failure in coping with the special needs of Aboriginal education which has tended to perpetuate the problems from generation to generation. I heard nothing in what the Minister said to suggest that he even understood this problem, much less that he was prepared to consider reasonable options open to us. Firstly, with regard to education, I would like to quote the words of a Mr Colin Bourke who was written about in the Melbourne Age last year. Mr Bourke is the head of the Aboriginal Research Centre at Monash University. The Age said of him last year:

Mr Bourke has bachelor degrees in commerce and education, an MBE and an Aboriginal ancestry in which he takes pride. He is involved in several black community groups, and in the National Aboriginal Employment Development Committee's Victorian campaign and the Victorian Aboriginal Education Consultative Group.
His comments on education are interesting. I quote them from the Age, as follows:
'Schools are designed to be extensions of the home-a white man's home, 'Mr Bourke said. Black children were at an immediate disadvantage when they attended normal schools.

Mr Bourke said so many things in a classroom were unfamiliar to a black child that he felt isolated. Many had not sat behind a desk before, or had used a pen. Suddenly they were being taught by a white teacher, surrounded by white children and with another sort of discipline.
Many black children were further disadvantaged because their parents had not gone through school and were perhaps illiterate themselves.
To some children, English was a foreign language. In the 1976 census, more than 27,000 people said they spoke an Aboriginal language regularly.
Mr Bourke said Aboriginals should attend special schools which gave them a closer tie with their culture and taught them in a more familiar way.

It has been suggested to me that somehow some kinds of institutions, perhaps boarding schools, will be necessary for young Aboriginals so that they can actually break away from a home environment where lighting is poor, where they cannot find a place in which to study in quiet and where, if they have any potential or any chance of breaking through in life, their environment prevents them from doing so. We would have to look at, not as a matter of compulsion but as a facility that might be offered to outstanding Aboriginal children, a boarding school situation, financed by the state, in which they were able to realise their potential among their own peers, their own people, in skills in which they themselves excelled, but not necessarily the kinds of skills we would expect children from a European culture to be expert in. There again, research so far suggests that those things may be very different.

I cannot see that there is any problem about getting such a program going. It is a matter of money and the will to do it. The fact is that the Government has not the will to do it and is listening to the racists, the reactionaries, in the society to the extent that it does not want to do it. I mentioned Senator Chaney's position not in any way as a jibe at him-far from it; I feel he has come through that matter completely to his own credit-but to point out that there are in the community those obstacles, those forces, who wish not to have done certain things which should be done. It seems that young Aboriginals are good at certain trades, including motor and marine engineering, metal working, boilermaking, the metal trades and heavy machinery driving. I have talked to people who have employed them in those fields. They are good at them and they like doing the work. I cannot see why special training areas should not be organised to do those things. Some are being done, as I will show a little later. They are also being closed down; that is another matter I want to put to the Minister in a few minutes. I feel that we can provide for young Aboriginal men and women-who are good at nursing, secretarial work and other things, I gather-facilities which would allow them to be employed; but those things are not being provided for them now.

The same kind of situation pertains with regard to health. I suggested at last year's National Aboriginal Week that instead of just talking about things we might as a project get rid of leprosy in our Aboriginal community. There is no excuse at all for this medieval disease still to exist in our midst. I have undertaken to prepare a position paper for the Minister on this subject. I merely say that the information available indicates that very small efforts, money and expertise would have cleared this problem out of Australia long ago but they were not made available. The problems of trachoma and infant mortality amongst Aboriginals are also indictments of this Government. They are a background to the employment problem because those children who do not die of malnutrition suffer brain damage. They reach the stage at which their difficulties with education and health make it impossible for them to compete effectively with the rest of the people in the work force. All of us in this place know that to be true. It is one of the things which we have elected to ignore.

Maybe we should have an Aboriginal task force trained in housing construction methods with wide autonomy like that given to Maori work gangs in New Zealand that are working extremely well. There should be autonomy in housing design. It has been suggested that the Aboriginal people might welcome hamlet-type housing with communal amenities and would prefer semi-rural surroundings. Let us create the means for Aboriginal people to solve these problems for themselves. I ask the Minister: Why was it that the Aboriginal housing company in Sydney was closed down last year and its funding cut off although its function was to provide training for young Aboriginal people in housing construction skills? Why were the 30 white tradesmen there who were training Aboriginal apprentices sacked? That is an example of the way the Government provides additional employment opportunities for Aboriginals-by cutting off funds for these valuable programs.

Of course, time will have to pass to solve the problems such as health, housing and education that I have mentioned. Those problems span generations. Therefore, it seems that some effective short term measures are necessary. Like Senator Baume, I have availed myself of the opportunity to have an Aboriginal staff member. I commend the Government for this initiative in attaching Aboriginal people to the staff of senators and members of Parliament. The experiment has been a triumphant success in my office and I shall certainly repeat it. It may give us more than a hint of what we should be doing for the Aboriginals. We might have to consider some kind of preferment of Aborigines for jobs in certain areas and training Aborigines to fit them with skills to work in those areas. I understand from those who know this problem better than I do that many areas of government employment could be available but in fact are not being made available to Aboriginal people. An obvious one is training more Aboriginal teachers for the teaching of Aboriginal children. I would have thought that that would have been square one. But the training of Aboriginal teachers in terms of numbers is pitiful. I have been told that in New South Wales there are only four. Positions in those areas involving Aboriginals, such as education and housing, ought to go to Aborigines on a planned basis geared in with a training program aimed at developing the specific skills which are required.

I would like to stress finally these other areas for which specific training might fit young Aboriginal people. They include the trade skills, in which many Aboriginals have proved apt-motor and marine mechanics, boilermaking, metal work, heavy machinery driving and the training of girls as secretaries and nurses. None of this training is being done. It would not be difficult to carry out such training. The Government has no cause for complacency. On the whole, the Australian Democrats must support the subject matter of this matter of public importance. The Government has little to congratulate itself on in respect of Aboriginal employment. There is much more it could and should do and the sooner it starts the better.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bonner Sen N.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is discussing a matter of public importance raised by Senator Ryan from the other side of the chamber. The subject matter of the discussion is:

SPEECH.PARA: The failure of the Government to develop employment opportunities for Aborigines.

It is all very well for Senator Ryan to propose such a discussion. In her early remarks she said that she wished to adopt a bipartisan attitude on this matter. If that were so and if that also was the position taken by Senator Mason on behalf of the Australian Democrats, perhaps the kind of wording of the discussion should have been 'to deplore the high unemployment rate amongst Aborigines' and 'to urge the Government to do more than it is already doing'. I would have thought that that wording may have led to a bipartisan attitude.

I have sat here and listened to all of the speakers from the other side of the chamber; including Senator Mason. I am still waiting for one honourable senator to come up with one constructive idea to let the Government know what it should be doing, apart from what it is already doing. I am very conscious of the high unemployment rate amongst the Aboriginal people. I suppose I have some qualifications in this respect because I have five Aboriginal sons, two Aboriginal foster daughters and 18 Aboriginal grandsons including five Aboriginal children of one of my foster daughters. In Aboriginal terms, that makes me a grandfather of 23 Aboriginal children. Therefore I have some qualifications, I believe, to speak on this very important matter being discussed in this chamber today.

I think one has to look at the achievements of Liberal-National Country Party governments over the years since the 1967 referendum. It was a Liberal-National Country Party government that set up the Office of Aboriginal Affairs after the 1967 referendum and created for the first time in Australian history a position of a Federal Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. The honourable Bill Wentworth, one of the greatest fighters for Aborigines, I think, that this nation has seen in a long time, was appointed to that position. The Office of Aboriginal Affairs changed to the Department of Aboriginal Affairs and there has been a string of Ministers in charge of the Aboriginal Affairs portfolio. It was like musical chairs during the Labor Government's regime of about five years. Since that time we have had three Ministers who have done a remarkable job in the field of Aboriginal affairs.

Let me refer to some of the things that the Government has been doing and is doing about unemployment among Aboriginals. The Lord knows that I am conscious of this because I grew up in a situation which a lot of people today would not even have a clue about. I know what it is to be unemployed. I know how degrading, how dehumanising it is not to have a good job, not to have a decent income to be able to buy the things that one would like for himself and his family. I know what that is all about. Let me deal with what the Government has tried to do. I ask honourable senators to look at some of the achievements of the present Government.

For example I refer to the announcement in the House of Representatives on 26 May 1977 in respect of the National Employment Strategy for Aboriginals. That strategy has the following strands: The Community Development Employment Projects Scheme; the National Aboriginal Employment Development Committee; Aboriginal Employment and Training in the Public Sector; an expanded use of the National Employment and Training System for Aboriginals and a greater use of the Commonwealth Employment Service. They are some of the things that the Government is doing to try to create employment for Aboriginal people. The Community Development Employment Projects Scheme, which is conducted by the Department of Aboriginal Affairs, provides an alternative to the unemployment benefit by making money available to Aboriginal communities to allow them to pay participants for work done on projects chosen by the community. This scheme is aimed at putting the responsibility back into the hands of the Aboriginals by making money available to Aboriginal communities for the creation of employment opportunities for their people in their own communities. The Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs, the honourable Ian Viner, is responsible for the running of the National Aboriginal Employment Development Committee. The role of the Commitee is to stimulate private sector employment and the training of Aboriginal people. The Committee consists of representatives of the Aboriginal people, commerce, industry, trade union groups, the Department of Aboriginal Affairs and the Department of Employment and Youth Affairs.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's terrific.

—It is certainly a lot better than what happened in the past. We are making progress. The Government is attacking the problem in the best way possible. It is doing so slowly and sensibly. There is no sense in creating employment opportunities which will not be satisfactory for Aboriginal people and which will not give them a sense of responsibility and a sense of achievement. I know what it is like. I do not want to work on a job where I am just digging a hole, passing the dirt over from that hole to another one and back again. I want to do a job that is worthwhile, so do my children and so do my grandchildren. They want to contribute something to the Australian way of life. That is the kind of employment that we want. Under the present Government and the schemes that have been initiated by it, that is exactly what we have been endeavouring to do. Sure, we can criticise, say that more should be done and that more money should be spent. We can say that. But overall, the Government, I believe, is doing what it needs to be doing at this time.

SPEECH.PARA: The National Aboriginal Employment Development Committee has conducted campaigns promoting the employment image of Aborigines and to secure job placements for Aboriginals in areas of high Aboriginal unemployment. The most recent campaign was conducted in Perth during October 1980. Similar campaigns have been held in Queensland, Victoria, New South Wales and South Australia. I was very proud to be involved in the launching of the campaign in Kempsey and Lismore last year on behalf of the Minister. I believe that campaign was a tremendous effort. At Kempsey and Lismore, literally hundreds of people came to find out what the scheme was all about and to see in what way they could be of assistance. It was a great success.

TALK.START.PARA: —They got jobs for people, Senator.

—Yes, they got jobs for people because the campaign was something that was responsible and appealing to the people. We stand up here and say that this matter is the responsibility of the Government. It is not wholly and solely the responsibility of any one section of the community. It is the responsibility of the Federal Government, State governments, industry, trade unions and people in the community. It is an overall responsibility on each of us. We all have to participate in any program that the Government may put forward. It is pointless for the Government to put forward some kind of proposition that will not be accepted by the trade unions or by industry. Such a proposal would be to no avail. I have seen this happen time and again.

SPEECH.PARA: I can quote what has happened over the years. Before I left Palm Island in 1960 I was in charge of building and construction work there. I was a carpenter in my own right. I did not have a little piece of paper stating that I was a carpenter. But I trained 23 young Aborigines to build houses. We were building houses for the community. When we came to the mainland, we could not get a job in our trade because the trade unions said that we did not have this little piece of paper. Do not tell me what it's like to be an Aborigine. I know what it is like. When other honourable senators have had that experience they can tell me. The union would not accept me without that piece of paper. I could not become a carpenter on the mainland because I did not have a little piece of paper stating that I was a tradesman. What the Government is endeavouring to do is to ensure through the education system that young Aborigines taking on jobs are fully trained and that they will be accepted by all sections of the community. This is what the Government is endeavouring to do at the moment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Now let us get sensible.

—Yes, let us get sensible. Let us look at other schemes that the Government has been able to introduce. Let us look at some of the achievements made in Aboriginal affairs matters. Let us look at the National Aboriginal Conference which was set up by the Government. This is the first time in history, under the restructured NAC, that Aboriginal people are having a direct input to the Government through the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Peter Baume) to the Cabinet. The restructured National Aboriginal Conference provides advice to the Government and members of such bodies at the Aboriginal Development Commission and the Council for Aboriginal Development. It is negotiating with the Government for a Makarrata. It is hosting the Third General Assembly of the World Council of Indigenous Peoples with the help of a $90,000 grant from the Federal Government. It is making its presence felt, not only in Australia, but also internationally. This is the body that has been set up by the Government to give advice to it.

SPEECH.PARA: In relation to the Aboriginal Development Commission, as a result of legislation introduced into the Federal Parliament on 21 November 1979 by me, the Aboriginal Development Commission commenced operation on 1 July 1980. The Aboriginal Development Commission replaces the Aboriginal Land Fund Commission and the Aboriginal Loans Commission and has taken over the Aboriginal Enterprises Program from the Department of Aboriginal Affairs. Again, Aborigines are doing something for Aborigines. Money is being placed into Aboriginal hands instead of being spent by non-Aboriginal people allegedly doing things for Aborigines. The creation of the Commission means that Aboriginal people are doing things for Aborigines.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has created another one hundred jobs.

—Yes, another hundred jobs have been created for Aboriginal people by this Government.
