On 1 July 1981, the Aboriginal Development Commission will take over the housing grants-in-aid program of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs. This means that more responsibility will go into the hands of Aboriginals. This Commission has $23.838m allocated to it for its work amongst Aboriginal people.

SPEECH.PARA: In relation to land rights the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act has resulted in Aboriginals obtaining freehold title to over 105,000 square kilometres of land in the Northern Territory. They are receiving also substantial amounts in the form of payments related to mining royalties for mining operations on Aboriginal lands. Through the operations of the land councils, they are negotiating agreements with mining companies regarding new mining operations on their land.

TALK.START.PARA: —What are you quoting from? Are you reading from notes?

—Yes, I am reading from notes. I will be quite happy to give them to Hansard when I have finished. You can have a loan of them; perhaps you will learn something, Senator Georges, from the notes from which I am reading. Let us look at some of the general achievements. As a result of education grants introduced by the Gorton Government, there are now 5,000 Aboriginal children studying at secondary schools, compared with 3,690 in 1967, with a further 4,500 at technical and tertiary institutions. The action of the Government which is enabling Aboriginal children to get a better education will result in Aboriginal people being able to obtain responsible, decent employment. Tertiary education and secondary education are very important. As a result of such education, Aboriginals will be able to fit into the community where they want to and not where they are told to. They will be able to compete on the open market with other Australians. That should be the aim of all people. We do not want handouts; we want our standards to be uplifted. We want to be able to do things for ourselves. We want to be given the responsibility for doing these things. That is what the Fraser Government is achieving in Aboriginal affairs at the moment.

SPEECH.PARA: More than 7,000 houses have been constructed for Aboriginal families. Eleven independent Aboriginal legal services, funded by the Federal Government, have now been established throughout Australia. Here are more jobs for Aboriginal people. Aboriginal people are working in many different occupations and dealing with their own people. We are employing only those non-Aborigines who have the expertise that, unfortunately, we do not have at this time in certain skilled occupations. I refer to solicitors and barristers, among others.

DEBATE.TITLE: COMMONWEALTH EMPLOYEES (REDEPLOYMENT AND RETIREMENT) AMENDMENT BILL 1981

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Ordered that the Bill may be taken through all its stages without delay.
Bill (on motion by Senator Messner) read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to incorporate the second reading speech in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

This Bill will have the effect of removing from the Public Service Arbitrator the jurisdiction to make determinations in relations to matters covered by the Commonwealth Employees (Redeployment and Retirement) Act 1979, hereafter referred to as the Act. This Bill arises in connection with the Government's decision announced on 5 February, the day before the Act was proclaimed to come into operation, that the Government would move to disapprove under section 22 of the Public Service Arbitation Act 1920, Determination No. 503 of 1980.

The Determination has been disapproved by the House of Representatives. The effect of this action is that the Determination has ceased to operate and it has no practical effect prior to the Government's announcement of its intention to move for disapproval. The Government believes that it is essential in relation to matters as fundamental as the efficient and economical use of staff in the Public Service that the Parliament should lay down and be seen to lay down the rules and regulations appertaining thereto and not some other body.

It was and is the Government's intention that Determination No. 509 of 1977 should operate in conjunction with the Act. Together they would provide a code of practice and benefits which would have to be followed by the Board and departments in the handling of redundancy situations. The Bill seeks to amend section 24 of the Act and, as I have already pointed out, it will in effect remove the jurisdiction of the Arbitrator to make a legal determination for or in relation to the matters comprehended by the Act. Its true effect will be that any future change which might be thought necessary to the code of practice and benefits applicable to the situations referred to will have to be brought about by the government of the day by legislation and thus it will, as it should, make the Parliament the ultimate arbiter on matters relating to redeployment, retirement, termination and other aspects covered by the Act and Determination No. 509 of 1977.

I must emphasise that the Government makes a real distinction between matters relating to the engagement and termination of the service of staff which are the prerogative of management and determinations in relation to traditional areas such as wages and salaries, annual leave and hours of duty which are properly matters for arbitration. Let me also remind honourable senators of the history of this matter. In 1976 the Commonwealth Employees (Redeployment and Retirement) Bill was introduced on the basis that it would not proceed further until there had been an adequate opportunity for debate and for consultation between the Public Service Board and unions. In the event, the Bill lapsed on the prorogation of Parliament in early 1977. When the Bill was introduced again in 1979 changes had been made arising from the intervening discussions with peak union councils. The main changes were the specification of reasons for which staff could be identified for redeployment and retirement and the inclusion of more detail of the appeal arrangements for the review of decisions.

The revised legislation gave comprehensive and elaborate protection to staff and was the result of extensive consultation with Public Service unions. Despite this, during 1979 some unions introduced bans and limitations. Some staff were stood down. In the result the Administrative and Clerical Officers Association, the Australian Public Service Association (Fourth Division Officers), and the Federated Clerks Union lodged applications with the Public Service Arbitrator, which were later referred to a Full Bench of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. These applications sought a determination relating to procedures for consultation with staff organisations in redundancy situations and the specification of minimum time periods of up to 29 months to be observed before staff could be redeployed to a lower paid job or terminated, plus a range of related claims. In effect, part of the purpose of the application was to change the provisions and frustrate the intent of legislation which had been passed by the Parliament and which at that time had not been put into operation. The Board opposed the application, arguing that the claims made were inconsistent with the Act and that the provisions of the Act together with the provisions of Public Service Arbitrator's Determination No. 509 of 1977 provided sound, workable, and fair arrangements for the handling of surplus staff, invalidity retirements and other redeployment and termination in Commonwealth employment and that the applications should be rejected. The Government supported the Board's attitude.

The Full Bench decided in December 1979 that a determination should be made and that it should cover a range of matters. The Commission did not issue a determination but directed the parties to discuss and draw up a draft determination to give effect to the Commission's decision. Agreement could not be reached between the Board and the relevant unions and in the result two documents were submitted to the Commission; one prepared by the Board, the other by the unions. It was made clear to the Arbitrator and the Commission that nothing in the draft determination prepared by the Board or the Board's comments should be taken to indicate agreement by the Board to the terms of a determination nor should be seen as committing the Board in any respect. So much for the claim which has been made by the unions that the Board got what it wanted.

On 23 December 1980 the Commission made a determination which came into operation on the date of proclamation of the Act-6 February 1981. Shortly before the Act came into operation the Board issued 106 staff with six-month or 12-month notices of redundancy, not retrenchments, in accordance with the provisions of Determination No. 509 of 1977. These notices were not issued under the provisions of the Commonwealth Employees (Redeployment and Retirement) Act. Not unexpectedly some leaders of the Public Service unions chose to make deliberately confusing and misleading comments about these notices, implying that they were retrenchment notices issued in secrecy and had been issued under the Act. They set about putting fear into the minds of their members that something new and horrific was happening to them. They chose to ignore the fact that 89 of the notices were issued to staff who had declined to move to Canberra with their jobs under the normal Canberra transfer arrangements and that these staff had known for at least 12 months of the Government's decision to transfer their jobs to Canberra. They chose to ignore the fact that long established and well understood practices meant that the notices would issue at about the time they did.

These same leaders also chose to ignore the fact that it was not the first time staff declining transfer to Canberra had been issued with such notices. They were silent about the fact that there has been a Canberra transfer program since time immemorial and there was nothing new about these transfers. They were also silent about the fact that over the years they have been fully involved in developing procedures to be followed in the transfer program, including the timing of the issue of notices to staff who decline to transfer with their jobs. The unions and the officers themselves know the rights of persons involved in transfer programs and the detriments if they decline to transfer. The Senate will accept, I am sure, that there must be changes in administration from time to time that involve relocation of staff to the place where the work is required to be performed. This is ordinary responsible administration. There is nothing untoward, unreasonable or arbitrary about the processes involved in reallocating staff resources in this way. It is therefore a serious act of irresponsibility on the part of the unions to confuse and mislead their members in this respect and foment fear in their minds.

The other 17 staff who received notices of redundancy are located in the Australian Capital Territory and various States and their jobs were not required because of the winding down of a program, for example, at Woomera, revised administrative arrangements introduced by the Government or normal organisational changes to meet the current needs. Most of the staff involved had been surplus for some time. In this case the unions were advised of the Board's intention to issue those notices to the 17 staff members and they raised no objection. Now some of the same unions obscure the issues and the facts and incite members to industrial action. Transfers to Canberra, and administrative changes have occurred for very many years and will continue to do so. Organisations simply cannot operate without adjusting to change. But the Public Service Board and departments have handled such situations in a careful and responsible way and quite properly have made every endeavour to find other jobs for staff when their existing jobs are no longer available. Indeed, the Board and departments have been successful in redeploying over 1,500 staff since 1976, in addition to larger numbers of staff involved in the Canberra transfer program. The termination of employment is clearly the last resort.

When the legislation was introduced in 1979, the Government ensured that Determination No. 509 of 1977 would continue to operate. That Determination provides a generous code of conditions and some procedures for the handling of surplus staff situations. The Determination requires the Public Service Board to advise the relevant staff association immediately it appears that a surplus staff situation has occurred or is likely to occur, and to provide all relevant details and arrange discussions with union representatives. In addition that Determination also provides for:
(a) six months formal notice for a permanent officer that he is excess to the requirements of the Service and 12 months if over 45 years of age or with 20 or more years service;
(b) a temporary employee shall be entitled to one months formal notice that he is excess to the requirements of the Service;
(c) a permanent officer shall receive an additional one month's formal notice that he is to be transferred to a lower salary level or terminated;
(d) a permanent officer shall be entitled to be retained as an officer on full pay for the notice periods;
(e) paid leave and expenses, where not met by prospective employer, to seek employment;
(f) use of accumulated sick leave in certain specified circumstances;
(g) reasonable expenses of moving household associated with transfer or termination;
(h) every endeavour to redeploy to continue during notice periods; and
(i) subject to minimum periods of service and age a temporary employee who is transferred to a lower salary level or terminated shall receive income maintenance for six to 12 months.

The mere recitation of the benefits available under Determination No. 509 of 1977 to officers and employees who become excess to the requirements of the Service serves to point up the fairness, even generosity, of the conditions which apply to staff under that Determination. Against this background, there seemed at the time of introduction of the legislation in 1979 to have emerged a general acceptance of the appropriateness of the proposed revised arrangements for redeployment and retirement. Sub-section 24 (3) was included in the Bill to facilitate adjustment of existing arbitral determinations in the light of the revised framework introduced by the Act. The provision also allowed retention of existing arbitral determinations dealing with matters related to redeployment and retirement of government employees. The Act, moreover, provides for appeal procedures for the protection of employees from arbitrary or capricious action.

What happened as a result of discussions with staff organisations following the introduction of the Bill initially in 1976 and the subsequent revision of the legislation was that instead of general acceptance of the fair and reasonable revised arrangements the ACOA, in particular, sought determinations under the Public Service Arbitration Act which would undermine the practices and procedures provided for under the Act so as to take out of the hands of management its rightful prerogative for the efficient and economical management of the Public Service as provided for under the Public Service Act. The Government has therefore decided, in order to ensure the integrity of the operation of the Act, to preclude future determinations from detracting from what are, reasonably and properly, management prerogatives. This amendment will leave unaffected the powers of the Public Service Arbitrator to make determinations in traditional areas such as wages and salaries, annual leave and hours of duty. The introduction of this Bill must be seen against a long history of irresponsible and persistent union opposition to the redeployment and compulsory retirement provisions of the Act and a determination by some unions to change the intent of the legislation and frustrate its operation. The unions, in effect, have attempted to challenge through the Commission the right of the Parliament to determine the legislative provisions that will apply to matters as fundamental as the efficient and economical use of staff of the Australian Public Service. The fact is that the Parliament must be the arbiter in such matters. This point is given added force by the fact that the Public Service Arbitration Act has had the disapproval power in it since its inception in 1920. This power has been used by the Senate as recently as 1973.

An important responsibility of the Parliament and the Government is to ensure that the Public Service Board and departments have the appropriate powers to ensure that the services of staff are used efficiently and effectively. This is the very least that the Parliament would require and that the taxpayer would expect. The Government is convinced that matters such as the hiring, redeployment and termination of employment of Commonwealth employees should be the prerogative of the Board and departments operating within the framework set by the Parliament itself. There can be no doubt that Parliament through its legislation has cared well for its employees and protected the rights of individual staff members. Public servants enjoy many advantages over employees in the private industry. They have permanency of employment. Their advancement is by merit. Their rights of redress against arbitrary actions by management are protected by very elaborate and comprehensive appeals provisions in both the Public Service Act and the Commonwealth Employees (Redeployment and Retirement) Act, which are second to none. On top of that they have a generous superannuation scheme and are well paid. Most employees would be satisfied with this but some Public Service unions want more, almost without limit. They seem to say that public servants should never be reduced in level, even if work at the employee's level is not available or the employee is inefficient; and that a public servant's employment should never be terminated, even if there is no work available for him or her to perform. Such propositions would be quite unacceptable to the community. They are unacceptable to the Government. It is our firm view that public servants have obligations and responsibilities which follow on from the generous conditions and protections which the Parliament has provided. Not least, public servants have a duty to provide an uninterrupted high standard of service to the people of Australia. Such responsibilities seem to have been put in the background by those union leaders who have incited public servants to industrial action over the Act, legislation which plainly aims to ensure that the services of public servants are used efficiently, effectively and economically.

This Bill will, as I have pointed out, leave in operation Determination No. 509 of 1977. It will also preserve the provisions of other determinations, in particular clauses specifying notice periods which have already been made by arbitral authorities. It will also permit the parties to these determinations to be varied. The Government considers that the provisions of Determination No. 509 of 1977 taken together with the provisions of the legislation are fair, just, adequate and appropriate to protect individuals and to see that they are fairly treated in relation to redeployment and retirement. Certainly, many outside the Public Service would like to have such conditions. The Government as always is prepared to consider constructive comments about the operation of the Act. The Minister Assisting the Prime Minister (Mr Viner) has already given a commitment to the Council of Australian Government Employee Organisations that the Government is prepared to review the provisions of the Act if, after some experience with its operation, it can be demonstrated that its procedures operate unfairly.

The staff of the Australian Public Service and Commonwealth authorities are, generally speaking, dedicated and hard-working. They come in for a good deal of criticism. Much of the criticism is exaggerated and unjustified and does not pay proper respect to the dedication and service given to their countrymen. It is a great pity that the actions of a minority of public servants and of some of the present leaders of the ACOA have tarnished the proud history of a non-political public service in Australia. Therefore, I commend the Bill to the Senate.

DEBATE.TITLE: SHIPPING REGISTRATION BILL 1981FLAGS AMENDMENT BILL 1981NAVIGATION AMENDMENT BILL 1981

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 10 March, on motion by Senator Chaney:
That the Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Shipping Registration Bill 1981 may appear to be a rather innocuous piece of legislation but, as I will seek to show to the Senate, it is a very important piece of legislation. In fact, the three Bills before the Senate-the Shipping Registration Bill 1981, the Flags Amendment Bill 1981 and the Navigation Amendment Bill 1981-have been a long time coming before the national Parliament. The purpose of the Bills is to abolish the requirements for British legislation to register Australian owned vessels, to establish the criteria for Australian registration, to set up a single Australian register and to establish the Australian Red Ensign as the colours of the Australian merchant fleet and the Australian national flag or the Australian Red Ensign as permissible colours for other Australian vessels. Because this is an important step towards national independence, the Opposition does not oppose the Bills.

SPEECH.PARA: As the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) mentioned in his second reading speech, the principal Bill of the package, the Shipping Registration Bill 1981, seeks to repeal Part I of the United Kingdom Merchant Shipping Act 1894 insofar as it applies to Australian law. I remind the Senate that that piece of legislation has had application to our shipping industry for the last 87 years. A navigation Act was passed in 1912 which took us a little bit along the way towards an independent position, but that was 69 years ago. It was not until 1931, just 50 years ago, that we took another step to establish a somewhat independent position. So we have been a long time travelling the road to bring about the situation that this legislation seeks to bring about, that is, the establishment of our own presence in our own maritime industry.

The Bill seeks to abolish the present Australian registration system which registers Australian owned ships as British ships, hence enabling Australian nationality to be granted to Australian owned ships. To that extent we are coming of age. In fact, we have cut the umbilical cord that has been with us for more than 100 years. The legislation establishes us in an independent position, a position which I hope will ultimately put us in a situation in which we will have our own maritime fleet, maritime industry and independent shipping industry. The agreement in 1931 to which I have referred was rescinded by all member countries, thus rescinding their participation as part of the British Commonwealth of Nations. A mutual agreement was signed in 1978 which took us slightly closer to the position being taken in this piece of legislation. Yet Australia is the only independent member of the Commonwealth, apart from Britain, that has continued to operate under the Merchant Shipping Act system. Therefore, this legislation is rather important and will completely cut our dependence on the British shipping legislation. To that degree we will have taken a very important step when we pass this legislation this evening.

The principal Bill seeks to establish criteria for both compulsory and voluntary registration of Australian ships. Compulsory registration will be required for commercial vessels which are more than 50 per cent Australian owned and which are more than 12 metres in length. Voluntary registration is permitted to government vessels, fishing vessels, pleasure craft, Australian-owned vessels of less than 12 metres in length, vessels less than 12 metres in length solely operated by Australian nationals or residents and ships on demise charter to Australian based operators. One has only to refer to those matters to realise what a subordinate position this country has been in with regard to our shipping industry.

The legislation seeks to establish a single Australian register, with a central office and branches as required. This will overcome the present peculiarity of having 20 ports of registry with no complete national register in one place listing all registered vessels. As a consequence of this legislation, there will be no ports of registery as such. However, because of the importance of the port of registry concept for legal and other purposes, as I think the Senate will appreciate, the Bill provides for the adoption of a concept of a home port for each ship. So the practice of marking the port on a ship's stern will thus be maintained. It is a national disgrace that the Australian Parliament and the nation as a whole has permitted the present state of affairs to continue for so many years, and to that extent the Government is to be commended for the steps taken in this legislation to establish Australian shipping in its own right, independent of any former relationships.

The two subsidiary Bills, the Flags Amendment Bill 1981 and the Navigation Amendment Bill 1981, are consequential on the principal Bill. Together they make provision for the Australian Red Ensign to be the colours of our merchant fleet. I do not canvass the view that that is a very acceptable position. For all other Australian vessels the Australian national flag or the Australian Red Ensign will be the national colours. Of course, this will not remove our dependence upon foreign vessels. The Opposition concedes the importance of the step, but we have a long way to go before a fully independent position is taken. For example, Australian vessels have carried between 0.1 per cent and 3.1 per cent of our exports and between 0.3 per cent and 2 per cent of our imports. In terms of general cargoes, the respective figures are 3.3 per cent and 7.3 per cent of exports and 6.1 per cent to 12 per cent of imports.

Surely it must be conceded that these are abysmally low figures for such an important country as Australia, a country engaged in world trade of tremendous and growing magnitude. As I have said, those figures are very low. Most of the remaining cargo is transported in ships owned by British container shipping companies the Conference system or in bulk ships and tankers belonging to the big multinational companies. Most bulk exports from Australia to Japan, for example, are transported in Japanese bulk carriers. Japanese flag vessels have carried between 39 per cent and 45 per cent of bulk cargoes which have left these shores since 1972-73.

TALK.START.PARA: —But that situation has altered to our advantage in recent years.

—Of course. Since bulk exports account for some 80 per cent in volume of all Australian overseas trade, the power of Japanese shipowners can be readily gauged and we can understand the desire of the maritime industry in this country to improve Australia's position. Because of the lack of an adequate Australian overseas fleet, and consequently lack of control over conditions for shipping Australian exports and imports, Australia is placed in a very weak commercial and strategic position, as a result of which all Australians suffer. I concede, of course, that places such as Tasmania would suffer particularly in that respect. Each year we lose hundreds of millions of dollars in freight and insurance payments to overseas shipowners. This has had a tremendous effect over the years in keeping the Australian shipbuilding and ship repair industries in a subordinate position, a position in which they are starved of capital and unable to develop for want of markets and work. I hope that the Government, having taken this important step, will move quickly to the next stage and establish a more durable shipbuilding industry in this country. The industries having been starved of capital and markets, the resultant loss of jobs, both direct and indirectly, has been substantial. In recent years various regions of our country have been affected by this decline in our shipbuilding industry. Jobs for seamen and for those who could build or repair vessels have been lost abroad, some might say for all time because of the economies of scale that have been developed in other parts of the world. We hope that, given government encouragement and assistance, these jobs can be won back for us. If this massive freight expenditure were retained in Australia, the multiplier effects on Australian industry, especially shipbuilding and ship repairs, would be substantial. It has to be conceded, surely, that these are the sorts of labour-intensive industries we need if our economy is to be strengthened by the current rearrangement of exports and imports, and by the manufacturing and trade changes that currently are affecting the prosperity of this country.
—Do you accept that they need to be efficient in world terms, though?

—That is true. Additionally, the conditions and cost of shipping Australian overseas trade rest in the hands of overseas corporations, and this affects domestic freight pricing. Australia being an island continent, most of our markets are a great distance from where our goods are produced. The cost of transport is of great significance in determining whether our goods will be competitive in the international market, yet we have very little say in the prices charged for shipping these goods abroad. The Conference system is largely outside our control and has not operated in the interests of Australia. This means that pressure is exerted by producers and manufacturers, wherever and whenever they can do so, on the cost of Australia's domestic freight system. Often this means the Government providing what I term commercial welfare to local exporters in the form of freight subsidies via government instrumentalities, and cost recovery on the cost of road freighting and the construction of export roads. This is something that has to be changed, and I am sure that it will be changed as more and more of our indigenous industries demand action by the national government.

SPEECH.PARA: Australia is a major trading nation which each year has about 6,000 vessels calling on its shores and carrying upwards of 200 million tonnes of cargo. Yet up until now Australia has not been regarded as a maritime nation. Only a meagre amount of our overseas trade is carried in our ships. With the development of resources in Australia, how important it is for us to look at this aspect in terms of an industry being given a shot in the arm by a national government. I have already mentioned the cost to the Australian community, Australian industry, and Australian primary producers of failure to do this, but there are a number of reasons for this detrimental imbalance. Some people seek to explain it by economics, by claiming that our costs are too high, our wages are too high, and so on. Rather, I think it is better explained by Australia's colonial heritage, against which we are still struggling, and I hope the Bills now before us will help to remedy that past situation.

Australia has never been a major maritime nation, and one finds it difficult to understand why in the past we have not taken steps to establish ourselves in a more independent position. It is probably due to the historical ties to Britain, which is a strong maritime nation. Time and again I hear Senator Carrick ask why changes did not take place during the years from 1972 to 1975. If we consider the post-war years we appreciate that the conservatives have been in office for very much longer than a Labor government has been in office. We were in a somewhat beseiged, beleagured state during the years of the Whitlam Government, and one could not have expected it to take all the steps necessary to put Australia in the position which this legislation seeks to establish. We have been in a position where we were part of a colonial heritage, and our ship registration system was a captive to the British system. We are now taking the step to cut that tie. Our lack of a large locally-owned fleet led to a short term expediency of seeking the best freight conditions from overseas ship owners, and I recall many debates in this Parliament which sought to improve our indigenous position.

The policy of conservative governments of the past has been one of neglect and one which Labor rejects as being unsatisfactory for the past or for the present. We support the extension of the Australian fleet both internationally and on the Australian coast. The later Labor Government supported the United Nations Conference on Trade and Development on the 40-40-20 principle. This is often quoted as representing a fair international distribution of freight carriage. In essence, the conference recommended that Australia and other trading nations should carry 40 per cent of their trade. It recommended that 40 per cent should be carried by the importing nation, 40 per cent by the exporting nation and the remaining 20 per cent by cross-traders. I believe that a similar policy is desirable in respect of repairs to overseas vessels. This would have a tremendous effect upon our ship repairing industry. At the moment we perform about only one or 2 per cent of those repairs. If the principle in respect of the carrying of our exports and imports was carried into effect in our ship repairing industry there would be a very important and regenerative effect upon our ship building industry. Consequently, we expect the Government to be more energetic as a result of the carriage of this Bill.

An understanding has developed within the maritime industry between the owners of our shipping industry and the unions. I appreciate the time factor involved but I think it is worth while to note and approve of the balanced approach that has been taken by the maritime industry-by both employer and employee organisations-to reach a point where there is common ground and a common desire to establish a better understanding and acceptance of the responsibilities and the problems on each side of this industry. We regard it as a welcome development for Australia. I hope that this approach is supported by both sides of the chamber and that the maritime industries will move forward as one in the interests of capital investment, of labour and of our indigenous industries. If that is able to be achieved, this piece of legislation is a very vital and important one. We must see it only as step further back from the 1894, 1912, 1931, 1978 and 1979 legislation. The legislation in 1981 puts us in a position where we will take the essential steps to establish this country as capable of sustaining and maintaining a viable maritime industry. We support the passage of the legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Gietzelt for his support of the three Bills which are, as he indicated, of great national concern and importance. The difficulties which face the Australian maritime industries are chiefly those of cost which are a function of distance from markets as well as being a function of the particular difficulties with industrial disputes and with labour costs in this country. Nevertheless, those are matters to which we need to address ourselves as time goes by. I am sure Senator Gietzelt acknowledges that. I thank him again for his support of the legislation.

DEBATE.TITLE: STAGING OF B52s THROUGH AUSTRALIA FOR SEA SURVEILLANCE IN THE INDIAN OCEAN AND FOR NAVIGATION TRAINING

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CARRICK
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Honourable senators will recall that negotiations on the staging of B52 aircraft through Australia were temporarily suspended to allow the new Administration of President Reagan time to examine and consider the matter. I am pleased to inform the Senate that in the course of his recent talks in Washington with Secretary of State, Alexander Haig, the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Street), took this matter further and was able to bring it to a successful conclusion. Agreement has now been reached between our two governments on the terms and conditions which will govern United States Air Force B52 staging flights through Darwin. I am tabling the texts of the notes exchanged between the Department of Foreign Affairs and the United States Embassy on 11 March 1981, which constitute this agreement. As honourable senators will note, the agreement provides that: The B52 flights shall be for sea surveillance in the Indian Ocean area and for navigation training; the agreement of the Australian Government would need to be obtained before the facilities at the Royal Australian Air Force Base, Darwin, could be used in support of any other category of operations; the B52 aircraft on surveillance flights will be supported by KC135 tanker aircraft for aerial refuelling and the operations shall consist of periodic deployments of up to three B52 and six KC135 aircraft; about 100 United States Air Force personnel and associated equipment will support the staging operations and some of these may be stationed at RAAF Base, Darwin; there will be no change in the status of RAAF Base, Darwin, as an Australian facility under Australian control. As the terms of the agreement make abundantly clear, nothing in the arrangements governing these flights could be regarded as in any way infringing Australian sovereignty; and the United States will provide the Australian Government with full and timely information about strategic and operational developments relevant to the B52 staging operations through Darwin.

SPEECH.PARA: The Senate will be aware that United States Air Force B52 aircraft are currently conducting low-level navigation training over Australia. As the Minister for Defence (Mr Killen) stated on 3 February 1980, these flights originate at Guam, the aircraft carry out navigational training over Queensland and then return to their base at Guam. The operations will be an extension of these current operations. After completing the low-level training exercises, the aircraft will land at Darwin and refuel. After appropriate crew rest the aircraft will undertake sea surveillance and navigation training operations over the Indian Ocean-an area of great security interest to both Australia and the United States. The flights will then return via Darwin to Guam. As is the case with the current navigational missions, the flights landing at Darwin will be unarmed and will carry no bombs.

As there has been much speculation in the media and elsewhere about this matter, I should like to emphasise that it has been agreed between the Foreign Minister and the Secretary of State that the aircraft staging through Darwin under the arrangements now agreed for surveillance flights and navigation training will be unarmed and will carry no bombs.

As I have also told the Senate, the exchange of notes provides that the Australian Government's agreement would need to be obtained before the Royal Australian Air Force facilities could be used in support of any other category of operations by the United States. In that regard, so that there can be no grounds for question or doubt, let me state the basis on which the agreement of the Australian government would be given to such other operations: Australia would need to know, firstly, what the strategic and tactical objectives are-Australia would need to be in agreement with these-and, secondly, what weapons are being carried and in particular whether nuclear weapons are being carried. The Australian Government has a firm policy that aircraft carrying nuclear weapons will not be allowed to fly over or stage through Australia without its prior knowledge and agreement. Nothing less than this is consistent with the maintenance of our national sovereignty.

The Government is particularly pleased that it has been possible to reach finality on this question so soon in the term of the new Administration. Australia shares the United States determination to take all steps within its power to deter further Soviet expansionism. We stand ready to lend our ANZUS partner what assistance we can in pursuit of our common aims. The provision of staging facilities at Darwin for these United States aircraft will facilitate the surveillance and training operations they are carrying out in an area of prime security concern to Australia. It also affords a further example of the close practical co-operation which has been developed over many years between our two nations. I present the following paper:
Staging of B-52s through Australia for Sea Surveillance in the Indian Ocean and for Navigation Training-Ministerial Statement, 11 March 1981.
I move:
That the Senate take note of the statement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition has had relatively limited time in which to consider the purport of this statement although there has been much media speculation about a decision being reached on this matter. There are, however, one or two things in the statement which do not lead me to the same conclusion which the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Street) drew on our behalf in a discussion--
—Not on my behalf.
—Yes, on our behalf.
—Not on my behalf.
—I ask Senator McLaren to listen to what I am saying before he determines that issue. Mr Street, on the PM program tonight, on Senator McLaren's behalf as well as on mine--
—I dissociate myself from his remarks.

—If Senator McLaren would just listen for a minute, Mr Street, on the honourable senator's behalf as well as on my behalf, said that he expected the Opposition would be happy with this. He did not speak for Senator McLaren and he did not speak for me. That is the point that I seek to make. I hope, if I am given the opportunity, to make it a little more carefully so that it might be fully understood. A number of items in this statement do not bring the warm inner glow to the hearts of members of the Opposition which they apparently bring to the hearts of Government members. I wish to refer to some of those matters in slightly more detail What is extraordinary about the matter is that the Parliament, not having had any opportunity to consider the matter, is presented with a fait accompli in terms of what is essentially a treaty between Australia and the United States. I would have thought that we might have had the benefit of at least a statement of intention regarding that matter in the Parliament before we were presented with such a fait accompli. I shall turn in a minute to some of the details of the fait accompli. I think the way in which they have been set out in the proposed agreement is quite extraordinarily sloppy.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable senators will recall in reading the first paragraph of the statement that the first indication of B52 bombers landing in Darwin was given in the gung-ho pre-election atmosphere in Australia. It was at that time that the idea was first floated, one suspects from Australia rather than from the United States. There was some brief discussion about that in the context of the recent election. Be that as it may, the matter is now consummated, as it were, in terms of this document.

I refer the Senate to one or two points in the document because I argue here that the statement, which has been made by the Minister for National Development and Energy (Senator Carrick) is in a sense inconsistent with the agreement which we are asked to accept. I will refer to the details of that agreement in this way. Firstly it is stated at the foot of page 1 of the prepared statement:
the B52 flights shall be for sea surveillance in the Indian Ocean area and for navigation training.

The agreement of the Australian Government would need to be obtained before the facilities were used for other purposes. It is quite clear that it is for surveillance functions and navigation training, which I think is a new element to which I do not attach any particular importance. It is a new element as it arises in the statement. We are told that nothing in the agreement could be regarded as in any way infringing Australian sovereignty. The statement continues:
The United States will provide the Australian Government with full and timely information about strategic and operational developments relevant to the B52 staging operations through Darwin.

There are, of course, two matters involved-first, the question of the B52s flying over Australia and, secondly, the question of staging operations. But there is an undertaking in the statement that Australia will be provided with 'full and timely information about strategic and operational developments'-whatever that expression might mean in this context. The important point in the statement appears at the foot of page 2 of the prepared statement where Senator Carrick said:

As there has been much speculation in the media and elsewhere about this matter, I should like to emphasise that it has been agreed between the Foreign Minister and the Secretary of State that the aircraft staging through Darwin under the arrangements now agreed for surveillance flights and navigation training will be unarmed and carry no bombs.

Page 3 of the prepared statement reveals that there is a firm policy against carrying nuclear weapons in aircraft which fly over Australia. I refer to sub-paragraph (i) of the purported agreement which states:

The B-52 staging operations shall be for sea surveillance in the Indian Ocean area and for navigation training purposes. The agreement of the Government of Australia shall be obtained before the facilities are used in support of any other category of operations.
Sub-paragraph (VII) of the agreement-this is something which I have difficulty in understanding in view of the provisions of sub-paragraph (I)-states:

Arrangements shall be made for consultations to ensure that the Government of Australia has full and timely information about strategic and operational developments relevant to B-52 staging operations through Australia.

Whatever the expression 'arrangements shall be made' means-there can be a lot of dispute about that-it is quite clear that arrangements are to be made for consultation about other uses of the Darwin facilities and about other uses in circumstances of strategic and operational developments. One wonders why sub-paragraph (VII) of the purported agreement with the United States is necessary if sub-paragraph (I) of the agreement means what it says. It states what the purposes of the flights will be and goes on to say:
The agreement of the Government of Australia shall be obtained before the facilities are used in support of any other category of operations.
It seems to be quite clear. The agreement of the Government of Australia will be obtained before facilities are used for other purposes. Yet sub-paragraph (VII) states:
Arrangements shall be made for consultations to ensure that the Government of Australia has full and timely information about-
Other purposes.

Sub-paragraph (I) states that the agreement of the Australian Government will be obtained before there is any change in the arrangement, yet sub-paragraph (VII) makes the point that information shall be given to Australia about other uses of the base and other uses of the B52s through Darwin as a staging point. That seems to me to be an extraordinary sloppy inconsistency which, I think, justifiably causes worry in the minds of people who are concerned about the implications of the actions of a country which in terms of foreign policy was prepared to talk only a year ago about the Indian Ocean as a potential zone of peace. The Minister for Defence (Mr Killen) only yesterday, I think, answered a question to the effect that he had no information about the deployment of naval vessels in the Indian Ocean. That is the same Minister for Defence, who for years has been able to give most detailed and specific information about the deployment of defence forces in the Indian Ocean region.

The Opposition is not happy with the way that this statement is couched and more particularly with the way the purported agreement is couched. It arouses great suspicion that it will be depending upon an exercise of sloppy goodwill between gung-ho politicians here and in the United States, rather than on any detailed specifications about what the arrangement is, to which the people of Darwin and Australia are entitled. By interjection somebody asked how we would know whether the United States would honour the terms of the agreement insofar as it deals with the carrying of nuclear weapons. I think that is a very good question and people are entitled to ask it. If one looks at the history of our defence arrangements with the United States in recent years, it is quite clear that members of the government of Australia, of whatever political persuasion, are being treated as banana republic politicians who have been told about defence arrangements what it is necessary to tell them and nothing else. For example, in October 1973, at the time of a war in the Middle East, when the North West Cape base was placed on full alert, the government of the day was not informed. The subsequent government was not officially informed. The story leaked out over a period that that had in fact happened. It is quite clear from the arrangements between Australia and the United States in relation to that base that the Government of the day would be informed.

More recently, when there was an attempt to involve Australia in operations in the northern part of the Indian Ocean, following the Afghanistan crisis, it was clear that there was not an absolutely frank exchange of information. It was only as a result of National Country Party pressure relating to the sale of wheat and wool to the Soviet Union that the Australian contingent, which was committed to the north Indian Ocean at that time, was in fact withdrawn. If those sorts of factors are to operate in international politics and the relationship of this country with the United States, there seems to be a need for a better spelling out in a document of this kind what the actual arrangements are.

The statement sounds good in terms of the Government's intention but as honourable senators can see from the fine print in the agreement there is very grave cause for concern and doubt about the Government's intentions or worse, the capacity of the Government to carry out its intentions in terms of its entering into treaty obligations with the United States. I take it that there will be ample opportunity to consider further at a subsequent time the implications of this matter, and not only in the Senate. As I believe that it will be a divisive issue in Australian political life, it is for that reason a matter in which the i's ought to be dotted and the t's crossed. This has not happened in the sloppy statement which the Government has brought down. We very much regret the contents of the agreement as are set out. We would very much like to know the meaning of sub-paragraph (VII) which should be deleted because the provisions of sub-paragraph (I), I think, effectively cover what ought to be the Government's intentions about this matter. Mr President, I shall not seek leave to continue my remarks later in case somebody else wishes to speak now.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Robertson Sen E.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak briefly to the motion that the Senate take note of the paper. I will speak briefly not because the matter is not vitally important but because my leader has already dealt with most of the topics that need to be mentioned and I did dwell on the situation in my contribution to the Address-in-Reply debate yesterday. I listened to the statement tonight of the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Carrick) with a feeling of sadness and frustration. I felt sad because Darwin is my home, and all honourable senators know what that implies.

SPEECH.PARA: I have seen Darwin grow from a small country town of some 3,000 or 4,000 people to a modern city of some 50,000 people. I have seen it rise from tin sheds, Sydney William huts and so on to a modern capital with attractive multi-storey buildings. It is a place which I have seen demolished by a cyclone and rebuilt from the ruins by a group of people who transformed it once again into a pleasant place. I felt sad because I am convinced that it will become a prime target simply because the Government wishes to ingratiate itself with the United States. I felt frustration because it seems to me that at this stage nothing can be done. As my leader has pointed out, we have been given no opportunity to consider this matter. We can do nothing, it would seem, but accept what the Government has done. I hope that the people of Australia who are sitting outside this chamber tonight will offer some alternative. Certainly, those in Darwin will be thinking about it. During the suspension of the sitting for dinner I read the Laurie Oakes Newsletter, which states:
American secret defence bases likely to become nuclear targets in a conflict between the super-powers have all been in Australia's outback, remote from major population centres.
That is one reason there has been relatively little community concern about them.
It has been a case of out-of-sight, out-of-mind.

I have to pose the question: Is this the case with Darwin in the present situation? Is it out of sight, out of mind and, therefore, expendable to the Government? Why do I feel disturbed? What aspects of the proposal that has been put in front of us tonight concern me? I hinted at some of these in my speech yesterday. I shall go quickly through them. Russia has made it quite clear that the staging of B52 aircraft in Darwin will make Darwin a potential target. No matter how much we pontificate about the matter, Russia has warned us that that will happen. It is a fair warning and it is a warning which we should heed. The second point I mentioned yesterday was the possibility of a nuclear accident, which also would wipe out the city. The third point I made and dealt with for some time was that it ties Australia to United States policy. I made the point then that while we would normally go along with the United States and while our aims would be basically the same most of the time, there would be times when we would not want to be involved. I will mention a couple of these instances later. Much less important, but worth mentioning, is the disturbance which this will bring to the local citizens of Darwin. Canberra, Sydney and other cities will not even have commercial aircraft but we are being asked to have B52 aircraft, and all for virtually no return.

Does anyone really believe that the establishment is simply for training and surveillance, whatever that might mean? Anyone who is naive enough to believe that would believe that the United States would tell us when the planes were carrying activated nuclear warheads. Of course it will not. Senator Button has already indicated that. The United States did not tell Australia when all the bases went on red alert. It did not tell Australia of the purpose of its bases in Australia. It did not tell Australia that commercial information was being made available to commercial firms in the United States by eavesdropping on Australian airwaves. It is not likely to tell us of any change in what it calls strategic and operational developments. Why do I say this? Why do I believe that the United States will not tell us? Senator Button has already hinted at it. Honourable senators will recall that when the present American Secretary of State, Mr Haig, was before a Senate committee in the United States and being tested as to whether he was the right sort of person to be the Secretary of State he said quite bluntly: 'I see no reason to tell the United States legislature that the United States was bombing Cambodia for five years. It is not their concern'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who said that?

—Mr Haig, who is now the Secretary of State. So we could hardly expect him to tell the Australian legislature. Some of our critics on the other side of the House might say: 'But he would tell the PM and the PM would know'. What good would it be to the people of Darwin for the Prime Minister to know that the planes coming into and going out of Darwin were carrying activated nuclear warheads? It would be of no value at all. We could not take any sort of action at all. I make the point strongly that we could find ourselves involved in United States involvements in, say, the Middle East and not want to be involved. I will be very interested in what the Minister for Finance (Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle) has to say about the question on nuclear non-proliferation that I put to her this morning. My understanding is that on the signing of that treaty we have agreed not to service or to provide facilities for planes for any other vehicle carrying nuclear warheads. That is mentioned in sub-paragraph (VIII) of the agreement put before us tonight. Sub-paragraph (VIII) also mentions ANZUS-not by name but it refers to our association with New Zealand and the United States. Let me just read the comments which I made yesterday on ANZUS. I said:

SPEECH.PARA: What ties Australia and the United States together? Basically it is the ANZUS treaty. Let me deal quickly with the ANZUS treaty without going into it too deeply. Article IV states:

Each Party recognises that an armed attack in the Pacific area on any of the Parties would be dangerous to its own peace and safety and declares that it would act to meet the common danger in accordance with its constitutional process.
Article IV states:

For the purpose of Article IV, an armed attack on any of the Parties is deemed to include an armed attack on the metropolitan Territory of any of the Parties, or on the island Territories under its jurisdiction in the Pacific or on its armed forces, public vessels or aircraft in the Pacific.

Basically the ANZUS treaty is a watered down version of the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation. Honourable senators will recall the NATO phrase which goes something like 'an attack against one, shall be considered as an attack against all'.

This is not contained in the ANZUS Treaty; it was specifically left out by the United States. I will not go any further except to recall one comment made by Arthur Caldwell when the ratification of the treaty was debated in the House of Representatives back in those days. He said:

There is an obligation on USA and all the other participants in the European Treaty, NATO, to go to each others aid. The only guarantee that it is given in the Pacific Treaty is that the nations will consult in common . . .
There is no real obligation in the Pacific Treaty on anybody and on some grounds it would be better to have no treaty at all.

Certainly, we want to be good to our friends and good to our allies, but at what cost? 'All the way with LBJ' did not bring much to Australia. 'Down the road with Reagan' is not likely to bring us much more, except to take us further down the road. The point I wish to make strongly is that B52 aircraft do not have to stage in Darwin. There are plenty of other places with a lower population, places with airstrips which are not right smack in the centre of the city-Learmonth, Gove, Tindal, to name just a few. As far as I am concerned, the role of a senator is to speak up in this place for his State or territory. I believe that the Government of Australia has sold out the people of Darwin for reasons of sheer expediency. History will record this decision as one of the many blunders of the Fraser Government. I grieve for my city and its people. They have been unnecessarily placed in real danger by a callous government.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Leave out the words 'next day of sitting', insert 'later hour this day'.

In moving the amendment I make the point that the Australian Democrats have been refused the right by the Government to speak on this important issue. I asked for a few minutes to speak on a matter that concerns people like ourselves. After all three quarters of a million Australians voted for the Australian Democrats. Therefore, we thought our request a reasonable one. Two speakers have spoken for the Australian Labor Party. I do not deny their right whatsoever to speak to this matter. We would have thought, however, that it was not unreasonable that the Australian Democrats who have given considerable thought and time to this very important matter-after all we are only going on to a Standing Orders debate after this-should have been allowed the time to discuss this issue. It is not sufficient to argue that we will be given the time to debate the matter at some later stage. Time and time again debates of this sort are adjourned and then it is not possible for honourable senators to speak to the matter when they wish to do so.

I think it is reasonable in this context to give some reason for my moving of this motion. The Australian Democrats have no real objection to the idea of navigation and surveillance by B52 bombers. But we are very concerned by the fact that in the statement read by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Carrick) matters are mentioned which in fact are not mentioned in the text of the note. In other words, the statement makes claims of Australian sovereignty which are not carried out and supported by the text of the agreement. Sub-paragraph (I) of the agreement states:
The B-52 staging operations shall be for sea surveillance in the Indian Ocean area and for navigation training purposes.

There is no mention of the status of the armament of those aircraft. Why could this not be included in the agreement because the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) has made the statement that definitely there will be no nuclear weapons. We in the Australian Democrats are concerned for the safety of the Australian people. We do not take an extreme view of this. We believe in co-operation with our ANZUS allies but we feel that our Government has allowed a sloppy deal to go through which in fact does not permit us to know in terms of the note prepared by the Department of Foreign Affairs and exchanged with the United States Government what is the status of the arming of these aircraft. My second reason for seeking to move an amendment to the motion that the debate be adjourned is to develop more fully the points made by the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Button) on sub-paragraph (VII) of the agreement. We are interested in the agreement not in the statement. After all the agreement is the nitty gritty. Sub-paragraph (VII) states:

Arrangements shall be made for consultations to ensure that the Government of Australia has full and timely information about strategic and operational developments relevant to B52 staging operations through Australia.

To the Australian Democrats, that is far too passive a view. In other words, it indicates that we have a sort of passive role, that Australia will be consulted so that we will have full and timely information. There is no indication in the statement that we will have any choice in what happens if, indeed, strategic and operational developments take place. What are strategic and operational developments? Does this term include the use of nuclear weapons? I have spoken to an ex-Australian diplomat of very senior status whom I do not propose to name. He was in a position to know and he has told me that there is no way in the world that the United States Government will tell any other government whether or not its aircraft are armed with nuclear weapons. And I see no reason why it should.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Mason, do not debate the statement.

I think it is important to make that point. My argument as to why this matter should be dealt with at a later hour this day-in fact, I believe it should be dealt with almost immediately-is that it is possibly one of the most important matters to come before this Parliament. He says that it is important, and he is proud of the fact that he has an assurance that there will be no nuclear weapons in the bombers. SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Government has a firm policy that aircraft carrying nuclear weapons will not be allowed to fly over or stage through Australia without its prior knowledge and agreement.

I repeat that the Prime Minister said that such an operation must have Australia's prior knowledge and agreement. A motion has been moved to the effect that we discuss this matter at some future date. When a motion is moved that the matter be discussed at the next day of sitting, that does not mean that it will come on for debate on the next day of sitting. It will come on for debate whenever the Government wants it to be debated and that may be many weeks hence. But the Opposition is so suspicious of the situation that it thinks the matter should be resolved early in the piece. The importance of this agreement was stressed by the Prime Minister. He is obviously of the opinion that there should be an early resolution of the Parliament's endorsing the agreement. PROCTEXT.PARA: Item 5 (i). Taking of In Camera Evidence.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question is:

-When consideration of this matter was interrupted on 26 February, I was discussing the question whether Senate Estimates committees should take in camera evidence. There was some dispute whether the present provision was adequate or some other provision ought to be made. Senator Rae had enlightened the Committee of the Whole on some of the history relating to the taking of in camera evidence. I understand that he has a proposal to make. I would like to hear Senator Rae's proposal before I speak again.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Following on the discussion which has taken place and in the light of the history of the desire expressed by this chamber and expressed on a number of occasions by various of the Estimates committees, I propose that we should endeavour to resolve the matter by having before the Senate for consideration a specific amendment to the Standing Orders which would permit the taking of evidence in camera by Estimates committees. It is for that reason that I move:

SPEECH.PARA: At end of motion, add ', and this Committee directs the Standing Orders Committee to prepare and present to the Senate during this session an amendment to the Standing Orders to enable Estimates committees to take evidence in camera subject to reporting to the Senate the fact that such evidence has been taken in camera and the reasons for the Committee's decision to take such evidence in camera'.

In the light of the discussion which has taken place, I do not think it is necessary for me at this stage to elaborate again on the reasons for moving such an amendment. I simply reiterate in very brief form that since 1972 this recommendation has been coming to this chamber, debated in this chamber, referred with approval to the Standing Orders Committee and has not yet been affirmatively resolved by an amendment to the Standing Orders. I have moved this amendment so that we can have from the Standing Orders Committee a clear recommendation for an amendment which could be debated in this chamber to finalise one way or other this matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am afraid that I must oppose the amendment moved by Senator Rae because its adoption would mean an instruction to the Standing Orders Committee to bring down a report that Senate Estimates committees can take evidence in camera. The Standing Orders Committee pertinently has pointed out that Estimates committees carry out a function in place of the Committee of the Whole in which in camera evidence cannot be taken. Surely affairs relating to the expenditure of Commonwealth money should not be a secret matter. Whilst the taking of in camera evidence may suit Standing Committees, such practice should be permitted in hearings of the Estimates committees. Therefore, I am opposed to any procedure that would allow for secret evidence to be given to Estimates committees and which would have to be endorsed by the Senate after it is dealt with by the Committee of the Whole. We would have to make a decision on evidence that is available to Estimates committees but not to the Committee of the Whole. It is proposed to have an exclusive section of senators who hear secret evidence which justifies their decision. But when the Committee of the Whole comes to make its decisions, it has not the advantage of that in camera evidence. Surely money that is spent by the Commonwealth is a matter of public interest. Questions on how money is spent and the reasons for that expenditure should be detailed. I point out that the Standing Orders Committee has made the point that evidence in camera can be taken now if the Senate so approves. If there is a good reason for evidence to be taken in camera, let the Estimates committee report to and get the approval of the Senate. Let us not lay down a procedure whereby Estimates committees can at any time go into in camera sessions and take secret evidence. The practice would then become a formality. Those who are not members of the Estimates committee will never know what is going on before the committee. There is also the requirement that hearings of Estimates committees shall be open to the public and to the Press. It is now proposed in this amendment to exclude every right that was granted in the establishment of Estimates committees. It is now proposed to take away those rights by this amendment and to have secret sessions of Estimates committees which can make a decision without the knowledge of anyone else.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Sen K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: -When the Committee was considering this matter on 26 February, I spoke on it and I do not seek to prolong consideration tonight because there has been a good deal of discussion. I did oppose the notion that we ought to change the situation as it obtains at the moment on the taking of in camera evidence; and most of my reasons have already been detailed. I just briefly reiterate that I would want to be persuaded that the present provisions that enable the taking of in camera evidence are in some way defective because, in my experience, I am not so persuaded. However, it is possible that a valid case can be put. I would not object to the Standing Orders Committee looking at the possibility of drafting a standing order just to see what comes out of it and what are the implications of it. To take up Senator Cavanagh's point, we ought to treat the matter of in camera evidence very carefully because, as I said on that previous occasion, the only people who are excluded from private sessions of Estimates committees are the public including the Press. In fact the situation is that all honourable senators could attend to hear in camera evidence. It starts to approach very closely something like the Senate sitting in camera.

SPEECH.PARA: I make these comments to indicate to the Standing Orders Committee when it is looking at the matter-and I will not oppose this question going off to it to look at the possibility of drafting a standing order so that we can see what the implications of it are-that it ought to look very closely at the discussion that has taken place on this question and the sorts of objections that have been raised to the matter of enabling Estimates committees easily to sit in camera.
