SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —My position is quite clear. I think I explained my position on 26 February when we were last debating the report of the Standing Orders Committee. I want to correct a statement made by Senator Lewis when we were debating Item 5 on 26 February. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: Before I do so let me say that Senator McLaren raised the question of Senate Estimates committees not having staff made available to them. In fact, we are trying to arrange, as he would know, for staff to be made available to assist them.
I interjected:
You are trying to arrange it?
Senator Lewis, in reply, said:
I do not think Senator McLaren was present at the last Estimates committee hearings. I think he was overseas at the time.

I want to correct that. I was not overseas at the time. I did not leave Australia last year. I attended hearings of the Estimates committees held in both the autumn session and the Budget session. I want to place on record the fact that I was quite happy with the previous staffing arrangements for Estimates Committee A, of which I was then a member and of which I still am a member. We were very well served by this staff. The staff was headed by Mr Peter Murdoch, who is now the Black Rod and who gave very great service to Estimates Committee A in the initial stages. However, we found it necessary during, I think, the last Budget session to second staff. I want to compliment the staff seconded. They had to work under a very great load. They came from the staff of the Senate Standing Committee on National Resources. Mr Edwards and Mr Abbott did a good job, having been brought in at the last meeting to try to service Estimates Committee A.

My claim is that we ought to have a permanent staff. I think that one person has now been appointed to Estimates Committee A. If that is so, I support that appointment. During the hearings of that Estimates Committee last year we had to bring in the two staff members I have mentioned of the Senate Standing Committee on National Resources. They already had a very heavy work load in servicing the Senate Standing Committee on National Resources, of which I am also a member. I fully appreciate the work that those two members do. They had put upon them the extra burden of servicing Estimates Committee A. I do not think the job should have been given to them because it involved an extra work load.

Estimates committees need full time staff who can devote the whole of their time not only to looking at problems that arise at the time of Estimate committee hearings but also to looking at questions asked by members of the committees in years gone by, the answers given and the way members of the committee have been sidetracked by officers of the department who came before the committees. One of the problems we face when we seek to solicit information from public servants who come before Estimates committees is that we are told-I have complained about this on many occasions-that we should approach another Estimates committee to obtain the information we are seeking. As I have pointed out on many occasions, honourable senators can attend only one Estimates committee meeting at a time. It seems to me that the Government, in its wisdom and because it suits it, has split up the responsibilities of the departments that come before Estimates committees over a whole range of Estimates committees. It will be even worse this year because I understand that the proposal will be that there will be eight Estimates committees instead of six Estimates committees. An honourable senator who is pursuing one line of thought and trying to obtain information on it will be told that he should have raised that matter before another Estimates committee. Therefore, he is unable to obtain the information that he seeks.

As I have said before, when we come back to the Committee of the Whole and we get too close to the bone we find the Government applying the gag and we never obtain information which the Senate ought to be given. As I said when I spoke in this debate on 26 February, there should be a one-line Budget so that we can have sufficient staff to enable us to run our own affairs in this place and so that the Parliament itself can examine the expenditure of public moneys. We should not be sidetracked by being told that we should go to another committee to obtain the information we require. I come back to the point that when we come back to the Committee of the Whole and we are getting too close to the bone, the Leader of the Government in the Senate stands up and places a time limit on the debate and the debate is gagged.

I hope that the Standing Orders Committee will insist upon its recommendation that the Estimates committees should have a full time staff, not have staff seconded to them from standing committees. They should have a full time staff whose sole job it is to service the Estimates committees so that those committees can obtain the information sought. That expertise should be available to us not only during hearings but also at other times. Questions which we ask are often replied to in letters which are not incorporated in Hansard. As I said before, the only way such a letter will be incorporated in Hansard is for an honourable senator to stand up and read that letter into Hansard. Mr President is nodding his head. He gave an undertaking on the last occasion on which we discussed this matter that he would take some action to see that letters from Minister to senators in reply to questions asked at Estimates committee hearings or about Appropriation Bills are incorporated in the first Hansard published after we receive that information. If that happens I will be happy. But I will not be altogether happy until the Estimates committees have full time staff and the members of the Estimates committees have full access to that staff to explore the avenues in which they have an interest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Laucke Sen The Hon Sir C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I believe that there is a fundamental difference between the functions of Estimates committees and the legislative and general purpose standing committees. On the one hand we have the standing committees taking public evidence or evidence in camera on matters which have been referred to those committees for report ultimately to the Senate. On the other hand we have Estimates committees, which report ultimately to the Committee of the Whole. I am inclined to Senator Cavanagh' approach on this matter. Public moneys are involved. I do not think that an Estimates committee should seek, of its own volition, to take evidence in camera as it may not have the concurrence of the Senate as a whole to do so. As to the matter of public funding as it applies now, I believe that it would be anomalous for the Senate to be voting public moneys, moneys for public purposes, based upon the recommendations of committees which have taken their evidence in camera, evidence which might not be known to all senators.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McClelland Sen The Hon D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise briefly to support the remarks that have been made by my colleague Senator Cavanagh and by Sir Condor Laucke. I want to set out briefly the history of the establishment of Estimates committees. During the time that Senator Murphy was Leader of the Opposition in the Senate he was a great proponent of the establishment of standing committees and when, by sheer weight of numbers, we were able to impress upon the Senate of the time that a number of Senate standing committees should be established, the then leader of the Government in the Senate, Sir Kenneth Anderson, decided that, in addition to the establishment of Senate standing committees, there should be established Senate Estimates committees for the purpose of scrutinising public expenditure. In order to get the Senate standing committees established, the Opposition agreed at the time to the establishment of the Senate Estimates committees.
—It did not. The Democratic Labor Party voted with the government of the day.

—Senator Cavanagh is quite right. The Democratic Labor Party did vote with the government of the day. A condition was established at that time that only two Senate Estimates committees would sit at the one time. The reason for that was that every senator would be given a chance to attend any sitting of the Estimates committees.
—We don't have that now.

—That condition existed for quite some time. As Senator McLaren says, I do not think we have that chance now. But the very reason for that condition was to enable public scrutiny of the work of the Estimates committees and public scrutiny by senators of the finances of government. Indeed, I note that Australian Senate Practice by Odgers states:

SPEECH.PARA: On 20 September 1972 the Standing Orders Commitee recommended to the Senate that any decision that any Estimates Committee take in camera evidence should be made only by the Senate itself upon receiving a Special Report from the particular committee. In moving for the adoption of this recommendation, which was agreed to, it was pointed out that, if evidence were taken in camera, it may have only limited value because the evidence may not be known to the whole Senate, which has the responsibility-not the Estimates Committees-of passing appropriations. It was considered to be not consistent with the role of the Chamber in examining the Estimates for evidence to be taken in camera, except in extremely special circumstances.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is that an immutable truth?
—Senator Rae's proposed amendment is:

SPEECH.PARA: and this Committee direct the Standing Orders Committee to prepare and present to the Senate during this Session an amendment to the Standing Orders to enable Estimates Committees to take evidence in camera subject to reporting to the Senate the fact that such evidence has been taken in camera and the reasons for the Committee's decision to take such evidence in camera.

TALK.START.PARA: —You would still put your head in the sand, wouldn't you?

—I am just saying that as a senator I have a right to be party to the whole scrutiny of the public expenditure that is carried out by the Senate. I raise very strong objections to a Senate Estimates committee consisting of four, five or six members of the Senate, taking it upon itself to take in camera evidence which would not necessarily be disclosed to any of the other senators who would then be expected to pass the appropriation on the report of those four, five or six people.
—Every senator can attend that in camera hearing.
—How do they know it is on?

—How do they know it is on when, on Senator Rae's definition, the committee would report the fact that the in camera evidence had been taken after it had been taken. I would strongly object to that course. If a committee were wanting to take evidence in camera I would want to know in advance. That fact should be reported to the Senate and the Senate should then determine whether that committee should be allowed to take the evidence in camera. That is the existing rule. I think it is applied effectively. I believe that to water down that system we would be sealing the death knell on Senate Estimates committees.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to say a few words about this matter. It seems to me that this is a case of some honourable senators, such as Senator Douglas McClelland who has just spoken, trying to keep their heads in the sand and denying themselves the opportunity of obtaining information which ought to be obtained by the Estimates committees. It is wrong to say that because only six senators will be present they cannot be trusted to make a judgment on the matter and that we will not trust them to take evidence in camera or to do it properly. They will report on the matter so that if an honourable senator does not like what they have done he will certainly have an opportunity to criticise the honourable senators concerned about it. But those honourable senators may well be examining witnesses and obtaining information which, of course, would be confidential. Perhaps it would be information about relations with a company concerning contracts and so forth. Such matters would be quite harmful to--
—Lawyers' fees!
—I ask the honourable senator to leave lawyers out of this. Lawyers do not appear before Estimates committees.
—But their fees do. That is what it is all about.

—Lawyers may serve on Estimates committees. The honourable senator has lawyers on the brain. The fact is that he does not want to find Estimates committees operating most effectively by being able to get information. They may be able to do that. If honourable senators turn down this proposal they are being myopic and typically conservative about a situation in which we require better information. As the next item will show, we require better means and staff in order to investigate.

SPEECH.PARA: We also need the senators at the Senate Estimates committees to be able to make a decision perhaps on the spot. Something might crop up and it could be seen that further questions that would be asked would reveal confidential information about contracts or something of that sort. Honourable senators would advocate that the whole hearing be adjourned so that senators could go back to the Senate and ask the Senate for permission to take evidence in camera. With respect, that is quite stupid. That is a waste of the time of the Senate and of the committee. In fact, this suggested amendment by Senator Rae provides that honourable senators ought to have the right to take in camera evidence so that it can be taken at the time and then the situation reported to the Senate. I suggest that this is a perfectly sensible proposal and that only pettifogging reasons have been brought forward against it. It ought to be passed by this Committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have listened to Senator Missen with some interest. He made no mention of the fact that Estimates committees are not allowed to meet-unless by resolution of the Senate-on the same day as the Senate is sitting. What happens if we find that Estimates Committee A and Estimates Committee E are scheduled to sit on a Friday and all the other honourable senators have gone to their States when suddenly a matter arises so that either Estimates Committee A or Estimates Committee E decides that it wants to take evidence in camera? What opportunity has every honourable senator who has left Canberra and gone to his home State of being present when that evidence is taken in camera? He has no opportunity at all.
—How can you oppose it?

—I hotly oppose any proposition that Estimates committees be given the power to take evidence in camera. If any in camera evidence is needed the committee ought to come into the Senate. We should not try to hide any evidence because, as Senator Missen has said, perhaps we do not trust six members of the Estimates committee to take evidence in camera and then to report back to the Senate. Senator Missen says that we have only to believe what those six senators were told when the evidence was taken in camera, and accept that they believe that the evidence should be kept in confidence and should not be divulged to the rest of the Senate. There are 64 senators in this place. That means that 58 other senators might have a different point of view on some of the evidence that would have been given in camera and those honourable senators are not privy to that evidence. We have to take as gospel the information which those six senators bring back into this place. I am not prepared to vote for any motion which allows any six senators to take evidence in camera at Estimates committees. It is a different matter all together at standing committees, but at Estimates committees it is not. I am not prepared to vote for any proposition which would give honourable senators on Estimates committees the power to take evidence in camera, have that evidence to their hearts and not divulge it to any other member of the Senate.

—I had indicated when we previously debated this matter that I had known of a case for a request for evidence to be given in camera-a request which proved not to be necessary. I also said on that occasion that I would like to know why the present arrangement, whereby this present criterion of commercial confidentiality which enables an Estimates committee to make a request to the Senate to take in camera evidence, does not work. As I have said, I am prepared to support Senator Rae's amendment to see whether the Standing Orders Committee can come up with something which would fit the bill. But I still think the Senate needs to know why the present arrangement does not work. Is there an example of that arrangement making it impossible for the commercial confidentiality basis for in camera evidence to be activated?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Martin has asked for an example. Over the years, there has been considerable debate on this matter. I do not want to see it extended. However, I cannot let what is, in effect, the challenge go by without using an example which first gave rise to this matter coming before this chamber in 1972. It has also come before us on many occasions since. The example is that of a question which was asked by an honourable senator in relation to the activities of the Australian Broadcasting Commission, about the programs which it was purchasing, had purchased the previous year and was proposing to purchase for the current year in relation to sporting television. The question related to what the cost of a soccer program would be as opposed to the cost of a rugby program. Some honourable senators on the other side of the chamber may now realise who asked the question. Be that as it may, the honourable senator, I have no doubt, will recall it.

SPEECH.PARA: The witnesses from the ABC said that they would prefer not to answer that question because the negotiations had not been concluded. Eventually, after an adjournment to try to overcome the impasse which had arisen, it became quite clear in discussion which took place in an unfortunate way out the back, as it were, that if the ABC were required to answer the question, it was likely to cost it many tens of thousands of dollars in the negotiations which were proceeding at that time. The honourable senator did not want the information on the record but rather wanted to know the relativities.

It may well have been that the question could have been phrased in another way. The witnesses from the ABC could then have answered it without any problem at all and everyone would have been happy. If the Committee had been able to deal with that matter in camera, had that facility been available, it would have been possible to have the matter clarified and then cleared up simply and readily in public. Everybody would have been satisfied as to what was the situation without commercial confidentiality being breached and without a situation arising in which one of the statutory authorities of the Commonwealth was disadvantaged to a significant extent in its commercial dealings in relation to the purchasing of rights for televising particular programs.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does that now show that it was not necessary? It was resolved out the back.

—It may show it was not necessary but at the time the honourable senator who was asking the questions believed it was necessary. After some explanation, he understood that there was another way in which he could get the same information. The opportunity did not exist. In this case, the matter had to be resolved by way of private conversation out the back. It could have been done more formally under the proposition which is before the Senate tonight, that is, by the taking of in camera evidence which would have sorted the difficulty out. The Committee could then resume its public hearing and the matter could be cleared up readily and simply.

SPEECH.PARA: The suggestion that public moneys are involved and, therefore, there cannot be any question of taking evidence in camera, is one of the less substantiated suggestions which I have heard made in the chamber in relation to the operation of Estimates committees. The corollary is that we prefer not to know anything than to have some members of the Committee able to know something and to report to the Senate, which can then take whatever steps it regards as appropriate to find out more information in relation to that matter if it were deemed appropriate. In no way is there a subterfuge taking place. I remind honourable senators that under Standing Order 36AB, sub-standing order 10, provision is made that every honourable senator may attend meetings of Estimates committees. Senator Grimes interjected at one stage with what I think was a perfectly legitimate interjection. He said: 'But how would they know that some evidence was to be taken in camera?' I imagine that the answer to that question is that they would be likely to be present while those estimates were being dealt with if they thought that there were matters of interest to them which required their attendance during the hearing of the proposed appropriations.

I point out to anybody who is not familiar with the operations of an Estimates committee that its meeting is programmed and it goes from step to step in dealing with the proposed appropriations. An honourable senator monitoring what is happening in that committee knows when it is likely to reach a particular part of the appropriations. If the honourable senator is interested, he can be there and is entitled, under the Standing Orders, to participate. There is no secrecy. Every honourable senator can participate. The choice being put before the Senate tonight, on the basis of the argument which is opposing this amendment, is that we would rather know nothing than have the opportunity for every honourable senator to know something. That is the rather incredible proposition which I find being made repeatedly as a result of the Standing Orders Committee reports but never yet accepted by a majority of this chamber. In the eight or nine years in which this matter has come before the chamber, it has repeatedly approved that this would make the operation of the Estimates committees more effective and that it is no different from the Senate permitting a standing committee or a select committee to do this.

I do not accept the argument that it is correct for the Senate to be voting funds, when it does not have full information of the details and when, in fact, this amendment would enable all honourable senators to obtain full information if they wished to be present when the Committee takes the evidence in camera. The alternative is that no honourable senator obtains the information. That is a preposterous situation to be arguing. I find it quite surprising that some eminent people who put that view have not seen the total fallacy in the view which they have put.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cavanagh Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak again on this matter. I ask Senator Rae to show the difference that is involved. I do not think there is a great deal of difference. His motion gives an instruction to the Standing Orders Committee to bring down a recommendation for the alteration. We are committed to the alteration before it is considered. Senator Rae has given as an example a legitimate case where there may have been a need to take some evidence in camera. He mentioned that this happened in 1972 in relation to the Australian Broadcasting Commission. I think he reported that the complaint came back to the Senate. The Senate adopted a recommendation of the Standing Orders Committee to get over that matter. The recommendation was that the committee seek leave of the Senate to take the evidence. So the complaint of Senator Rae has been overcome. He has accepted that now. He does not put his finger on one occasion when that has not worked. Senator Martin asks where this has not worked, but no one can say that it has not been tried. There has been no occasion when an Estimates committee came back to the Senate and asked for the Senate to give approval on the operation of the relevant Standing Orders.
—How could they when the Senate had risen?

—If there were justification, a committee would have done so. My condemnation of the motion is that there may be a need to alter the position and that approval has to be given by the Senate. I am not opposed to the Standing Orders Committee looking into the matter to see whether there is a better way to proceed. I am of the opinion that there should be some safeguards. The Estimates committee should not suddenly meet and then decide to take the evidence in camera. A dangerous precedent is being established here that will grow and grow. If Senator Rae is of the opinion that the present Standing Order does not work, I am not opposed to a motion asking the Standing Orders Committee to look into the matter again. Senator Rae's amendment reads:

SPEECH.PARA: 'and this Committee directs the Standing Orders Committee-
I draw attention to the word 'direct'.

. . . to prepare and present to the Senate during this Session an amendment to the Standing Orders to enable Estimates Committees to take evidence in camera subject to reporting to the Senate the fact that such evidence has been taken in camera and the reasons for the Committee's decision to take such evidence in camera.

The question is whether the Committee of the Whole or the Senate agrees with the evidence being taken in that way. That is the position. This motion is designed to give power to the Committee to take evidence in camera without a reference to the Senate. This is complete executive control. Unless we can indicate that the existing Standing Order has not worked, I say that this motion should not be carried. If any senator wishes the Standing Orders Committee to consider whether there is a better procedure for taking evidence in camera than the present one, I would not oppose a motion to that effect. But by referring the matter to the Standing Orders Committee and asking for a recommendation whether it is in order for the Senate to give the Estimates committees the power to hear evidence in camera, we are simply agreeing to an Estimates committee being able to decide on the question of evidence.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to ask Senator Rae a question. I believe that the Estimates committees are part of the Committee of the Whole. I am well aware of the point he has made that evidence given in Estimates committees should at least be available to some senators if it cannot be available to all. If a senator who is a member of another Estimates committee-and most senators are members of Estimates committees-and who has an interest in a particular area finds that in camera evidence has been taken while he or she has been on another committee, would that senator have access to that evidence even though he or she had not been present at the time it was given? I believe that, even though that evidence would not be made public in the Senate itself, as long as every member of the committee had access to that in camera evidence, that procedure would fit in with the Committee of the Whole concept.

—I find it inconceivable that the amendment moved by Senator Rae is not acceptable. When a Senate Estimates committee meets to examine the Estimates it goes through all the hard work of examining witnesses and everything else, reports back to the Senate, and the Senate accepts its findings together with any reservations on the part of the people who sit on those committees. The same Estimates committee may be asked to hear in camera evidence. Some honourable senators are saying: 'Whilst we accept the findings of a Senate committee when it reports back after examining the Estimates, we do not want to give that committee the right to hear in camera evidence'.
—No one said that; they have the power now.

—I think that line of reasoning is quite inconceivable. Senator Cavanagh will accept the findings of an Estimates committee which has examined the Estimates when it reports to the Senate. One or two of the members of that committee may have a matter to put before the Committee of the Whole but generally we accept the findings of that committee. Yet Senator Cavanagh is not prepared to accept that committee saying that it will hear in camera evidence from people who want to give evidence in camera. He wants the whole Senate to approve of that action. I think it is inconceivable that we cannot say to that committee: 'You determine whether that evidence should be heard in camera. If it is heard in camera, report back to the Senate as you report to the Senate the findings of the committee in the consideration of the Estimates'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the amendment moved by Senator Rae. I know that there are historical reasons for the creation of a particular situation when Estimates committees were first established, but that was some years ago. Quite frankly, I was not here and I am sure that over 50 per cent of the honourable senators who are here now were not here either when those reasons were put forward originally. We ought to consider the situation as it is in 1981. I think that Senator Rae's argument, that the alternative to those senators who are present at an Estimates committee knowing what a matter is all about is that the Senate will know nothing of a specific matter is irrefutable.

SPEECH.PARA: I ask my friend Senator Cavanagh whether he would mind having a good look at the wording of the amendment. I must say that in common with every other senator in this chamber I greatly respect Senator Cavanagh's mind on matters such as this. If I understand it, Senator Cavanagh is saying that the word 'directs', which is the fourth word in Senator Rae's motion, would in some way or another bind the Senate to accept the amendment that would be put forward by the Standing Orders Committee. I ask Senator Cavanagh to read the amendment moved by Senator Rae and to consider that, if the Standing Orders Committee during this session suggested an amendment to the Senate, there is no question that the Senate would then give that amendment its consideration. It may amend or reject that amendment, but certainly, it would debate the amendment. I suggest to Senator Cavanagh that his suggestion that in some way or another the Senate would be bound to accept some amendment that it had not yet seen is not a proper argument.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Temporary Chairman, I have been misunderstood or my remarks cannot be understood. I explain that the direction proposed to be given to the Standing Orders Committee is to bring down a recommendation whether Estimates committees should be permitted to take evidence in camera and report to the Senate afterwards. The proposal is a definite direction to bring down a recommendation on the question. We are deciding tonight whether the basis for that evidence being taken in camera should be more lenient. I am not opposed to a proposal to refer the matter to the Standing Orders Committee to consider whether the Senate should adopt another method of permitting Estimates committees to take evidence in camera than provided for at present in the Standing Orders. That is not acceptable to Senator Rae because he wants to commit the Senate tonight.
—I have not said that it was not acceptable. I would just like to see the words of it. I have not said that it was or was not acceptable.
—It is a motion to defer it. There is no need to see the words of a deferral motion.

—No, there is not. Such a motion would refer the matter to the Standing Orders Committee to determine whether there is any method of handling the situation other than that presently provided for in the Standing Orders.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I feel that I should answer the question asked, very reasonably, I thought, by Senator Walters. She asked: What would happen to the evidence taken in camera? Would it be available to senators who were members of an Estimates committee but were not present when the evidence was given? The sort of thing that I had in mind in suggesting that we refer this matter in rather broad terms to the Standing Orders Committee was that the Standing Orders Committee would give consideration to the practicality and the implications of either making the transcript of evidence taken in camera available to all the senators who may attend-that is, the whole committee-or, alternatively, all those who are present at the time whether they are members of the Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: I would hope that the Standing Orders Committee, with this sort of direction and request from the chamber, would set about to consider this matter positively. That is something which for nine years the Standing Orders Committee has failed to do, notwithstanding the fact that this chamber has repeatedly referred this matter to it. The Standing Orders Committee has been induced over the years by what amounts to a minority attitude within this chamber to refuse to deal in detail with the question but rather to say that it objects to the principle. I am simply trying to achieve a situation in which the Standing Orders Committee will look at the detail. If questions such as the one asked by Senator Walters are raised, let us have something back from the Standing Orders Committee in relation to it.

TALK.START.PARA: —It depends on the way you word it.

—The direction needs to be so worded so that we avoid what has happened every other time such a direction has gone from this chamber to the Standing Orders Committee in the past nine years. That is quite a number of times. All I am trying to do is to avoid the matter being cut off without real consideration by the Standing Orders Committee, which reports back saying that it is against anything at all happening. I would like to see the Committee give real consideration as to how to implement it. It could then report in whatever way it deems appropriate.

SPEECH.PARA: A matter that I do not think has been made adequately clear at this stage is that the concern expressed by Senator McLaren and others can be answered in a simple way. The latter part of my amendment ensures that before the Committee of the Whole considers the Estimates-this answers also the point made by other honourable senators-and the vote is passed, there is a report from the Estimates committee which draws the attention of the Committee of the Whole to the fact that some evidence relating to such and such a matter was taken in camera for a particular reason. That would leave the Committee of the Whole in a position in which it could then decide whether it wishes, in the Committee of the Whole procedure, to endeavour to obtain further information in relation to it. It is not a secret; it is known to those senators who were sufficiently interested to be present. It can then become a matter of debate in the Committee of the Whole. But practicality requires that when the matter arises-the Senate would not be sitting, a whole horde of public servants would be waiting to answer questions-the committee should proceed to take evidence in camera and report to the Committee of the Whole on that so that it would then know that some evidence had been taken in camera. I thought that the latter part of this amendment answered the concern expressed earlier in the debate by some honourable senators.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is wrong with the present Standing Orders?
—The present situation is that nobody finds out the information.
—Come on; get on with it.

—I am trying to answer a question. If Senator Cavanagh agrees with the general principle, I give the assurance that I will not assert that the Committee of the Whole has agreed to implement the Standing Order when it comes in, but rather that the Standing Order would be drafted by the Standing Orders Committee and come back here for debate, which I think, is what Senator Cavanagh wants to see happen.

—I rise to support Senator Rae's amendment. I also support what has been said by other honourable senators. Whilst Senator Rae is, by this amendment, directing the Standing Orders Committee to prepare and present a report to the Senate, the final decision on that report from the Standing Orders Committee will be made by honourable senators in this chamber. So there is a safety valve in it and I cannot accept the concern that Senator Cavanagh has expressed tonight. I suggest to Senator Rae that he consider altering one word in his amendment. There appears to be a lot of concern about the use of the word 'directs'. Changing that to 'requests' may overcome one of the problems of Senator Cavanagh tonight. I feel that there is very little difference between the sentiments expressed in this discussion tonight by Senator Cavanagh and those expressed by Senator Rae and many other senators.
—I accept the amendment. If after this debate the Standing Orders Committee received a motion in terms of a request and it did not get the message, all I can say is that I would give up.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Laucke Sen The Hon Sir C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have expressed my point of view on this matter and have listened to the other arguments in respect of it. The present Standing Orders require an Estimates committee to seek the permission of the Senate when evidence is sought to be taken in camera. I can appreciate both sides of the argument on this matter. In the light of tonight's debate, it would appear that this matter should go back to the Standing Orders Committee for it to ascertain whether the present procedure should be retained, as has been expressed by some honourable senators, or whether there is some fruitful way of resolving this highly important matter. I think that this has been a very good discussion.

SPEECH.PARA: Unless I am convinced by further discussions that we are better off as we are or that a committee may operate in this way under certain conditions, while still giving credence to the supreme importance of the Committee of the Whole, of which Estimates committees are a part, and satisfy the requirements of the majority of senators, I suggest that the Standing Orders Committee should take another look at the matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought Senator Sir Condor Laucke suggested that the matter should be referred back to the Standing Orders Committee for reconsideration in the light of tonight's discussion. If that is his proposal, I would second it.
—Senator Sir Condor Laucke, are you proposing an amendment to the amendment?

—I have indicated that I think that it should be referred back to the Standing Orders Committee, but if the situation requires the moving of an amendment to an amendment, I will move one. I am saying that the matter should be referred back to the Committee.
—You are merely supporting Senator Rae's amendment with the word 'request'.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Sir Condor Laucke

TALK.START.PARA: —That is all, yes. I move as an amendment to the amendment:

INTERJECT.PARA: Leave out all words after 'and', insert 'requests the Standing Orders Committee to further consider this matter'.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that that is the only way in which to do it because Senator Rae's amendment directs the Committee to do certain things.
—I understood that Senator Rae accepted the word 'request' in place of 'direct'.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Sir Condor Laucke has moved as an amendment to the amendment that the matter be referred back to the Standing Orders Committee for further consideration and report. The question is:

INTERJECT.PARA: That Senator Sir Condor Laucke's amendment to Senator Rae's amendment be agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: At end of proposed amendment, as amended, add, ', and that in its consideration the Standing Orders Committee have regard to the desire of the Senate to consider a draft Standing Order to permit Estimates Committees to take evidence in camera'.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order. Is Senator Rae in order in moving the motion he has moved, in view of the fact that you, Mr Temporary Chairman, have declared that Senator Laucke's amendment has been carried? You said that the ayes have it.
—That is right.
—I submit that that motion has been carried unless somebody on the other side calls for a division. Senator Rae is out of order in moving the motion that he has moved.

—I raise a point of order. Mr Temporary Chairman, you called for a vote and stated that the ayes had it. Nobody rose on a division. Accordingly, the ayes have it and the matter is determined. Senator Rae is out of order in seeking to recanvass what is, in essence, a subdivision for that motion. I suggest that you move on to the next item in the report.

—I rise to speak to the same point of order. There is no reason why Senator Rae could not move a further amendment and that is what he did. He then moved a further amendment, which was to add to the motion to refer it back, certain requests--
—You cannot add to a motion.

—Of course one can add to an amendment. We have already amended the motion to send it back and we can send it back with any directions we care to place on it. Senator Rae then gave directions in a further amendment, and that amendment, I submit, is eminently in order and should be considered.

—My advice is that Senator Sir Condor Laucke's amendment to an amendment was carried, which means that Senator Rae's original amendment does not apply. My advice is that the question now is that the amendment to item No. 5, as amended, be agreed to.

—That is quite right, Mr Temporary Chairman, except for a further matter on which you apparently have not been advised, and that is that, perfectly legitimately, I have moved a further amendment. I am perfectly entitled to do that. Senator Sir Condor Laucke's amendment having been carried, I am now simply adding a further amendment in the way that Senator Sir Condor Laucke added an amendment. In no way is it other than perfectly in order. I cannot understand why there is this confusion.
—Mr Temporary Chairman, I wish to raise a point of order. I do not agree with what Senator Rae has said.
—The question is that the words proposed to be added to Senator Sir Condor Laucke's amendment be added.
—We have carried that motion.
—No, we did not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Temporary Chairman, I again move the motion which I claim to have legitimately moved already. I will read it in exact terms. It is an amendment which adds to what Senator Sir Condor Laucke moved. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: At end of proposed amendment, as amended, add, ', and that in its consideration the Standing Orders Committee have regard to the desire of the Senate to consider a draft Standing Order to permit Estimates Committees to take evidence in camera'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Temporary Chairman, I wish to raise a point of order. As I understand it, Senator Sir Condor Laucke moved an amendment. It was put, voted on and you declared it carried. No division was called. Do you now deny that you made such a declaration and in fact is the amendment not carried?
—Mr Temporary Chairman, I wish to speak to the point of order. You put the question and you ruled for the ayes.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak to sub-item (ii) relating to staff of Estimates committees. I think that this is a most hopelessly disappointing recommendation-if it may be called a recommendation-from the Standing Orders Committee. It states that it does not intend to make any recommendation on the matter at this stage. The situation, as it pointed out and as honourable senators will know, is that the staff members who have served the Estimates committees in the last year or two have been taken away from the standing committees. SPEECH.PARA: For many years, the standing committees of this Senate have produced reports and done work of value. TALK.START.PARA: —And future rearrangements.

—One can juggle people around from one place to another. I think that Senator Lewis is making the point that there may be room for staff to be moved from somewhere else; perhaps we could take some of the attendants away from the boxes and bring them in as research officers. I rather doubt that that could be done. The fact is that it is very unsatisfactory-as Senator Lewis would agree-just to pass this thing up and wait until something happens. The situation of staff ceilings has been examined in some of the committee proceedings going on at the present time. Doubt has been expressed-I expressed it also-about whether the staff ceilings imposed on the Senate office are lawful-whether it is necessary for the Senate to observe staff ceilings in this way. Perhaps that is a controversial view and would take some argument. Be that as it may, I say that I am not prepared to accept or to vote for a recommendation which states we will not do anything at the moment and that we will accept complacently a situation in which our committees will be deprived this year, as they were last year, of essential research staff for a period of three weeks or a month twice a year when the Senate is meeting. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Sen K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not sure that the Senate Standing Orders Committee can do anything about the staffing of Parliament House. However, I totally agree with Senator Missen's sentiments on this subject. We were told that the staff support for Estimates committees has been on a part time experimental basis and that this should continue. I think the proof of the experiment is whether it works. The support that part time staffing has given to Estimates committees has been valuable. That does not deny any of the difficulties that Senator Missen said this practice may put other committees into. I think it is deplorable that we are in a position of trying to make Parliament work through the committee system. It does not matter whether the committees be Senate standing committees, select committees, Senate Estimates committees or joint parliamentary committees. They are being set one against the other squabbling over how they should share staff, how much staff they should have, what rights the Senate staff has and what rights the House of Representatives staff has. Frankly, I think that the whole Parliament is being had on the issue.

SPEECH.PARA: I am interested to note that Senator Missen raised the point that it may not be in order for staff ceilings to be set in this area by the Public Service Board. I do not know whether it is legal but I think that it is outrageous that the Executive can tell us how much staff we may have in Parliament. The time has long since passed when this Parliament should have an appropriation to determine how many of which types of classifications of staff it should have-how many attendants and Hansard reporters it needs, how many committee staff and how many ancillary staff it needs. It is just outrageous that the Executive can say, 'You may have so many Hansard reporters-it may or may not be a satisfactory number-but you may not have further staff in the category that would provide support staff for parliamentary committees'. That is our business, not the business of Cabinet or the Public Service Board.

At the same time, I do not feel that the Standing Orders Committee can do very much about that situation. I note that there is a Senate Select Committee on Parliamentary Appropriations and Staffing. I was absent from this Parliament during the last sessional period; I assume that that select committee was set up in my absence. I am not au fait with all the details of what it is doing. I hope it is looking into the matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is very advanced.

—That is very good. I am very pleased to hear it. I hope the Committee serves some useful purpose. I have been Chairman of Senate Estimates Committee A on several occasions. That Committee in reporting on parliamentary appropriations has tried to make a point relating to the staffing of Parliament House. I think that the Senate certainly should say very seriously that we ought to have a parliamentary appropriation and that it should be Parliament's business how that appropriation is divided. I am not clear that by throwing out a section of the Standing Orders Committee report we are being fair to the Standing Orders Committee and making the point in the best possible way. It may not be very fair to the Standing Orders Committee just to toss out a section of its report.
—Is the system always very fair?

—Senator Missen has taken the pragmatic approach on this occasion. I think the President has tried to help. I would not want our action on this section of the report of the Standing Orders Committee to appear to rebuke the President, because he has indicated in evidence before the Estimates committees that he has attempted to help the situation and that he and Mr Speaker are trying to do something about it, although unfortunately without success at this stage. I think that the next step is probably in the hands of the Parliament. I am at pains to point out that I would not want any action on this section of the report to be taken as a rebuke to that Committee or to the President.

—I listened with great interest to Senator Missen and Senator Martin, both of whom, particularly Senator Martin said, if I heard them correctly, that the Standing Orders Committee cannot make any recommendations about the staffing of the Parliament. But at least the Senate can. It is within its power, as I said last week and again tonight, to pass a motion that there be a one-line appropriation for the Parliament. We have it in our hands here to pass that motion. Whilst we hear Government senators criticising the shortcomings of the Parliament which result from the determinations of the Executive, apparently in their own party room they do not put forward that point of view. They are prepared to put it here--
—How can you say that?

—If they put it forward strongly enough, they might get some results. I am saying that they ought to put it forward. The Parliament has the power. Both Senator Missen and Senator Martin have said that they are not happy with the decision of the Executive to impose ceilings on the staffing of the Parliament. I am not happy with that, and neither are my colleagues on this side of the chamber. We have expressed that point of view. I say in all sincerity that if any Government senator is prepared to put the proposition that we have a one-line appropriation for the Parliament he or she will get the support of the Opposition. We might then get down to taws and have this Parliament working as it should be working-not under the directions of an Executive which tries to put a stranglehold not only on the workings of members of parliament but also on the officers who serve us.

—I wish to say a word on this part of the report because I have previously made comments on the matter. I endorse what Senator Missen said with respect to the difficulties that are imposed on the standing committees of the Senate when staff have to be taken from the standing committees to service the Estimates committees. If we examine section 9 of the Public Service Act, we will find that the Presiding Officers have the right to appoint staff for the Parliament. I would like to see that provision tested. I know that the President very commendably has endeavoured to attract sufficient staff to service the Estimates committees but he is always confronted with the objection concerning staff ceilings. I think that is unacceptable to the Senate. I am sure that the Presiding Officers need the support of the Parliament to test that section of the Public Service Act.
—Could the President pay them without parliamentary appropriation?

—That is a question that may well be asked, and the purpose of establishing a select committee was to examine the whole question. I think we should look at the suggestion that the Parliament ought to have its own appropriation and ought to be the master of its own destiny with respect to funding and staffing. I like to think that later in this session the select committee that has been appointed to deal with this matter will come forward with some more positive propositions which will attract the total support of the Senate and, I am sure, reinforce the purpose of the Presiding Officers in this Parliament to assist, where they can, in a far more effective manner with respect to the question we are discussing at present. I suggest that it would be interesting to test that section of the Public Service Act in this way. I hope that ultimately we will resolve the problem to the satisfaction of the whole Parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make only a few remarks on this subject and to move an amendment in terms of the way I think it would be useful to deal with this section of the report. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: At end of motion add, 'but that consideration on any matters relating to the staffing of committees of the Senate arising from the Standing Orders report be deferred until the Senate has received the report of the Select Committee on Parliament's Appropriations and Staffing.

I believe that the Standing Orders Committee, as Senator Martin has said, is not really in a position to make detailed recommendations about the staffing of Estimates committees or indeed of any of the Senate's committees. But, we were simply to note the section of the Standing Orders Committee's report. It would appear, I think, that the Senate had noted, and accepted from its Standing Orders Committee, a report which says that the Committee does not make any firm recommendation on the matter. I believe the desire of the Senate in establishing the Select Committee on Parliament's Appropriations and Staffing was that the Senate would not want to make decisions, whether by way of positive decisions, by way of noting recommendations or by way of noting what is here a non-recommendation, prior to the date when it received and had the chance to consider the report of the Committee that the Senate established. I think quite clearly the Standing Orders Committee is not in a position to make those recommendations. The Select Committee was established for that specific purpose.

To put on the record a comment simply that the Standing Orders Committee, having looked at the question, was not in a position to make any recommendations would not advance the cause that all honourable senators are united on of seeing a greater degree of control over the Senate's business, including the Senate's committee responsibilities, exercised by the Senate itself. Rather than simply noting a report that says that no recommendation can be made, we should move to a position of saying that we defer consideration of any matters arising from this report on the question of staffing of Senate committees until such time as we have received the report of the Committee which the Senate specifically established to consider that very question. I think that would obviate the need for excessive debate on this item. We should simply record no decision until our own expert committee on the matter has reported and the Senate has had a chance to examine the recommendations of that committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Laucke Sen The Hon Sir C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer honourable senators to the words in the report before us with respect to the staffing of Estimates committees. They read:

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee notes that staff support for the Estimates committees has been on a part-time and experimental basis and considers that, in the absence of more permanent staff arrangements, this should continue. I must state to this Committee that, since this report was presented, we have filled the six positions on the six committees with six research officers. That has been done. Each committee now has its own research officer.

TALK.START.PARA: —In view of what the President has outlined to the Senate, I ask him: What will be the position now in view of the proposal before us that there be eight Senate Estimates committees? Is he in a position to find the two extra staff to staff the proposed new Estimates committees?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Laucke Sen The Hon Sir C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The situation is that the six positions have been filled. If there are to be eight positions, the challenge lies ahead of us to fill two extra positions. I cannot give any firm assurance now in respect of that but I can indicate to the Committee that since the presentation of this report six positions have been filled. Some of the comment here tonight indicates that there has been an appreciation of that fact.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —The motion before the Chair is:

INTERJECT.PARA: To that motion, Senator Puplick has moved, as an amendment:

At end of motion add, 'but that consideration on any matters relating to the staffing of committees of the Senate arising from the Standing Orders Report be deferred until the Senate has received the report of the Select Committee on Parliament's Appropriation and Staffing'.

Item 5(iii)-Appearance of House of Representatives Ministers before Estimates Committees.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question now is:

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Sen K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: At end of motion add 'and this Committee requests the Standing Orders Committee to prepare and present to the Senate during this Session an amendment to the Standing Orders to enable House of Representatives Ministers to appear before and give evidence to Senate Estimates Committees'.

The report of the Standing Orders Committee refers to the suggestion that House of Representatives Ministers should appear before the Senate Estimates committees to give evidence in the same way that Senate Ministers do. The report notes that there are no constitutional or procedural barriers to House of Representatives Ministers appearing before Senate committees, including Estimates committees. The report then raises a number of difficulties with the proposal. The purpose of my moving an amendment to the motion is to enable the Committee of the Whole to indicate its opinion on the subject of House of Representatives Ministers appearing before Senate Estimates committees and, by voting in favour of my amendment, to indicate to the Standing Orders Committee that it wishes that Committee to proceed with whatever measures are necessary in relation to the Standing Orders to enable this procedure to take place. The issue is a serious and a basic one.

I would like to give my opinion on some of the points raised in the report of the Standing Orders Committee and also to give my opinion on the principle of House of Representatives Ministers appearing before Senate Estimates committees. I have to say, with respect, that I do not consider the difficulties raised in paragraph 20 of the report of the Standing Orders Committee to be substantial ones. I do not want to appear to be unkind to House of Representatives Ministers or not understanding of their difficulties. However, I do not feel that the practical difficulties referred to by the Standing Orders Committee are insuperable barriers. In fact, I do not consider them to be substantial barriers. The question of the difficulty of arranging times of meeting to suit House of Representative Ministers who have commitments in that House is, I think, not a very difficult one. We have had until recently only five Senate Ministers who have had to spread themselves over six Estimates committees. That has created difficulties because on that sixth committee where there was not a Minister we had to bring in a series of Ministers who were already appearing before other Estimates committees. There were some practical difficulties. It worked but it had to be worked at hard to make it work. If we had the situation of being able to call all of the Ministers-25, 26 or however many-before Estimates committees, however many of them there may be, and one does not envisage a large increase in their number, it should be possible to arrange some timetable to meet the problem. The Senate Ministers carry a far heavier load, I believe, in relation to timetabling for the chamber than do House of Representatives Ministers. Again, I do not want to appear to sound too cavalier about the responsibilities of House of Representatives Ministers but that House does have House duty-the requirement to sit in the House-spread among 20 people, and those Ministers do not carry a heavy representational load. Only a small number of Senate Ministers have to be represented in the House of Representatives, so that House of Representatives Ministers present their own Bills and very few others. They are not tied to the chamber as much as Senate Ministers are. I do not consider that it would be so difficult to arrange the timetabling of Estimates committees and indeed of the commitments of House of Representatives Ministers that it could not be handled. I believe it could be handled because I think our Senate Ministers showed that they handled a far more difficult proposition in relation to timetabling when we were in the situation of having only five Ministers with six committees.

The second point raised by the report of the Standing Orders Committee relates to the difficulty of predicting when particular departments will be examined by the Estimates committees. That difficulty, I think, has already been covered in my reference to Estimates Committee F and the problems it had when we were a Minister short in relation to the number of committees. It is not possible to predict exactly when particular departments will be examined. Nevertheless, Senate Ministers have seen their responsibility to the Senate and to Estimates committees and have made the adjustments necessary. I think the Senate is very grateful for the fact that they have done that. I would not think that the difficulty is too much for House of Representatives Ministers.

The third point raised in the report of the Standing Orders Committee relates to the difficulty of predicting in advance whether questions to be asked during the hearings are such as to require the attention of the Minister concerned. I am afraid the point of that objection pretty well goes over my head because we can have a situation in which a Senate Minister can be answering questions in relation to his or her portfolio and the Ministers are there whether they or their officers are answering the questions. Our Ministers have never required and we have never required that they sit before the committees only on those instances when they personally are answering questions. I think the position is to the contrary.

At present we have a number of Ministers who can answer questions in relation to their own portfolios and on occasions they will refer to departmental advisers questions asked of them by senators. That applies even in relation to their own portfolio. However, what happens when we move into an examination of the estimates of those departments for which the Minister is only representing and it is not his own department is something quite unsatisfactory both for the Minister and for the Estimates committees. It is not often that a Minister can answer questions under those circumstances and certainly not questions relating to detail. Ministers can answer questions relating to policy. We really are in a situation in which once we move beyond a Minister's own portfolio we can examine only the public servants. It is quite satisfactory that we examine public servants. But I do not think it is entirely satisfactory that we do not examine the Minister as well. We are unable to ask questions in certain areas where it is appropriate that the Minister is the one who should be answering in relation to his own responsibilities. The report states:
If questions arise requiring answers from House of Representatives Ministers, it is a simple and convenient practice for written answers to be provided.

In my opinion that is not a satisfactory arrangement. I am sure that all honourable senators who have sat on Estimates committees have been in the position where they have agreed to information being provided in a written form subsequent to the committee meeting and it has not come in a satisfactory form. The answer has come after the committee has finished its deliberations and is about to report to the Senate and we are about to consider Estimates and Estimates committees reports in the Senate. It is too late then. We are not in a better position then if we wish to point out that the written answers have not given us all the information that we would have sought or, if they have given us the information, that there are other issues which we would like to pursue as they arise from that answer. It is too late to pursue it in the Senate in the way in which it should be pursued.

The Senate Minister is in no superior position. He can only turn to his departmental advisers here when we are in the Senate chamber and seek further advice. He is certainly in no superior position. I will not accept that it is a simple and convenient practice for written answers to be provided. I will go on record and say that frequently I have been dissatisfied with the answers when they have come but they have come too late for me to do anything about it through the Estimates committee's procedure. The proposal that the Committee suggests raises large questions which go to the fundamental of the bicameral system. No one is suggesting-I am certainly not-that House of Representatives Ministers should come to this Chamber to answer questions and to present legislation. I think, on the whole, we proceed satisfactorily in those matters. I think the Estimates committees are a separate point. I think, from the point of Government Ministers being able to present evidence in relation to their own departments, that it should be more satisfactory for those Ministers to be able to do it themselves rather than have to depend on others to answer questions directly relating to their portfolio. I am not suggesting for one minute that the Senate Ministers representing House of Representatives Ministers do not do their job adequately or do not attempt to do it adequately. I am saying that I do not think it is satisfactory from the point of view of the Ministers or of the departments concerned or from the point of view of the Senate.

I consider it fundamental to the improved operations of Estimates committees that they receive evidence from House of Representatives Ministers. At present, House of Representatives Ministers give evidence to Senate standing committees. They may give it under very particular circumstances. It may be, for example, in camera. It is not as though there is no precedent for House of Representatives Ministers appearing before Senate committees. They do appear before Senate standing committees. There is not a precedent for their appearing before Estimates committees. The Standing Orders Committee report points out that there are no constitutional or procedural barriers. I think we should move to get procedures initiated which would enable them to come before Senate Estimates committees.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to Senator Martin's amendment I am prepared to support it. I think it has a lot of merit. She might be surprised that I support any motion which she moves in this place. In considering the proposition about the appearance of House of Representatives Ministers before Senate Estimates committees we may be faced with the other place requesting that Ministers in this place appear before House of Representatives Estimates committees. The House of Representatives does have Estimates committees now. I would not object to that. Paragraph 19 of the Standing Orders Committee report states:

SPEECH.PARA: It is considered that there are no constitutional or procedural barriers to the appearance of Ministers who are members of the House of Representatives before Senate committees, including estimates committees.
I hope that means that when a Minister in the House of Representatives is invited to appear before the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations he will not refuse to appear.

TALK.START.PARA: —They have not been invited to appear. They have been asked to comment.

—They have been asked to comment, then, and I hope that they will appear. I will say no more about that. Senator Evans seems to be getting in a bit of a fit. When we debate the Standing Orders in this place I think everybody has a right to express a point of view. We express that point of view quite apart--
—However ignorant.

—Senator Evans might say 'however ignorant' but we can express that view quite apart from party affiliation. That is a right that we all have. We are able to exercise that right. I intend to do it irrespective of what Senator Evans might say or how often he might flap his papers on his desk. As I said at the outset I am prepared to support Senator Martin's proposal. As it is getting near to the time for the adjournment of the Senate I will not say any more. I hope this matter is voted on before we adjourn. I support the amendment moved by Senator Martin.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I oppose the amendment moved by Senator Martin. I think there is a substantial point which goes to the arrangement and operation of a bicameral parliament and which, in fact, I think can be resolved at this stage by noting the recommendations that the Standing Orders Committee makes. We do not need to go to the stage of requesting the Standing Orders Committee now to prepare a Standing Order which, in its own turn, would therefore come back to the chamber for debate and which would raise the whole matter again. I think we can grapple at least with some of the issues that arise by Senator Martin's moving this amendment and, at least, start to examine them. I think the Standing Orders Committee is quite right to say that there are no consitutional barriers to the appearance of Ministers who are members of the House of Representatives before Senate committees. I accept the point Senator McLaren was making that the converse of that would be an acceptance by the Senate that its Ministers should be available for questioning by committees, however established or whatever the nature of those committees, established by the House of Representatives.
—They have Estimates committees now, senator.

—They do. They are not as well developed as the Senate Estimates committees are. They lack the incisive and penetrating questions that Senator McLaren always brings to Senate Estimates committees. Nevertheless, they are undoubtedly seeking to make a contribution.
—That certainly applies to Estimates Committee C because that is a high calibre one.

—I take it that the fact that it is a high calibre committee is not to be taken to mean simply that a large number of its members are known to be extremely large bores. The procedural barriers and practical barriers that are raised by way of comments made in paragraphs 19 and 20 of the Standing Orders Committee report do need some investigation.

SPEECH.PARA: I have no doubt that there would be problems with this proposal in a number of areas. I envisage for instance the way in which one would deal with the Senate calling the Prime Minister before one of its Estimates committees in order to examine the estimates of the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet. I think the way in which that sort of procedure would develop would, in fact, be the first step in the total ruination of the process of Senate Estimates committees. I believe that the procedures that we have been following, imperfect as they may be, have strengthened the Senate's oversight and scrutiny of the estimates of government departments. I think that the idea of provoking what undoubtedly would be a confrontation when, from time to time, Ministers in the House of Representatives decide that they are responsible to the House of Representatives and are unable to appear before Senate Estimates committees will lead us into some difficulty.
