DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Birkenhead Point Shopping Complex-Social Security Benefits-Senator's Motoring Mishap: Appreciation of Assistance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! In conformity with the sessional order relating to the adjournment of the Senate, I formally put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mulvihill Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I speak tonight at the request of a number of electors in the Federal electorate of Lowe for which I happen to be the duty senator. I am prompted to speak by Mr Michael Maher, the New South Wales State member for Drummoyne. My concern is at the Commonwealth Government's control or lack of control over foreign investment, particularly in the real estate field. I refer to the Birkenhead Point shopping complex of which both the senatorial Ministers from New South Wales would be aware. It is a big shopping centre. It has been the scene of a sort of octopus operation by a real estate firm known as Kingsgate Investments Pty Ltd. The firm operates from Singapore. It originally took over the Hyatt Kingsgate Hotel at Kings Cross. At that complex there is a dispute between certain small shopkeepers in an arcade over whether they will be closed down. I think the original buyers visualised that there would be more high-density housing.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not cavil about the need for more housing for the inner city area. That is not at stake. I am concerned about the people in the Lowe electorate. They are very adequately represented by the State member, Mr Maher, who is eternally vigilant on these sorts of matters. He telephoned me this evening to point out that a considerable number of small shopkeepers within the Birkenhead Point complexes are concerned about this matter. I understand that the people in this area, which is like a lot of other metropolitan Sydney shopping complexes such as the Westfield shoppingtowns and others, have been enticed to go into this field of merchandising. Now they find that the overseas operators who masquerade under the name of Kingsgate Investments Pty Ltd are threatening their livelihoods.

It is not the time of night to have a long discourse on the pros and cons of the influx of foreign capital. It certainly has a place in any country but the ground rules have to be very effective. I will ask the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Senator Peter Baume, for permission to have incorporated in Hansard an article on the Hyatt Kingsgate project by Hazel Pillemer, property reporter for the Sydney Morning Herald, which appeared in the that newspaper on 2 January 1981. While the Minister is perusing that document, I simply say that I am asking whether there can be some joint consultation with the New South Wales State Government and appropriate local government people so that we do not get a sudden suppression of this sort of small business operation in big shopping complexes. The Minister is indicating that he approves of the extract from the Sydney Morning Herald being incorporated in Hansard-
Leave granted.
The article read as follows-
HYATT KINGSGATE SALE REFLECTS LOCAL APATHY
By Hazel Pillemer, Property Reporter

The recently completed sale of the Hyatt Kingsgate hotel complex in Kings Cross to a Singapore-based company shows how overseas interests are more willing than Australians to take on the risks of hotel investment.
The Hyatt Kingsgate is the third major hotel to be sold to overseas interests in the past year.
The hotel complex was sold on June 14 for $25 1/2m, but settlement only took place on December 22.

The complex was sold to Tesela Pty Ltd, a shell company-which is in the process of having its name changed to Kingsgate Investments Pty Limited-whose principals are wealthy real estate developers and investors Mr Ho Whye Chung and Mr Ho Sim Guan.
They are resident in Singapore but operate out of Hong Kong and have substantial property investments throughout South-East Asia.
This is believed to be their first Australian-and their first hotel-venture.
The property was formerly owned by Kingsgate Property Management Services Pty Limited, which was controlled by Tinnabruich Pty Limited, the State Superannuation Board, and Wardley Australia Limited.
Tinnabruich is an investment consortium which includes the Rothschild group and Australian and South African interests.
Wardley Australia Limited is the merchant banking arm in Australia of Wardley Limited, which is the merchant banking arm of the Hong Kong and Shanghai Banking Corporation.
The Hyatt Kingsgate hotel complex was developed by the South African based Summit organisation which collapsed in 1975.
It was then taken over by the various parties in a financial reconstruction.
The real estate agents and property consultants Jones Lang Wootton were responsible for introducing the purchasers.
It is understood that the $25 1/2m was sufficient to repay the various contributions made by the three vendor partners, but that there was no material profit made.
As such it appears that the hotel and the shopping arcade earned only enough to cover the carrying and other costs.
It is believed that the Foreign Investment Review Board required a sale of about 49 per cent of the equity in the hotel within 10 years to Australian interests.

TALK.START.PARA: —I return to my summing up. I simply seek a tripartite conference between the Federal Government, the State Government-in this case the New South Wales Government-and local government authorities to ensure that, whilst some foreign capital is necessary in many ways, it is not to be used as a steam-roller approach in the case of the Birkenhead Point shopping complex so that these shopkeepers go to the wall. Whilst there may be some value to the economy in the initial influx of capital, if 200 shopkeepers go to the wall they will add considerably to the unemployment statistics. On that basis I ask the Minister for Finance (Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle) to take up this matter urgently. Perhaps by the middle of next week we will be able to give some indication to these people of Birkenhead Point that their livelihoods are not on the block.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise tonight a matter which demonstrates the difficulties that can arise with too rigid an application of one section of the Social Services Act. I ask the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) to look into not only this case but also other cases which seem to bedevil the administration of social security in this country. The case to which I wish to refer involves a Tasmanian mother who has suffered unconscionably as a result of a very rigid approach by the Department of Social Security to her eligibility to a widow's pension. The woman, Mrs Ferguson, separated from her husband in 1956 and later divorced him. A year later she took in a male boarder who had been working for a relative and who had been living in less comfort and at much greater cost in a boarding house. At that time she valued the protection he gave to her. Later she fostered two of his children who had been under the care of the Social Welfare Department in Tasmania since his marriage had failed.

SPEECH.PARA: I have read the very lengthy file, which includes a sworn statement from Mrs Ferguson, correspondence from the Department of Social Security and the Australian Legal Aid Office and a very cogently argued case from Mr Michael Longbottom, her solicitor, from which I will quote later. I have seen nothing in all this material which presents Mrs Ferguson as anything other than a very caring woman, and one who, having been in trouble herself, understands only too well the value of stretching out the hand of help to people in need. At other times she has assisted another pensioner who had nowhere to go; she has offered to care for children who lost their homes in the 1967 Hobart bushfires. Once she looked after nine children belonging to a neighbour who had been in hospital. It would seem to me that her motivation has been charitable and Christian throughout.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I take a point of order in a very friendly way. I am a little concerned. This is a matter which has not come to my attention before. I understand that it is the subject of a formal appeal before the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. I have no wish to hinder Senator Grimes in any way. Given that the matter is before a tribunal of this sort, I just query whether the detail should be gone into. I have not looked at the authorities to see the extent to which one could consider the matter in the same way as one would consider a matter if it were before a court. I have absolutely no doubt about the bona fides of Senator Grimes in putting this matter before me and seeking my consideration of it. I merely raise this point because I have only just had a look at the facts-or such facts as are available to me at this stage. I ask him to consider the fact that the matter is before a tribunal. The lady is being represented by a solicitor and it is open to argument whether this is the appropriate forum in which to air the matter at this stage.

—I have considered that matter. Senator Chaney would know that one of the difficulties is that the lady concerned is getting no support from anyone while waiting for this matter to be put before the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. A colleague of mine and I have consulted with Mrs Ferguson's solicitor, who knows of the procedure being followed here tonight. As I am not a lawyer, I do not know whether the sub judice rule-which I suppose is what the Minister is talking about-applies to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal in this way. It seems to me that there are two problems in this case: Firstly, the lady is without support and it seems to us that the only support that she is likely to get in the meantime is from the Department of Social Security; and, secondly, appeals before this Tribunal are subject to delay and the appeal in question has been subjected to considerable delay. What are we to do?
—Has a date of hearing been set down?
—No date of hearing has been set down at all. What are we to do in situations of injustice such as this? Are we to be limited in what we can say and do in this place because of such delays?

—I am trying to be helpful, not unhelpful. I am certainly prepared to examine the matter that is raised by Senator Grimes. I am not able to say, on the knowledge of the facts that I have at the moment, whether Mrs Ferguson would be eligible for alterative forms of benefit, such as a special benefit. I would be happy to examine that matter tomorrow morning and, on that basis, Senator Grimes might then wish to take the matter up again on the adjournment. I do not raise this out of a sense of technicality. As far as I am concerned, it is without precedent in the sense that I have not had to deal with a similar matter in the same way. I would be happy to give the matter urgent consideration in collaboration with Senator Grimes to see what is the most appropriate course. We may not agree on that tomorrow, but I think it would be worth examination and it removes any risk of any argument later that an injustice has been caused by the matter being aired in this chamber when it is to come before the Administrative Appeals Tribunal.

—I am in some difficulty because I accept Senator Chaney's offer in good faith. Senator Chaney has quite rightly pointed out-I am not without some experience in these matters-that one alternative is a special benefit. Mrs Ferguson has, in fact, had a special benefit removed and refused. We are in a difficult situation if the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, which was set up to assist people in circumstances like this and set up as a form of appeal, is going to be used in this way to prevent honourable senators from raising cases like this in the Senate on the adjournment or at any other time.
—I am not seeking that.
—I do not know what your ruling is on matters like this, Mr President.

—I am not seeking a ruling. I am not in a state of mind where I am clear enough to take a point of order to prevent the honourable senator from raising the matter. My suggestion merely was that he might like to consider examining the matter with me tomorrow. That would mean that, at worst, he could raise the matter on the adjournment debate tomorrow evening if it appeared that that was the only satisfactory course. However, if he feels that his duty to Mrs Ferguson, who is a constituent of his, is such that he should continue, I have no intention of taking a formal point of order. I was not seeking to intervene in an obstructionist sense.

—I wish to make a comment before the honourable senator resumes his speech. In sub judice matters, anything which can influence a hearing and which can, in any way, have an effect for good or for bad-any influence which can be brought to bear on that which is being considered-is better not brought up. I leave that to your discretion. The Minister has indicated that he does not make a point of sub judice on this matter.

—I accept what you have said, Mr President. In view of Senator Chaney's assistance in cases like this in the past, I am certainly willing to discuss this matter with him tomorrow in the determination that should it not be resolved satisfactorily I will obviously have to bring it up on the adjournment debate tomorrow night. Therefore, in that spirit, I will do so. I must say, though, that your statement concerns me a little. We have a case here where, in fact, the lady and her solicitor know what is going on, have been subjected to long delays and may well be subjected to long delays in the future because of the failure to set a hearing for this matter. I also question whether raising matters like this in the Senate can affect the wise judicial gentlemen on the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. In the spirit of what Senator Chaney has offered, I will certainly take it up with him tomorrow with the proviso that I will bring it up again if necessary.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Melzer Sen J.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to take up a few minutes of the Senate's time on the adjournment debate to record an incident which illustrates some of the finer points of human behaviour which we sometimes ignore. I pay a tribute to two extremely kind and cheerful members of the farming community in South Gippsland in Victoria. The two men concerned are Mr Ken Price and Barry Dakin of Glen Forbes. I made their acquaintance on Monday afternoon last. The south Gippsland highway in Victoria was at a standstill. I was expected at a dinner in Melbourne. I attempted a detour through the lovely country of South Gippsland. I was a little too anxious to get home and not observant enough on a strange road. I went round a bend too wide and slipped over the edge of a steep drop.

SPEECH.PARA: A very kind passing motorist offered to find help and within minutes Mr Dakin and his tractor arrived and, at the same time, Mr Price pulled up. They did not even hesitate. They did not ask or consider whether it was their business to help me, whether they should do it or who I was. They came to help. Mr Price went off to get his large truck and because of the efforts of the two of them my car was back on the road ready and able to proceed within minutes. Neither of the men would accept any payment. They were both as courteous, as helpful and as cheerful as they could be. They were a tonic to meet.

When I offered to pay, Mr Barry Dakin said: 'Give the farmers a go in parliament instead'. I think the community generally can take a lesson from two such unselfish, cheerful and helpful people. I wanted to put my thanks on record. I will not forget their generosity. When the farmers' situation is brought before this House I will always remember the spirit with which they came to my assistance. From now on I will be even more conscious of the need to give the farmers a go. I have kept faith with my two farmers of South Gippsland. I am on record as saying I will give the farmers a go.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have had two contributions on the adjournment debate tonight. I will refer briefly to Senator Melzer's very nice speech and to the tribute she has paid to Mr Dakin and Mr Price for the help they gave her earlier this week. I am reminded of an incident that occurred when I was at the Singleton Army Camp as a captain in the Citizen Military Forces. The weather at that time was very hot and as a medical officer I made a decision that there was an urgent need to inspect the local water supply which was the Hunter River. We tried to cross the Hunter River in a jeep at what was called a low level bridge. The only trouble was the bridge did not exist. Of course, we did not have to report the incident to any officers because the jeep started straight away when it was pulled from the river.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Sibraa Sen K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 3 December 1980:

QUESTION.PARA: Did the judgment brought down in Redy v. Redy give the father custody of his children because they were residing with their mother in a refuge and this accommodation was deemed unsatisfactory by the Judge because of its temporary nature; if so, can the Minister assure women who are residing in refuges or who may wish to reside in refuges in the future that they will not lose custody of their children because of the obviously temporary nature of refuges.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Having regard to s. 121 of the Family Law Act, which prevents the publication of details of proceedings under the Act, and the purpose of that section to protect the privacy of individuals, I do not propose to provide in this answer the case details sought by the question.

As to the second part of the question, the Family Law Act requires a court hearing proceedings for the custody or guardianship of, or access to, a child to regard the welfare of the child as the paramount consideration. In custody proceedings in which the mother of the child is temporarily resident in a refuge, the significance of this fact would depend upon the effect the court thought it had on the welfare of the child in all the circumstances of the particular case.
